webTitle: Germany send loud warning to Keegan

fields.headline: Germany send loud warning to Keegan
fields.trailText:
Germany 4 -1 Spain
Germany last night sounded an early warning to England's World Cup hopes when Rudi Völler's first selection enjoyed a 4-1 victory over Spain in their friendly in Hanover.
fields.body:
Germany last night sounded an early warning to England's World Cup hopes when Rudi Völler's first selection enjoyed a 4-1 victory over Spain in their friendly in Hanover.

Mehmet Scholl and Alexander Zickler scored two goals apiece as the Germans began their rehabilitation impressively and the margin of victory will put England on even greater alert before Kevin Keegan's team open their qualifying campaign against Völler's new-look team at Wembley on October 7.

Last night's match was a triumphant start for Völler, the interim coach who will guide the German team in his one-year tenure.

Scholl scored the only goal of the first half with a superb curling 20-yard free-kick and he put his side further ahead before Zickler added two goals in quick succession as the Germans overwhelmed a reshuffled Spanish team.

Raul, the Real Madrid striker, outmanoeuvred two defenders and found the roof of the net in the 69th minute for Spain's only goal.

The Spanish league season has not yet started and the Spaniards, quarter-finalists at Euro 2000, were clearly out of shape.

There was a further warning from Helsinki where Finland, who entertain England on October 11, beat Norway 3-1 in the Nordic Cup, with Barcelona's Jari Litmanen scoring two superb goals.

Litmanen struck in the 24th and 61st minutes with Shefki Kuqi scoring the other Finnish goal with an injury-time penalty. Torstein Helstad had equalised for Norway in the 54th.

Greece, another of England's qualifying rivals, drew 2-2 in Switzerland at St Gallen, the home side equalising late in the second half.

fields.headline: Leeds gamble on Matteo
fields.trailText: Leeds United will gamble £4.75m on Dominic Matteo's health today by concluding his transfer to Elland Road even though the Liverpool defender failed a routine medical examination last night.
fields.body:
Leeds United will gamble £4.75m on Dominic Matteo's health today by concluding his transfer to Elland Road even though the Liverpool defender failed a routine medical examination last night.

The tests revealed that Matteo will be out of action for up to two months with a knee injury but Leeds are prepared to carry on regardless and supply the 26-year-old with the treatment he needs.

While a player failing his medical is usually the catalyst for a transfer to collapse, the Leeds manager David O'Leary has been assured that Matteo's injury is not career-threatening and that, given time, he should make a full recovery.

Matteo had already agreed personal terms and the deal now hinges on whether the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale can come to an agreement with Liverpool about its structure.

It is usual for the buying club to make a down payment of roughly half the transfer fee but Ridsdale hopes to persuade Liverpool to accept a lower figure because the player will not be immediately available.

"We are prepared to conclude the transfer," said Ridsdale. "We are in discussions with Liverpool and hopefully we can reach a mutually acceptable financial arrangement that will allow the move to be completed."

webTitle: Review: Edinburgh: Cleveland Orchestra/ Christoph von Dohnanyi

fields.headline: Romantic grandeur
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Cleveland Orchestra/ Christoph von Dohnanyi
Usher Hall ****
fields.body:
Cleveland Orchestra/ Christoph von Dohnanyi
Usher Hall ****

The Cleveland Orchestra is one of the most technically polished in the world. With such virtuosity at his disposal, Christoph von Dohnanyi''s approach to Bruckner''s Fourth Symphony was surprisingly lean and clear-cut. Not that there was any lack of romantic grandeur in his perorations of Bruckner''s vast symphonic canvas, but Dohnanyi eschewed any hint of flabby self-indulgence in his choice of speeds and the crispness of his articulation.

Dohnanyi''s performance was full of dynamic contrast and infectious momentum. Far from basking in a warm, pastoral glow, he connected Bruckner to the teleology of Beethoven''s symphonies, and his approach to the slow movement was fascinatingly concentrated. But it was in his performance of the finale - a piece that can sound block-like and episodic - that Dohnanyi''s interpretation was most gripping.

In their accompaniment to Berg''s Violin Concerto, with soloist Frank Peter Zimmermann, Dohnanyi and the orchestra again revealed their feeling for large-scale structure and long-breathed musical line. Against this seamless orchestral backdrop, Zimmermann projected a performance of mercurial abandon and tightly wrought intensity. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Under an Irish spell
fields.trailText:
Danu
Borderline, London ****
fields.body:
Danu
Borderline, London ****

The best traditional Irish groups are in such demand abroad these days that your chances of sitting under the nose of some wild bodhran player of repute are fading fast. What a treat, then, to see the next big thing, Danu, average age 24, in the poky Borderline.

The Doorley brothers from Dublin - Eamon on bouzouki and Tom on sprightly flute - lead Danu's easy, session-rooted flow along with Jesse Smith, a fine if rigid fiddle player from Washington DC (not a drop of Irish blood in his veins), and punchy Waterford box player Brendan McCarthy. Despite jet lag and an arhythmic couple clapping madly in the front row, they built up great energy, urged on by bodhran player Donncadh Gough, his fringe flying up with the effort of beating. For one song he ditched his stick for a washing-up brush, and a set of uillean pipes lay at his feet amid beer bottles for when he doubled up as piper.

Not all Danu's tunes are traditional; Peggy's Nettles, for example, was written by guitarist Noel Ryan in memory of the morning his mother woke him from a deep sleep with a bunch of stinging nettles.

Best of all, freed of his piano accordion duties, Ciaran O Gealbhain from Irish-speaking Waterford unleashed a voice to lie down in the road for: rich, lilting, tender, lovelorn, playful. Even the bar staff heeded his warning to women in a spellbinding Fair and Tender Ladies: "Men are only after one thing," he explained, "your money." Or in the words of the song: "For they're like a star on a cloudy morning/First they'll appear and then they've gone."

Let's hope Danu don't go away just yet.

fields.headline: Freecom jumps 14% after chief resigns
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The chief executive of internet firm Freecom.net, Michael Williams, resigned abruptly yesterday and suffered the ignominy of watching the group's share price rise by more than 14%.
fields.body:
The chief executive of internet firm Freecom.net, Michael Williams, resigned abruptly yesterday and suffered the ignominy of watching the group's share price rise by more than 14%.

The shares gained 8p to 57.5p but are still way below last November's 130p offer price when the group joined the market and nowhere in sight of their March peak of 560p.

Mr Williams is leaving with immediate effect and will take a year's salary of £100,000.

The company maintained that Mr Williams departure had been amicable and said the business now needed a different kind of manager to bed down a string of acquisitions. A statement said his resignation "reflects the continuing realignment of the group".

In the past six months Freecom has made a series of takeovers largely reshaping the business from a one-stop-shop for small businesses wanting to get on the web to a provider of accounting software.

He had, however, come under criticism for some of the deals he structured particularly the handling of the Oneview.net acquisition. The deal ended in acrimony with the Oneview founder quitting soon after completion.

Mr Williams will be replaced by finance director Paul Coleman. Bodo Heiss, another Freecom director has also resigned with immediate effect.

webTitle: Notebook: A timely jolt for the City

fields.headline: A timely jolt for the City
fields.standfirst:
MPC massages rates expectations

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Bank of England's monetary policy committee is capable of springing a surprise on the City even when it behaves precisely as expected. Earlier this month, the committee left interest rates on hold.
fields.body:
The Bank of England's monetary policy committee is capable of springing a surprise on the City even when it behaves precisely as expected. Earlier this month, the committee left interest rates on hold.

The jolt for the market came yesterday when minutes of the meeting showed not only that rates were left on hold by the narrowest of margins, but also that some of those in favour of "no change" acknowledged that the call was close.

Interest rate hawks immediately interpreted the fine balance over the decision as a sign that rates have still to peak. Others seized on the latest earnings and employment data as evidence that events were moving in the direction that the MPC wanted and there was little reason for a change.

In fact the figures can be argued either way. The claimant count last month was the lowest for more than 20 years, the percentage of the workforce unemployed and claiming benefit the lowest since 1975. Yet the earnings numbers - those most likely to worry the MPC while the rest of us are celebrating the buoyancy of the jobs market - appear benign.

Back to the spoilsports, who point out that, while headline earnings numbers for June showed a fall, the so-called negative bonus effect meant the figures flattered, perhaps to deceive. Forget the new economy - if the unemployment rate continues to fall it will feed through into higher earnings which in turn will stoke up consumer spending which is what really worries the MPC.

The problem for the committee is that it has little or no control over two of the key determinents of inflation - the level of sterling and the price of oil. The latter is bobbing around a 10-year high and, according to some analysts, could spike higher. Nor will the foreign exchange market's view of the appropriate value of the pound necessarily correspond with MPC inflation forecasts.

The MPC may not be too unhappy to have caught the City on the hop. If it can massage expectations towards the possibility of a rise in the repo rate to 6.25% or even 6.5% that may have a helpful knock-on effect on market rates. It would also mean that, if a rise were deemed necessary, it may have less impact on the politically sensitive sterling/euro exchange rate than if it came as a bolt from the blue.

Mutual benefits
One factor which may have an impact on the consumer spending that haunts the MPC is the latest demutualisation windfalls. Policyholders with Scottish Widows are due to receive their share of the £5.8bn windfall from the Lloyds TSB takeover. This could make official spending numbers tricky to read.

The payout, a reminder of the short term gains of demutualisation, comes at an awkward time for another Scottish institution, Standard Life. Shortly after fending off one attempt to push through demutualisation it is coming under fresh pressure to turn itself into a plc and hand out large sums of money to policyholders.

It appears there is little that Standard Life can do to prevent itself being confronted by a succession of demutualisa tion efforts until, either through weariness or boredom, policyholders opt for the cash.

Introducing a rule that Standard Life could not be asked to consider demutualisation for (say) two or three years after the failure of a previous proposal could easily be overturned.

Raising the numbers of members needed to back a demutualisation proposal might look a better bet but, in these days of the internet, it is hard to pick a number high enough to present an effective hurdle.

Such a defence would, in any case, be wrong. Policyholders have voted, once, against demutualisation.

That decision cannot be set in stone for ever. Provision must be made either for changes in circumstances or simply for a change of mind on the part of the policyholders. But there should be a decent interval in between.

Irish dilemma
If the MPC is ever inclined to feel sorry for the difficulties it faces in making policy, members need do no more than look across to Ireland. There the economy is roaring ahead but inflation this week hit a 15-year high. At 6.2% it is more than double the euro-zone average. The government has already frozen the price of booze and now the unions would like it to do the same with petrol duty and VAT. The International Monetary Fund thinks it would do better to raise taxes. Hardly the best background for negotiating a national wage pact.

The problem for Dublin's economic policymakers is that there is little they can do. Cutting indirect taxes would have a one-off effect but would give consumers extra spending power. An IMF style tightening is reckoned to have limited impact. At least the MPC gets to set interest rates.

webTitle: Setback for Starbucks as online venture fails

fields.headline: Setback for Starbucks as online venture fails
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Starbucks, the coffee retailer, yesterday became the latest victim of the internet downturn when it was forced to write off a $20.6m (£14.2m) investment in a failed online venture.
fields.body:
Starbucks, the coffee retailer, yesterday became the latest victim of the internet downturn when it was forced to write off a $20.6m (£14.2m) investment in a failed online venture.

Shares in the Seattle-based company were suspended in New York after the company revealed the extent of its involvement in Living.com, the online furniture retailer which filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this week.

The collapse of Living.com may reduce Starbuck's fourth quarter earnings by seven cents a share. Excluding the charge the company is expecting to make 22 cents a share for the quarter.

Starbucks said that it decided to write off 100% of its investment in the online retailer after Living.com announced that it would lay off 275 employees and liquidate its assets.

In a statement released yesterday, Starbucks said: "In recent months, companies in the internet and e-commerce industries have experienced difficulties, including difficulties in raising proceeds to fund expansion or to continue operations."

The company added that it still had some $43m invested in public and private internet and e-commerce companies. The statement offered a further note of warning to investors by adding that "Starbucks may conclude in the future that some or all of these investments warrant similar non-cash write-downs".

Shares in the company were expected to fall once the Nasdaq market reopened late yesterday. Wall Street analysts have previously criticised Starbucks' online plans as too ambitious. Their criticism, combined with that of some investors, prompted the management to scale back their plans over a year ago.

The company, which operates more than 3,300 Starbucks coffee shops in the US, Britain, Asia and the Middle East, was not available for comment yesterday. Its statement added that the write-down would not hurt earnings expectations for next year of between 90 and 92 cents.

Living.com was the second major casualty of the e-commerce sector in the past week, following the collapse of Value America's website.

Its collapse could also bring further pressure on Amazon.com, the online retailer which had a minority stake in the company and which has suffered from a crisis in investor confidence since April. Seven months ago, Living.com paid Amazon $145m as part of a five-year agreement to appear as a link on the larger company's home page. Amazon also paid an unspecified amount for its stake.

The loss of Living.com has stripped Amazon of its ability to offer online sales of furniture, though the company said it would continue to expand and find another partner in the near future.

Shares in Amazon, which are trading at about one-third of their all-time highs, remained largely unaffected by the travails of Living.com yesterday.

fields.headline: Sale QXL could do without
fields.standfirst:
Market forces Neil Hume
Net news
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Different day, same story: more bad news for internet auction house Qxl.com. Not only did a trust connected with its non-executive chairman sell more shares, but the analyst who stunned the brokerage community by setting a £44 target price made an embarrassing climbdown.
fields.body:
Different day, same story: more bad news for internet auction house Qxl.com. Not only did a trust connected with its non-executive chairman sell more shares, but the analyst who stunned the brokerage community by setting a £44 target price made an embarrassing climbdown.

First, the share sales. Yesterday it emerged that New Jersey based Fenwick Trust, of which QXL's non-executive chairman Jonathan Bulkeley is a beneficiary but has no control, sold 500,000 QXL shares at 55p each on Tuesday. Although Fenwick claims the disposals were made to cover the administrative expenses of the trust, dealers were more sceptical, pointing out that Fenwick made a similar move earlier this month.

On August 7, Fenwick also said it had sold 325,000 QXL shares between July 19 and August 2 to cover its administrative expenses.

Whatever the reason for the sales, dealers are starting to get twitchy. Not only are the sales undermining what little confidence remains in QXL, but Fenwick still holds 18.2m shares. Given that it has been selling from 78p downwards, there can be no guarantee that further sales will not follow. QXL shares, which were 1.5p better at 59.5p last night, have already fallen from 778p in the past 10 months.

Meanwhile, SG Cowen analyst Thomas Bock, who drove QXL's share price up six-fold in one day when he first came out with the eye-catching target price back in April, appeared to throw in the towel on QXL.

In a research note, Mr Bock cut his rating on QXL to "hold" from "strong buy" citing recent developments that have created concerns regarding the company's growth strategy, its acquisition of German rival Ricardo.de, and its financial position.

On this last point, Mr Bock, who made no mention of a new target price in the note, said QXL might only be able to finance its operations for another four to five quarters before it needs to raise fresh capital.

Elsewhere, leading shares continued their winning run. The FTSE 100 index closed up 56.5 points at 6,532 - its highest close since June 14 - on a turnover of 1.46bn.

Most of the support came from oil heavyweights BP , up 13p to 615p, Shell , 6.5p stronger at 573. Both were boosted by the strong crude price.

The banking sector also chipped in with Barclays rising 63p to £16.75, while Alliance & Leicester gaining 18p to 550p.

Dealers remain convinced that some form of corporate activity is on the cards at business services group Hays . According to the story making the rounds yesterday, Hays is working to unlock hidden value via a demerger of its recruitment arm. The shares closed up 3.25p at 403.25p, as 7.1m shares changed hands.

On the downside, Rolls Royce , off 10.25p to 228.75p, was the worst blue-chip performer, unsettled by a negative research note from UBS Warburg. In a preview of interim results due on August 24, UBS said that it was expecting a complex set of figures that are likely to contain some and hidden and unpleasant surprises.

British Airways lost 12.75p to 368.75p, hit hard by the withdrawal of Concorde from service and the buoyant oil price.

Lower down the corporate scale, Safeway fell 18.25p to 282p, as CSFB set about placing 40m shares with clients at 282p, a significant discount to Tuesday's closing price.

Whitbread was also out of favour, sliding 20p to 508p, unsettled by the gloomy outlook for the pub market. The latest data from market research firm AGB Taylor Sofres indicates that all is not well in the industry, with the growth in pub bar snacks all but evaporating.

Great Portland Estates once again moved higher (up 4p to 237.5p) on a reasonable volume. Market gossips believe the property group, which stands at a significant discount to net asset value, is vulnerable to a takeover.
fields.bodyText: Different day, same story: more bad news for internet auction house Qxl.com. Not only did a trust connected with its non-executive chairman sell more shares, but the analyst who stunned the brokerage community by setting a £44 target price made an embarrassing climbdown. First, the share sales. Yesterday it emerged that New Jersey based Fenwick Trust, of which QXL's non-executive chairman Jonathan Bulkeley is a beneficiary but has no control, sold 500,000 QXL shares at 55p each on Tuesday. Although Fenwick claims the disposals were made to cover the administrative expenses of the trust, dealers were more sceptical, pointing out that Fenwick made a similar move earlier this month. On August 7, Fenwick also said it had sold 325,000 QXL shares between July 19 and August 2 to cover its administrative expenses. Whatever the reason for the sales, dealers are starting to get twitchy. Not only are the sales undermining what little confidence remains in QXL, but Fenwick still holds 18.2m shares. Given that it has been selling from 78p downwards, there can be no guarantee that further sales will not follow. Meanwhile, SG Cowen analyst Thomas Bock, who drove QXL's share price up six-fold in one day when he first came out with the eye-catching target price back in April, appeared to throw in the towel on QXL. fields.headline: Woven with emotion
fields.trailText:
Keller Quartet
Royal Albert Hall, London ****
fields.body:
Keller Quartet
Royal Albert Hall, London ****

Founded in Budapest in 1986, the Keller Quartet has gone on to achieve something like cult status as a result of their adventurous programmes and their willingness to tackle both the mainstream and contemporary repertoires. Their late night Prom formed a tribute to Bach, extracts from whose Art of Fugue were interwoven - mesmerically if not always seamlessly - with music by Gyorgy Kurtag, some inspired by the quartet's own playing.

The end result may best be described as a tapestry woven of fragments. The Art of Fugue itself is the great, incomplete work of Bach's final years, its climactic section breaking off in mid-flow, its instrumentation never designated (which means that the possibilities in performance are infinite). Kurtag's work consists of myriad miniatures in which every note and texture speaks volumes. Bach is one of Kurtag's constant references. His 12 Microludes each take successive notes of the chromatic scale as a starting point, much as Bach exploits successive keys in The Well-Tempered Clavier. The Officium Breve is consciously modelled on The Art of Fugue, the last of its 15 sections shockingly interrupted and tailing off into silence.

The concert itself blends austerity with emotion. The Kellers' approach to Bach is severe, frequently exploiting a vibrato-less tone so that the lines of the fugues emerge with blinding clarity. Kurtag's deeply nuanced music fills the breaks with a mixture of intense feeling and stringent technical demands that push the quartet almost to the limits of their expressive capabilities. The Bach's final fugue breaks off at the height of its glory to be succeeded by Kurtag's Ligature, written for the Keller Quartet's two violinists. It is strange, unearthly music. Whispering harmonies attempt to fill the void left by Bach's passing, until they, too, seem to follow him into a final silence.

fields.headline: For your eyes only
fields.trailText: 17 August: My boss wants me to spy on my colleague so he can sack her. Can he make me do this because I certainly not happy about it.
fields.body:
The problem

My firm has been bought out by another company and a lot of people are losing their jobs. My boss is asking me to look at what a colleague does on her PC after hours so that they can get rid of her. I don't feel comfortable with this as we all have a good working relationship in the office - can my boss require us to do this sort of thing?

The solution

In theory, probably not, unless it is in your job description. However, many employers get around the problem of making unusual requests by having a clause to the effect of "other duties as deemed necessary or reasonable by your line manager" somewhere in the contract. And, this could be seen as necessary since your boss obviously suspects your colleague of inappropriate behaviour. He is asking for your help to catch your colleague misusing her work equipment so that there is something to hang her on. What your boss is asking of you is certainly not illegal.

The issue is whether, if you refused, you could be sacked (or constructively dismissed) - and whether, if you were sacked, you would have a claim for unfair dismissal. There is no definitive answer to this but I suggest you speak to your local ACAS public enquiry point (number in the phone book), union or even Citizen's Advice with all the details.

Rather than refuse point blank to do this, however, I would recommend more conciliatory action. Arrange a meeting with your boss and explain how uncomfortable this makes you feel. But, at the same time, you will need to suggest some alternative course of action rather than just refusing to play ball. Perhaps you would not feel so bad if everyone's computers were monitored in this way, or maybe your boss herself can do it.

At the end of the day, if you do spy and your colleague is fired, it is up to them to consider whether they feel the dismissal is unfair and try to do something about it.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Tear-inducing wit
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Adam Hills
Gilded Balloon Peppermint Lounge ****
fields.body:
Adam Hills
Gilded Balloon Peppermint Lounge ****

Adam Hills isn't the most inventive comedian in history, but for tear-inducing wit he's hard to beat. A genial Aussie with a shirt so loud he needs no amplification, he ingratiates himself with the crowd by ridiculing us individually. A geneticist studying plants that "have sex with each other" is lampooned as "a pervert". I escape with the relatively mild "You sir, in the pervy jacket." Preamble over, Hills delivers stand-up so effortlessly brilliant you wonder why some other comedians even get out of bed.

Hills creates a boy band on stage (almost wrecking the venue in a hail of flying chairs), obtains material from an Innovations catalogue ("a wheelchair that's so light you can pick it up and carry it away") and, in an inspired moment, uses a map of Cornwall to illustrate the difficulties TV censors face when deciding what constitutes an erect penis. He also makes pointed observations on sectarianism and clause 28, and if there's a fault it's that he doesn't fully explore this to give things a greater edge. As it is, he's too hung up on japes such as grabbing my notebook, reading it aloud ("'An hour feels like 20 minutes'? - yes!") and using crowd suggestions to write his own review. Cheeky, but it's difficult to argue with "a comic genius, see him before he loses his teeth".

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-226 2151.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Fitfully entertaining
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Beside Picasso
Rocket@Theatre Arts Centre ***
fields.body:
Beside Picasso
Rocket@Theatre Arts Centre ***

Two sharp performances carry Brian McAvera's fitfully entertaining play, which sees Picasso's longtime secretary and biographer, Sabartes, getting after-death revenge upon his former employer. Radio 4 is where this play should really find a home.

Essentially this is Huis Clos with bio-drama, and while the wordy script is never less than intelligent, its musings on the relationship of genius to bad behaviour and Picasso's appalling treatment of women are hardly revelatory.

As Sabartes, Mick Jasper subtly suggests a worm that after years of humiliation and growing resentment finally turns and sees an opportunity to settle old scores. Iain Armstrong conveys all the charisma and ego of the painter who knew he was great and let everyone know it. These two are fantastic.

But in the end, the play is not sufficiently illuminating to make you disagree with Picasso's assertion: "Biography is irrelevant. I am what I paint."

Till August 26. Box office: 0131-667 6666.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Wafer thin majority kept rates on hold

fields.headline: Wafer thin majority kept rates on hold
fields.standfirst:
Bank of England minutes reveal how doves held sway in closest vote for more than a year
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Homeowners and businesses were spared a further rise in interest rates this month only by a wafer thin majority on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Homeowners and businesses were spared a further rise in interest rates this month only by a wafer thin majority on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, it was revealed yesterday.

Minutes of the MPC's meeting on 2 and 3 August showed the closest vote for over a year, with four of the nine members voting in favour of a tightening of policy and five against.

Breaking ranks with the governor for only the second time since joining the committee in September 1997, deputy governor David Clementi sided with the hawks, comprising Mervyn King, John Vickers and Stephen Nickell.

With growth accelerating in the second quarter, the hawks argued for an immediate quarter point increase in the Bank's base rate to restrain consumer spending and prevent a breach of the government's 2.5% inflation target.

But the governor, Sir Eddie George, the bank's markets expert, Ian Plenderleith, and new recruit Christopher Allsopp stayed with the doves - DeAnne Julius and Sushil Wadhwani - who said that overall monetary conditions were already restrictive and that a further rate rise risked sending sterling higher on the foreign exchanges.

The 5-4 majority in favour of leaving the base rate unchanged at 6% was the narrowest since May 99, when the committee was split down the middle about the wisdom of a rate cut and again opted to maintain the status quo.

Interest rate futures rose after the release of the minutes, implying that investors increasingly expect the cost of borrowing to rise again before the end of year.

The pound also received a boost but later fell against both the dollar and the euro on the back of benign US inflation figures.

City analysts said the timing of any British interest rate rises remained uncertain. Figures published yesterday showed an unexpectedly sharp deceleration in earnings growth to 4.1% from 4.6%, suggesting that there was little immediate danger of a pick-up in wage inflation.

However, a further 22,700 fall in unemployment in July, to a total of 1,069,800, indicated that labour market was still tightening and that a shortage of workers could eventually prompt wage growth to recover.

Tumbling unemployment was also likely to underpin consumer confidence.

Philip Shaw, an analyst at Investec bank, said: "Overall this week's inflation data, at least at the retail level, and the further deceleration of earnings weakens the hawks' case slightly. However, it remains clear that the committee feels private sector demand must slow and we remain unconvinced by the latest evidence that this is happening to a sufficient degree."

He added that strong retail sales figures today would strenghten the odds on a move next month.

Geoff Dicks, of the Royal Bank of Scotland, said that sterling's value on the foreign exchanges was the key to future policy moves. "Unless we get some major surprises in the domestic data, we still need a stronger euro to get the last rate hike," he said.

webTitle: Review: Edinburgh: Film: Water Drops On Burning Rocks

fields.headline: Provocative promise
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Water Drops On Burning Rocks
Filmhouse ***
fields.body:
Water Drops On Burning Rocks
Filmhouse ***

It looked for a while as if young French director François Ozon would never live up to the provocative promise of his early shorts. His debut feature, the John Waters tribute Sitcom, was strictly subversion-by-numbers, and his follow-up, Criminal Lovers, was a directionless essay in fairy-tale nightmare.

But Ozon certainly doesn't waste time licking his wounds. Already on his third feature, he has taken a new tack and adapted Water Drops On Burning Rocks, a stage play that Rainer Werner Fassbinder wrote at the age of 19.

Ozon wisely heightens rather than hides the film's theatrical origins. The drama, set in the apartment of middle-aged bisexual roué Leopold, is played out on a series of tightly-framed sets, decorated in a glumly kitsch style that may well be an accurate evocation of whatever passed as chic in 70s bourgeois Bavaria. The claustrophobic mood is unmistakably close to Fassbinder, but has an edge of parody that is strictly Ozon's, as in the scene where the four characters burst into a ludicrous but dapper disco routine.

Ozon's casting makes the film more skittishly sexy than Fassbinder would have done: Malik Zidi and Ludivine Seigner make a doe-eyed ingenue couple, and Anna Thomson is a disturbingly fragile faded vamp. The real discovery, however, is Bernard Giraudeau, for many years a mainstream tough guy lead, now weathered enough to play Leopold as a suavely predatory lounge lizard in tweeds and polo-neck.

This acidic essay on sexual manipulation bodes well for Ozon's new direction, and if he continues to follow Fassbinder's industrious example, it won't be long before we see where that leads.

At the Filmhouse (0131-228 2688) tonight.

webTitle: Review: Edinburgh:  A Man of Substance in a World of Filth

fields.headline: More penises
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
A Man of Substance in a World of Filth
Gilded Balloon Backstage 2 ***
fields.body:
A Man of Substance in a World of Filth
Gilded Balloon Backstage 2 ***

Warning: this is yet another fringe show that revels in ostentatious display of the human penis. Andrew Clover plays Maurice Clarke, a bogus literature student who believes himself to be the reincarnation of Jonathan Swift.

This fanciful premise fires the madman/exhibitionist off at all manner of tangents, including his difficult relationship with his family, a Swift-customised porn mag and some dubious audience participation. One woman is persuaded to don a silly hat and glasses and imagine she's being approached by a red shark, while many of her peers are rudely propositioned. This show is funny and provocative, but there's something faintly traumatising about a man who delights in stripping to opaque women's tights (laddered in a very dangerous place). The now agitated Clover can't stop there, and following a bizarre final ramble ("We come naked in the world"), he strips starkers and prances about in front of the stunned but cheering audience.

Tch. The lengths (or lack of them) some people will go to get a laugh.

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-226 2151.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Drama and dance
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Don Juan Royal Lyceum *****
fields.body:
Don Juan Royal Lyceum *****

Drama and dance often make uneasy bedfellows. But Mats Ek's production of Don Juan, brought to Edinburgh by Stockholm's Royal Dramatic Theatre, choreographs a classic text with rare brilliance: Ek uses the skills he acquired with the Cullberg Ballet Company to give Molière's study of an atheistic seducer a prodigious, and highly erotic, physical life.

Ek highlights the theatricality of the play throughout. Mikael Persbrandt's imposing Don Juan is not just an arithmetic bed-hopper but a fetishistic role-player: he dons a black wig when in seductive mode and, in flight, becomes a masked, sombrero-clad Zorro. Maria Geber's design deploys romantic landscape panels that ironically evoke a vanished pictorialism. And, at the climax, the hero is hoisted up to the top of a reversed flat, as if impaled by his own love of theatricality.

But what makes Ek's production startlingly different from other Don Juans is its transformation of actors into dancers. Persbrandt and Nina Togner Fex's Dona Elvira at one point do a sexually charged pas de deux. Niklas Ek's ageing Sganarelle is not just the voice of virtue but a formidable athlete who slides horizontally across a table like a fast-moving parcel. And the Don's female victims are given a head-inclined, lateral style of movement as if their natural equilibrium had been destroyed by the hero's assaults.

The miracle of Ek's production is that it gives the play a vividly choreographed energy without losing its philosophical arguments. Persbrandt's impressive Don Juan becomes a narcissistic nihilist who tries on any role he fancies: a god-defying seducer, a masked avenger, even a fashionable social hypocrite. But Ek emphasises the character's sheer nastiness in the scene where he offers a beggar money in payment for blasphemy and then kicks the purse just out of his reach; and when Sganarelle lectures his master on the fantastic nature of mankind, the hero slumps in front of a television set.

Ek uses any number of devices to highlight his theme that Don Juan is really a man on the run terrified of any lasting relationship. Best of all, he casts the actress who plays Dona Elvira as the indigent beggar, a male creditor and even as Elvira's brother to emphasise the point that the supposed libertine is in reality a haunted, hunted man. You could object that Ek sometimes ignores the letter of Molière's text: the peasant girl, Charlotte, whom Don Juan pursues, here becomes a provocative, bum-wiggling cleaner. But Ek captures the spirit of the play superbly, in particular its portrait of the spiritual emptiness of self-enraptured egotism.

Above all, Ek's production combines physical exhilaration with serious fun. There's a lovely moment when Sganarelle, as part of Molière's sidewipe at the medical profession, turns himelf into a fraudulent shrink analysing his genuinely disturbed master. A great play has been rethought and turned into an ironic commentary on our modern belief in passionless hedonism and fluctuating identity. Although its stay is tragically brief, it is exactly the kind of life-enhancing event for which one goes to an international festival.

Ends tonight. Box office: 0131-473-2000. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible
fields.bodyText: Don Juan Royal Lyceum ***** Drama and dance often make uneasy bedfellows. But Mats Ek's production of Don Juan, brought to Edinburgh by Stockholm's Royal Dramatic Theatre, choreographs a classic text with rare brilliance: Ek uses the skills he acquired with the Cullberg Ballet Company to give Molière's study of an atheistic seducer a prodigious, and highly erotic, physical life. Ek highlights the theatricality of the play throughout. Mikael Persbrandt's imposing Don Juan is not just an arithmetic bed-hopper but a fetishistic role-player: he dons a black wig when in seductive mode and, in flight, becomes a masked, sombrero-clad Zorro. Maria Geber's design deploys romantic landscape panels that ironically evoke a vanished pictorialism. And, at the climax, the hero is hoisted up to the top of a reversed flat, as if impaled by his own love of theatricality. But what makes Ek's production startlingly different from other Don Juans is its transformation of actors into dancers. Persbrandt and Nina Togner Fex's Dona Elvira at one point do a sexually charged pas de deux. Niklas Ek's ageing Sganarelle is not just the voice of virtue but a formidable athlete who slides horizontally across a table like a fast-moving parcel. And the Don's female victims are given a head-inclined, lateral style of movement as if their natural equilibrium had been destroyed by the hero's assaults. The miracle of Ek's production is that it gives the play a vividly choreographed energy without losing its philosophical arguments. Persbrandt's impressive Don Juan becomes a narcissistic nihilist who tries on any role he fancies: a god-defying seducer, a masked avenger, even a fashionable social hypocrite. But Ek emphasises the character's sheer nastiness in the scene where he offers a beggar money in payment for blasphemy and then kicks the purse just out of his reach; and when Sganarelle lectures his master on the fantastic nature of mankind, the hero slumps in front of a television set. Ek uses any number of devices to highlight his theme that Don Juan is really a man on the run terrified of any lasting relationship. Best of all, he casts the actress who plays Dona Elvira as the indigent beggar, a male creditor and even as Elvira's brother to emphasise the point that the supposed libertine is in reality a haunted, hunted man. You could object that Ek sometimes ignores the letter of Molière's text: the peasant girl, Charlotte, whom Don Juan pursues, here becomes a provocative, bum-wiggling cleaner. But Ek captures the spirit of the play superbly, in particular its portrait of the spiritual emptiness of self-enraptured egotism. Above all, Ek's production combines physical exhilaration with serious fun. There's a lovely moment when Sganarelle, as part of Molière's sidewipe at the medical profession, turns himelf into a fraudulent shrink analysing his genuinely disturbed master. A great play has been rethought and turned into an ironic commentary on our modern belief in passionless hedonism and fluctuating identity. Although its stay is tragically brief, it is exactly the kind of life-enhancing event for which one goes to an international festival. Ends tonight. fields.headline: Beginning of the end
fields.trailText:
Ax/BBC Symphony Orchestra/Davis
Royal Albert Hall, London ***
fields.body:
Ax/BBC Symphony Orchestra/Davis
Royal Albert Hall, London ***

Andrew Davis takes his leave of the BBC Symphony Orchestra as chief conductor at the end of this year's Proms. In his penultimate appearance on Tuesday he conducted Mahler's Ninth Symphony, prefaced with Mozart's Piano Concerto E Flat, K482, with Emanuel Ax as soloist.

There were many things to admire about Davis's approach to the Ninth, especially his treatment of the inner pair of movements - the insistence of the scherzo, the abandon of the Rondo-Burlesque - in which the solo playing of the BBC SO had real bite. The focus that Davis found for both character pieces gave a direction to the symphony which the first movement had somehow lacked: the elements had all been placed precisely, but they did not plumb the emotional recesses that the vast canvas sets out to explore.

By taking the tempo markings at face value he made the music sound hurried; Mahler's Ninth Symphony should be allowed to set its own pace - something that its greatest interpreters, Karajan, Abbado, have understood perfectly - otherwise the results can be hugely disappointing. By the finale Davis and the orchestra had got the measure of things; though the BBC strings aren't the greatest at laying down plush carpets of sonority, Davis made the structure and its rapt acceptance genuinely convincing.

The Mozart concerto, too, contained many things to admire; Ax is a delightfully expressive pianist. But though the orchestra was slimmed down, the accompaniments could have been even lighter. It is difficult, in this cavernous space, to generate the intimacy that some of the dialogues between the wind and the piano suggest, but Ax's filigree lines asked for something more subtle in response.

fields.headline: Stretched to the limit
fields.trailText:
Ernesto Neto
Dundee Contemporary Arts ****
fields.body:
Ernesto Neto
Dundee Contemporary Arts ****

Brazilian Ernesto Neto's playful sculptures, which are made out of a material which resembles stretched chewing gum and opaque white tights, are both disgusting and endearing. Pods, filled with sand, hang from Nave Nove, a giant mutant object through which you can (and must) climb. The sculptures resemble bags of dung, or particularly rustic cheeses wrapped in mesh; they hark back to a low-tech game (tennis ball in one leg of some tights, swung from side to side against a wall), and forward to futuristic visions. Climbing through Nave Nove - and don't imagine you can do this with any modicum of dignity - it seems as though you have entered, for a moment, a high-denier world.

But Neto is not just a touchy-feely artist. A small room has a selection of stretchy, gloopy pods, made murky with coloured spotlights and filled with cloves. Another work uses turmeric to the same eye-watering effect - the spice hits the back of your throat, as though you are licking gauze.

The gallery leaflet refers to the way in which Neto's work offers "unusual experiences of our surroundings", and that's no understatement. My notes included the words "scrotal sac" and "squid". In the smaller of the main galleries, one big, flaccid item takes up nearly all the floor space, like a police outline of a giant's body. The thinnest white gauze holds together an infinitesimal number of polystyrene balls. This is Neto's take on the make-up of a red blood cell: full of tiny beads, he says, just "like a bus full of people". This is nothing like a bus, nothing like a blood cell, but a gloriously over-the-top gesture - ironically, anything but tight.

Until September 10. Details: 01382 432000.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.standfirst: County Championship Division One points table
fields.trailText: Surrey will be aiming to pull clear of Yorkshire in the race for the County Championship title when they take on lowly Derbyshire at the Oval today.
fields.body:
Surrey will be aiming to pull clear of Yorkshire in the race for the County Championship title when they take on lowly Derbyshire at the Oval today.

But Surrey will be wary of the favourites for relegation from Division One, since they are one of only two sides to beat them in the championship this year.

Surrey's only change sees Ben Hollioake dropped for Gary Butcher, and Derbyshire recall Lian Wharton and the 17-year-old Zubair Khan to their 12-man squad.

Yorkshire's captain David Byas is injured but is hoping his players keep up the pressure with a win against Leicestershire at Grace Road.

"This is a massive game," he said. "It's basically a two-horse race now, although Lancashire could feature if ourselves and Surrey slip up."

Leicestershire's cricket manager Jack Birkenshaw has a full squad to choose from with Jon Dakin, Phil DeFreitas and Anil Kumble all returning.

Durham are without their young guns for their crucial match with Somerset, Nicky Peng and Graeme Bridge having been lured away by the England Under-19s. Michael Gough, Jimmy Daley and Steve Harmison all return.

Somerset, without England players Andy Caddick and Marcus Trescothick, have Peter Trego on duty with the England Under-19s and Piran Holloway is also ruled out. Michael Burns and Adrian Pierson come into the side.

At the top of the Second Division Northamptonshire, with four wins in five games, play Sussex for the second time in a week. Both sides are unchanged from the match which Sussex lost by an innings.

Essex continue their quest for promotion at home to Gloucestershire with Ronnie Irani's side hoping to reproduce the form that saw them trounce Worcestershire by 10 wickets in their last outing. Graham Napier and Tim Mason come into the squad.

Gloucestershire's match against Middlesex at Bristol has been brought forward to next Monday to allow more preparation time for the NatWest Trophy final the following Saturday against Warwickshire, who have already had their match at Worcester rescheduled to start on the same day.

England Under-19s bowled out Sri Lanka for 211 at Trent Bridge thanks to a superb spell from Surrey's Tim Murtagh, who took four for 29 from 15 overs. England closed on five for one from the 10 balls they faced.

webTitle: Aston Villa in need of secure foundation

fields.headline: Feel-good factor depends on Ginola
fields.standfirst: A summer of discontent leaves John Gregory's future in doubt
fields.trailText: A summer of discontent leaves John Gregory's future in doubt. Daniel Taylor reports.
fields.body:
After the summer John Gregory has had, he could probably do with a holiday already instead of the short trip to Leicester City on Saturday. But if Aston Villa's manager needs a break, he should think again. The way things are going, his hotel would be infested with cockroaches, the resort would be packed with Birmingham City fans and Stan Collymore would be booked into the next room.

Villa, even by their standards, have surpassed themselves in recent months. The smallest "big club" in Europe has seen more backbiting and squabbling than a sixth-form common room. And, as if that has not been bad enough, they have had their fingers burnt in the Intertoto Cup. Now that is embarrassing.

"I want to be optimistic, I really do," insists Dave Woodhall, editor of the Heroes and Villains fanzine. "But, bloody hell, I don't know what's going to happen this season. There is no long-term strategy, the players are arguing with the manager and the chairman [Doug Ellis] seems to have the business mentality of a market trader."

If Villa found themselves at a crossroads after their wretched FA Cup final defeat against Chelsea, they have clearly taken a wrong turn or two since.

If it has not been Paul Merson throwing a wobbly, it has been Julian Joachim. If it has not been Ugo Ehiogu wanting out, it has been Gareth Southgate. Benito Carbone has defected from Brum to Bradford without so much as a backward glance. And Gregory's talent for making enemies remains unsurpassed.

Ehiogu and Southgate now say they will honour their contracts but that is more to do with neither player finding a club big enough to satisfy his ego rather than them overcoming their dissatisfaction with life at Villa Park.

As Villa are discovering, being the biggest club in the midlands does not guarantee acceptance as a proper "big club". In Premiership terms they belong very much in the category B list and, while they may strenuously deny it, the inferiority complex is threatening to suffocate them.

When Southgate said at the start of the summer that he wanted to move on to bigger and better things, it cut to the quick - not just because the captain was effectively accusing his employers of lacking ambition but because he was citing something the supporters were already thinking.

Around 20,000 season tickets were sold last year, but only 14,500 have been taken this summer, fewer than Charlton Athletic, Derby County or Ipswich Town.

Given that Villa have one of the biggest catchment areas in the country, those figures should alarm everyone associated with the club, not least their accountants. The club made a loss of £4.8m in the last financial year compared with a profit of £20.2m in 1998-99.

The vultures are hovering. Gregory is the 6-4 second favourite to become the first Premiership manager to be sacked - only Chris Hutchings of Bradford City is ahead of him at 8-11 - and Ellis's wish list could be enough on its own to have the manager privately scrutinising the situations vacant columns.

Ellis says he wants to be in the Champions League next season and that any downbeat view of Villa "is a slur on our integrity, our hard work and our ambition to suggest we will settle for second best". He adds that "I will not acknowledge that my dream has gone and nor will the manager."

It may not happen publicly but, after all the acrimony, the chances of Gregory pulling off a top-three finish are roughly the same as Roy Keane being invited to lunch at Chelsea.

Gregory desperately needs David Ginola to play somewhere near his best. But he did not arrive from Spurs with a guarantee attached. And, do not forget, George Graham is far from the only manager to have told the shampooed Frenchman to "wash and go".

"Ginola has looked the part," says Gregory. Yet the questions still come thick and fast. Ginola may have provided some hope for the disillusioned droves but Villa surely needed a couple of other signings to go with the Turkey defender Alpay Ozalan and the Belgium forward Luc Nilis.

Gregory has heard it all before. "Whenever we don't sign anyone it's always seen as a lack of ambition," he sighs. "If it's one of the top four, it's never described as that. All three new signings will prove their worth, make no mistake about that."

Life is never uneventful at Villa Park; it is just that this season things seems to have started earlier than normal. "This is not a club at war," insists the vice-chairman Mark Ansell. But it is certainly giving that impression.

"It's not been ideal," adds Gregory, submitting an early contender for understatement of the season. "You just have to get on with it. Believe it or not, I'm looking forward to the season."

webTitle: Fourth Test: Yorkshire launch tug of war for Gough

fields.headline: Yorkshire launch tug of war for Gough
fields.standfirst: Counties claim contracts leave them short-changed
fields.trailText: David Hopps reports from Headingley as the counties claim central contracts leave them short-changed.
fields.body:
While Darren Gough is being roared through the fourth Cornhill Test by a devoted Leeds crowd, with the series against West Indies at a critical stage, an equally passionate encounter will be fought out behind the scenes as England and Yorkshire battle for the services of the most coveted bowler in the land.

At issue is the controversial decision by England's coach Duncan Fletcher to withdraw Gough, and other selected Test players, from the climax to the County Championship season on the grounds that they need rest and recuperation before the start of an arduous winter programme.

Yorkshire will privately warn Fletcher that the decision, which was sprung on the first-class counties last month without discussion, will have disastrous consequences for the county game, as its flagging reputation can only be demeaned further.

They expect to enlist support from Surrey and Lancashire, their major title rivals, in arguing that any more damage to the status of the County Championship will automatically undermine Fletcher's attempts to raise standards at international level.

Gough is a free spirit, as bullish and opinionated as any Yorkshire fast bowler, but he knows when to keep his own counsel. "I'm saying nowt," he said yesterday. He is conscious that the tug-of-war for his services could not come at a more uncomfortable time. The Western Terrace is likely to have a view on the matter.

Gough would love to lead Yorkshire to their first championship since 1968 and knows how much damage could be done to his folklore image if he appears reluctant. But he also has a niggle or two and is desperate to be fit and fresh enough this winter to turn round England's appalling run of failures overseas.

Yorkshire supported the introduction of central contracts, which gives England's management control over their leading players, only with considerable soul searching. Craig White and Michael Vaughan are also centrally contracted and Matthew Hoggard, too, is in the England squad for Headingley.

Yorkshire's view is unrepentant: "The counties agreed that players might have to be rested between Tests but no one suggested that they might need a holiday at the end of the season. How can supporters take the climax to the county season seriously if the best players are missing? This undermines all our attempts to raise standards."

The view from another northern Test-ground county was equally abrupt. "Somehow international cricketers must play more often in the county game, otherwise there is absolutely no point anybody watching it."

Central contracting of England players, although still on trial, has been widely accepted in principle but the counties will still voice their displeasure over certain aspects of the system at the next meeting of the First-Class Forum.

Several Test-match counties - although Yorkshire are not among them - privately contend that a reduction in the number of first-class counties is the only solution to an otherwise intractable country versus county dispute. As the ECB is criticised by the metropolitan counties for withdrawing their best players, so it is also regarded with deep suspicion by shire counties fearing for their survival.

Don Trangmar, the Sussex chairman who oversaw the introduction of central contracts, has been disturbed enough by rumours that the ECB hierarchy would welcome a streamlined championship that he has written to his fellow chairmen proposing that candidates for board chairman - including the present incumbent Lord MacLaurin - should produce manifestos.

"These rumours are a huge turn-off for potential sponsors and the ECB should snuff it out if there is no substance. County cricket has gone a long way towards backing the England team this summer. Now we want some proper leadership."

Last night the ECB offered it. "We recognise the undeniable importance of all 18 first-class counties, and this will be apparent when we publish our five-year strategy for the game later in the year," said the chief executive Tim Lamb.

Hampshire, oddly enough, were one county who would gladly have seen Alan Mullally receive a central contract: it would have helped to pay his wages. Mullally's England return lasted 48 hours and he pulled out of England's 13 yesterday with a thigh strain.

webTitle: Poverty gap threatens to destroy league

fields.headline: Poverty gap threatens to destroy league
fields.standfirst:
As game breaches £1bn barrier, report claims that new broadcast deal gives football one last chance to save its poorer clubs from ruin
Deloitte & Touche Annual Review of Football Finance
fields.trailText: Football was warned yesterday that it had one last chance to salvage its future otherwise the game as we know it could be destroyed.
fields.body:
Football was warned yesterday that it had one last chance to salvage its future otherwise the game as we know it could be destroyed.

The annual Deloitte & Touche report on football finance confirmed yesterday that the game is richer than ever before and on the verge of breaking through the £1bn mark in annual turnover. However, with most of the money going towards players' wages or to foreign clubs, the report's authors warn that new money from the sale of television and internet rights, particularly by the Football League, must be distributed sensibly to ensure that clubs are prevented from going out of business. The report found that only five football league clubs out of 72 made an operating profit during the 1998-99 season.

The Football League's new £380m television and internet deal, which was signed in this June this, is being seen as a way of saving the country's less profitable clubs in an era where economic disparity is a common feature of the game.

Gerry Boon, the report's editor, said: "The new TV deals offer Football League clubs a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to stabilise their financial condition once and for all - to create a business that can break even or even run at a profit on a sustainable basis."

Boon added that the money needed to be distributed in a way that would help ensure the future of the existing league structure and not go just to the bigger clubs.

Boon said: "The Football League has done a fantastic television deal. It presents a great opportunity because running a football league club has been an unprofitable activity. If the money is distributed right then it could save many clubs in all three divisions."

In total, the report found that football's income across all 92 professional clubs in 1998/99 rose 10% to £951m and that by the time results are reported for last season and the new television deals taken into account, the entire football industry will be worth more than £1 billion for the first time in its history.

However, the biggest threat to the game is the growing gap between rich and poor, brought about mainly by television money. The next Premiership television deal is worth around £2 billion but the bulk of that is expected to go on wages and transfers, mainly to foreign clubs, resulting in even less revenue for football league clubs who once relied on the sale of players to balance the books.

The no-win situation many of the country's less fashionable clubs find themselves in meant that in 1998/99 only five of 72 football league clubs registered an operating profit, compared to 14 of 20 Premiership clubs.

The bulk of money within the game will continue to be spent on wages and transfers. In 1998/99 English clubs spent £316.9m on transfers, compared to £227.9m the season before. £142.2m (compared to £70m the season before) went abroad while the Premiership spent £27.5m on transfers from Nationwide League clubs.

Boon warned that it was becoming increasingly hard for First Division clubs to secure promotion to the Premiership. Top-flight clubs will earn £23m a year from the new television deal while a First Division club will receive £13.5m. With money less likely to filter down the leagues and players and agents already preparing new wage demands, Boon claimed that a new structure to English professional football was already emerging.

At the top of the new structure are the established Premiership clubs, who because of television money, extra matchday revenue and merchandising are able to generate huge sums of money. Clubs in the First Division will look to consolidate their position, while a third group of clubs will "yo-yo" between the top two divisions.

Boon said: "In a few years time, division one clubs will need around £25m for a promotion push. The gap is widening. For the majority of our 92 league clubs playing in the Premiership or in Europe will always be a dream."

The pressure for success, however, is pushing many clubs towards financial insecurity. Worryingly, the report found that professional clubs borrow a total of £118m from banks. At some point they will want to be paid back.

webTitle: Irish demand doctors' notes from injured trio

fields.headline: Irish demand doctors' notes from injured trio
fields.trailText: The Irish Football Association has threatened to prevent Neil Lennon, Gerry Taggart and Steve Lomas from playing in the Premiership on Saturday after all three cried off from tonight's Northern Ireland friendly with Yugoslavia in Belfast claiming to be injured.
fields.body:
The Irish Football Association has threatened to prevent Neil Lennon, Gerry Taggart and Steve Lomas from playing in the Premiership on Saturday after all three cried off from tonight's Northern Ireland friendly with Yugoslavia in Belfast claiming to be injured.

The IFA is suspicious and feels that Leicester, Lennon and Taggart's club, and West Ham, where Lomas is captain, might be trying to pull the wool over their eyes as they prepare for the start of the season on Saturday.

Lennon, according to his club, has a thigh injury and Taggart an ankle problem. West Ham claim that Lomas has tendinitis. The IFA may take a little more persuading though, and has asked the two clubs for medical reports on the injuries. It will not lift its threat to prevent the players from playing on Saturday until wholly satisfied.

The Northern Ireland manager Sammy McIlroy, though, had words with the trio yesterday and accepts that they are unfit. "I've spoken to Lennon and Taggart and they were in the medical room at Leicester City," he said. "They assured me that they are injured and that they wanted to be here.

"As far as I'm concerned, I have to believe these players. I have to take them at their word. I've also spoken to Steve Lomas on the phone and at least I've heard it from the players themselves."

Dominic Matteo last night agreed the personal terms of a five-year contract with Leeds and will conclude his £4.75m transfer from Liverpool, subject to a medical, today. "All the formalities have been completed," said the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale. "We are just waiting for Dominic to complete his medical and then he will be a Leeds United player."

Wolves have signed Manchester City's Robert Taylor on a four-year deal for £1.55m. The striker, who joined the Maine Road club for £1.5m last November, turned down Portsmouth to move instead to Molineux.

"I have been interested in Robert for a while," said Colin Lee, the Wolves manager. "He is a hard-working striker who will score goals and I am delighted he has signed for us."

Fifa has lifted its ban on the use of Harare's national stadium, where 13 people were killed in a stampede at last month's World Cup qualifying match between Zimbabwe and South Africa.

Chaos broke out after police fired tear gas to control unruly fans. Zimbabwe's president Robert Mugabe subsequently accused opposition agitators of provoking the violence.

Scotland are hoping to arrange a friendly against Australia at Hampden Park on November 15.

webTitle: Chelsea at war after Leboeuf attacks Vialli

fields.headline: Chelsea at war after Leboeuf attacks Vialli
fields.trailText: Frank Leboeuf's future at Chelsea was in doubt last night after he was branded "totally unprofessional and out of order" by the club for his swingeing criticism of Gianluca Vialli earlier in the day.
fields.body:
Frank Leboeuf's future at Chelsea was in doubt last night after he was branded "totally unprofessional and out of order" by the club for his swingeing criticism of Gianluca Vialli earlier in the day.

The France defender destroyed the feel-good factor established by Sunday's victory over Manchester United by claiming Vialli was at loggerheads with his squad and had tried to force him out when he was most in need of the manager's support.

"Vialli has problems with everybody, with Albert Ferrer and many others," Leboeuf claimed. "It's normal for a coach to get along with his lads, but not him.

"Last year he didn't back me up when I had problems with the referee during a game against Leeds [for stamping on Harry Kewell]. He even tried to get me out of the club. But when [Arsenal's] Patrick Vieira had discipline problems, Arsène Wenger supported him."

Leboeuf's remarks, made from France where he is preparing for tonight's international against a Rest of the World XI, drew an angry response from Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson.

"If there's any credence whatsoever in the comments it's totally unprofessional and out of order to come out with remarks like 'He's got a problem with everybody'," Hutchinson said.

Leboeuf's typical forthrightness can be expected to alienate fellow players as well as Vialli. Hutchinson recently spoke to the 32-year-old about his capacity to be his "own worst enemy" with inopportune remarks and said Leboeuf accepted that. Yet the centre-back does not appear to have taken it to heart.

His outburst seems to have been fuelled in part by insecurity brought on by Vialli's pursuit of Gareth Southgate. He feels the need for first-team football particularly acutely because Laurent Blanc plays his last game for France tonight.

"I would like to finish my career at Chelsea," Leboeuf said, "but I'm not sure that the coach has that much faith in me. I don't know what's in store for me since there are rumours that Southgate will be arriving. But I'm not that worried.

"Footballers lead a nomadic existence and so we must always be ready to move on. My aim is the 2002 World Cup, so if I'm on the bench by then that will mean I won't be able to play for France."

Hutchinson said he would sit down with Leboeuf as soon as the player returns to London. "Of course he's got a part to play at Chelsea but he's got to learn not to upset people, " he added.

Meanwhile, Chelsea have agreed a deal of about £8m with Barcelona for Boudewijn Zenden, although Hutchinson claimed the Holland winger could still join Lazio. "If I was a betting man I would say the odds are still slightly against us," he said.

fields.headline: Ferguson move to Everton collapses
fields.standfirst: Newcastle refuse striker's demand for loyalty bonus
fields.trailText: Duncan Ferguson's dream of a move back to his beloved Everton almost certainly collapsed last night after he appeared to place his wish for financial security before his desire to return to Goodison Park.
fields.body:
Duncan Ferguson's dream of a move back to his beloved Everton almost certainly collapsed last night after he appeared to place his wish for financial security before his desire to return to Goodison Park.

This morning Ferguson should have been enjoying an emotional reunion with those team-mates from whom he was reluctantly parted 20 months ago; instead he is staring an uncertain future in the face because of his failure to make one brief phone call.

Ferguson was scheduled to arrive in the north-west at noon yesterday to undergo a medical before completing his transfer back from Newcastle United.

But, to the astonishment of Everton officials and the disgust of the club's manager Walter Smith, the 28 year-old Scot failed to show up.

Even more damaging was the player's failure to phone either Smith or Everton's chief executive Michael Dunford to offer an explanation or excuse for his non-appearance.

Smith immediately indicated that his two-month pursuit of Ferguson was at an end - news which will hardly have been welcomed on Tyneside.

As Everton's medical team awaited his arrival, Ferguson was at St James' Park making one last attempt to persuade Newcastle that his brief stay at the club merited the payment of a loyalty bonus - believed to be about £750,000.

Ferguson is believed to have stayed in the north-east on Monday night before training with his Newcastle team-mates yesterday morning. His plan was then to hold one final round of talks with members of his club's hierarchy in the belief that he could convince them he should be given a cash settlement to help speed his departure back to Everton.

Ever since Everton's interest in him first surfaced last month, Ferguson has argued that as he has never indicated a desire to leave Newcastle he should be entitled to the payment, in full, of bonuses which would have accrued had he stayed to see out the remaining three years of his contract.

Newcastle's board of directors - seemingly to a man - were unmoved by Ferguson's plea for a handout, insisting he had spent insufficient time on Tyneside to warrant any bonus.

When he was controversially sold to Newcastle in November 1998 for £8m, Ferguson collected about £1m in bonuses and signing-on fees.

During what has been a rather unproductive 21-month spell in the north-east during which he has made only 24 Premiership starts, Ferguson has been paid more than £35,000 a week, making him one of the highest-paid players in British football.

However, despite Smith's sense of outrage, Everton's desperation for a striker of proven ability is such that the deal may yet be resurrected.

Smith has spent most of the summer seeking to sign a competent forward after being informed that Kevin Campbell would definitely miss the opening few weeks of the new season after knee surgery almost five months ago.

Smith ran the rule over several men - including Blackburn's Ashley Ward - before informing his club's majority shareholder, Bill Kenwright, he wished to re-sign Ferguson.

If Ferguson was this morning to abandon his attempts to squeeze more money out of his current employer, and then apologise to his prospective future employer, he might still find himself lining up in a blue shirt when Everton's season opens against Leeds United at Elland Road on Saturday.

Everton assumed that the closure of the deal was little more than a formality after they had agreed terms with Newcastle - an initial down-payment of £3.75m with an additional £1.25m after Ferguson had featured in a specified number, believed to be 60, of first-team games.

Last night Ferguson's agent, Dennis Roach, indicated that his client would almost certainly be remaining with Newcastle, curiously citing his friendship with the former England captain Alan Shearer as the deciding factor.

webTitle: Football comment: Walter Smith's judgment in question

fields.headline: Going back is no way to move forward
fields.trailText: Walter Smith's efforts to bring Duncan Ferguson back from Newcastle have raised further questions about his judgment.
fields.body:
Walter Smith, the man who locked horns with Peter Johnson and won, can do little wrong at Goodison Park. There are some clubs where getting rid of the chairman can be placed on a par with lifting the Champions League so far as the fans are concerned. Everton was one of them.

There are dangerous signs, however, that the Everton manager is beginning to push his invulnerability to the limit, in the same way that Bill Murray repeatedly killed himself in Groundhog Day because he knew he would live through it.

After signing Paul Gascoigne, who cost Middlesbrough £71,875 an appearance, he will be remembered as the manager who sold Barmby and bought Barmy. Unless Gascoigne stays fit and out of trouble, Smith's reputation will be damaged.

Now, his efforts to bring Duncan Ferguson back from Newcastle, albeit unsuccessful, have raised similar questions about his judgment. Going back, when everything has changed in your absence, rarely works, in football or any other walk of life. It usually ends in anti-climax; legends can only lose their lustre. Nor does the fact that Smith was interested in Ferguson say much for what is currently available in the market place.

This is not to argue that the club of Dixie Dean and Tommy Lawton should not employ a target man. Nor is it to question the tactical acumen of Smith, even though experience should have told him that, when Ferguson was at Goodison Park, everything was played to him and that his return would signal a miserable return to route one football, an approach most supporters despised and something the club appeared to have evolved beyond with Kevin Campbell last season.

No, it is none of these things. It is to argue that going back, hankering after history, does not work unless all the other ingredients are the same. Usually they are not. Worse still, it betrays a measure of panic, conveys the notion that to travel backwards is better than not moving at all.

Howard Kendall, who twice returned to Everton as manager after his period of outstanding success in the 1980s, might have given Smith some useful advice.

Ferguson was Everton's last hero, a memory that could only have been tarnished, just as countless other players have had their reputations rewritten by untimely returns to the clubs that made them famous when managers with no vision have fallen back on their memories.

It can be generally said that going back does not work for boxers, for racing drivers or for cricketers, as Graham Gooch would ruefully confirm after his unhappy return to first-class cricket this season. And it certainly does not work for footballers.

Since the hindsight of fans endows great players with even greater qualities than they originally possessed, those who return must be better than they originally were if they are to be judged successful. Few sportsmen can live up to the raised level of expectation.

Surely the Everton manager was not indulging in a piece of crude, William Hague-style populism. He is too good a manager for that. Besides, Everton supporters were split down the middle about whether a Ferguson return would have been a good thing for the club.

Good luck to Walter Smith. He is a likeable fellow and he has much on his plate at a club which, since finishing sixth in 1995-96, has come 15th, 17th, 14th and 13th in the past four seasons.

He has had a busy summer and made a number of promising signings. But, if he sees Everton's future in their recent, modest past, he and the Gwladys Street faithful who for once did not have to worry about the prospect of relegation last season are in for a bitter disappointment.

If Smith cannot see that, he would deserve to see not only Ferguson but Peter Johnson back at Goodison Park.

webTitle: Cautious Wenger fears the end of transfers

fields.headline: Cautious Wenger fears the end of transfers
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger admitted yesterday that he is being cautious in his dealings at Highbury because he fears the transfer system will soon be abolished, rendering expensive signings worthless overnight.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger admitted yesterday that he is being cautious in his dealings at Highbury because he fears the transfer system will soon be abolished, rendering expensive signings worthless overnight.

The Arsenal manager earned £30m from the sales of Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars to Barcelona but is determined not to pay exorbitant fees in this climate of uncertainty, as his ongoing battle with Bordeaux over the value of Sylvain Wiltord shows.

Wenger said he would look elsewhere for a striker unless a deal for Wiltord was reached this week because he needs to bring someone in before the Champions League deadline of September 1. But he stressed he would not be held to ransom on any transfer.

"Since I've arrived here I've always tried to buy players at the right price," he said. "With the transfer rules maybe collapsing next season we could have bought a player for an expensive price that you cannot sell him for.

"It is influencing my strategy because I am really scared the whole thing will collapse. It's a huge crack that could happen and it could happen very soon."
