webTitle: Girls' lead in A-levels expected to grow

fields.headline: Girls' lead in A-levels expected to grow
fields.standfirst:
First gender breakdown of results set to confirm supremacy

The Guardian Unlimited's clearing service
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText:
Girls' continued supremacy in exams is expected to be
confirmed today when A-level boards publish a
breakdown of results by gender for the first time.
fields.body:
Girls' continued supremacy in exams is expected to be confirmed today when A-level boards publish a breakdown of results by gender for the first time.

The figures, published a day ahead of individual A-level results, are likely to confirm trends brought out in a comparison of GCSE results over the past 10 years which shows that girls have extended their lead over boys.

Pass rates across subjects and for both sexes will be published tonight as part of the examination boards' attempt to improve transparency.

In 1989 35.8% of girls and 29.8% of boys achieved five or more A to Cs at GCSE. In 1999 53.2% of girls and 42.6% of boys achieved the same level.

During the 90s girls overtook boys in GCSE maths results and maintained their lead in English. The publication of GCSE results next week is likely to show a similar pattern.

Ministers are concerned about the underperformance of boys in state schools and in particular point to a dip in performance during the early years of secondary school.

Many fail to progress beyond, and in some cases fall behind, the standards attained in key stage two tests at 11. Some of the money made available in last month's spending review will address that issue.

Meanwhile, a package of measures to make this year's A-level and GCSE marking in England fairer and more transparent was revealed yesterday.

The measures could herald a new era of "candidate power", assisted by the internet. Designed to eliminate bias, they limit the information examiners have about candidates and improve the candidates' ability to question the examiners' verdict.

But students who appeal against the marks they have been awarded could find their grades can go down as well as up.

In a pilot scheme by the qualifications and curriculum authority (QCA), which oversees examinations in England, the names of some candidates were disguised to examiners. Up to 20,000 pupils, taking one GCSE English paper, wrote their name underneath a flap which was then sealed. Their candidate number was written on the top.

Throughout England the names of the examination centre, school or college of candidates were kept secret from examiners. This follows a complaint last year from an independent school that its candidates were deliberately marked down by an examiner.

The centre's name does not appear on exam scripts, but it does come attached to examiner mark forms.

Dennis Opposs, manager of the QCA's quality audit, said that after the Macpherson report on the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence public bodies had to respond to anxiety about discrimination and bias. The best system was one in which there was no room for doubt.

Hiding the names of the examination centre will "provide reassurance for those that might previously have had any concerns about the impact of schools' names on markers".

Once grades have been published candidates in all A-level and AS-level exams, and in GCSE English, Irish, Welsh and maths, will this year be entitled to see their marked exam scripts on request.

And, in another pilot scheme, some candidates will be able to see their exam papers on the internet. The scheme involves about 25,000 scripts and 25 centres in subjects including maths and English.The QCA hopes that eventually all students will be able to check their marked papers on the internet.

Last year the results of 3% of A-levels and 0.5% of GCSE exams were questioned. After re-marking, 0.4% of A-level grades and 0.05% of GCSE grades went up.

The QCA said yesterday it had urged that if remarking produced a lower mark it should be allowed to award a lower grade. The decision has gone to ministers for approval.

 Birmingham University is to mask the names of students from tutors marking many exam papers because of fears that women are marked down. Some universities already have anonymous marking.

webTitle: Education: Who is the brightest of them all?

fields.headline: Who is the brightest of them all?
fields.standfirst: A report confirms that girls perform better at A-levels than boys, writes education correspondent Rebecca Smithers
fields.trailText: Wednesday 4.15pm: A report confirms that girls perform better at A-levels than boys, writes education correspondent Rebecca Smithers .
fields.body:
Watch out boys, here we come! Girl power will be confirmed later today with the publication of A-level results reinforcing the apparent intellectual superiority of the female sex over their male rivals. For the first time, results for 280,000 A-level candidates have been broken down by gender and are expected to confirm that girls are better overall at passing examinations.

While boys will be shown to have made no real progress, girls have not only overtaken boys by achieving more grade As but are also steaming ahead across the whole range of grades.

The results follow the publication of earlier figures from the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority which oversees the exam system, showing that the gender gap is not only alive and well but is also widening at both GCSE and A-level. The results are interesting and will be scrutinised by education experts all over the country.

What is difficult to pin down is whether girls are naturally more clever, or whether they do better because they work harder. The earlier maturity of girls is undoubtedly a key factor, and explains while girls steal a march by doing better in the so-called SATS tests for 11-year olds.

In addition, according to Alan Smithers of Liverpool University, girls have a better expectation of a good university place and career; their superior verbal skills at a young age mean they master English language more quickly; and the emphasis on coursework in GCSEs favour the girls' more consistent approach towards study.

Overall, girls tend to be more conscientious and diligent, which will inevitably reap rewards from the exam system. It is no coincidence that girls removed from the potentially harmful influence of boys can do even better - the results from single sex girls' schools are among the best in the country.

The National Association of Head Teachers has already indicated its concern about this year's A-level results, and the need to crack down on a laddish culture that despises academic achievement. It also had a dig at parents for tolerating such an attitude rather than encouraging their children to better themselves.

The belief that it is not cool to be clever is a worrying one. Moreover, the NAHT believes very strongly that if the problem of under achievement among boys is not cracked by 11 - and by 14 at the latest - it will cause damage throughout the rest of their school careers and even beyond that.

What is to be regretted is that girls' early promise fails to follow through later in their lives. A research study published earlier this week by the British Psychological Society (and carried out by academics at Oxford) for example, claimed that men get more firsts at Oxford University than women not because they are more clever, but because the exam system favours the male.

The Department for Education and Employment is relatively unusual in Whitehall in having a fair smattering of women ministers. So why are still relatively few women in the Cabinet, for example, or in senior jobs in the judiciary or industry? Is it because even in this day and age women are still forced to choose between family or career? There are clearly still more questions than answers

fields.headline: Pierre-Yves Gerbeau
fields.standfirst:
Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the chief executive of the Millennium Dome, was online to answer your questions on Tuesday August 15. He outlined his belief in the dome, told how he wished the whole enterprise had been left to business people rather than politicians, and of his history managing more than the car park at Eurodisney. This is an edited transcript of the discussion; click here to read the full debate and have your say

Millennium Dome: special report
fields.trailText: 15 August:Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the chief executive of the Millennium Dome, was live online to answer your questions. Read his postings here.
fields.body:
J Swan
I deplore the whingey British sniping which has taken pleasure in running down the dome. Typical dog-in-the-manger stuff. It's just an excuse for the Daily Mail to have a pop at a Labour government and shouldn't be encouraged. Most people who have been seem to have really enjoyed it.

DMcV
Down, Swan! The Dome is a Tory idea. If the Daily Mail is daft enough to snipe at it, so be it. Their poodles built it.

PY Gerbeau
With regard to the Tory idea, I am a businessman, not a politician, and truly believe that politics and business do not match.

SysOut
The expo is also having trouble in Hanover getting visitors. Do you see any connection between the difficulties of Eurodisney, dome and Expo?

PY Gerbeau
SysOut - one more time, a business that should have been driven by experts of the tourism and attraction industry and not by politicians. Are they ever going to learn?

DeVise
Un Dome finance par les impots et dirige par des hommes d'affaires! Quel idee! Voici surement la troisieme voie dont M Blair est si fier. Ni le marche libre des Etats-Unis, ni l'intervention socialiste... Bravo!

Alex Whiley
Does the French media rubbish France's "grands projets" in the same way as the British media does? To what extent do you blame the media for the mixed success of the dome?

PY Gerbeau
AlexWhiley, I think this is not a question of British and non-British media. It is more the fact that the dome has been and still is a huge political football, and that people have different agendas all with the same objective - knocking it down. It is very frustrating for me and for the team, since we have fixed the product, the business and the organisation. So now, we are at the middle of a big dichotomy, which is the financial problems from the previous business plan and the lean, successful, commercial operation and great popular success that the dome is today.

Mpcrossley
If the failure of the dome prior to your timely intervention were due to financial problems, then to what extent is this "great popular success" due to your team's management initiatives and how much is due to being bailed out by the National Lottery?

PY Gerbeau
The financial situation has nothing to do with the popular success. Actually it is an argument to knock it down again.

To clarify what you call a "bail out" from lottery money, I went only once to the commission, my banker, to demonstrate that the original business plan was entirely wrong and that was it!

Since then, we are receiving the legacy receipt, which is the money that was always coming to the company from the sale of the business. That was factored in the original business plan, so there is absolutely nothing new.

Why don't you come over and test out for yourself why this is now a great popular success?

HannahB74
In former creative director Stephen Bayley's words, is the dome's image "irredeemably mired"?

PY Gerbeau
About Stephen Bayley, let me pass...

Bauhaus1
Hand on heart, what do you think are the weak points of the dome and how would you have done it better yourself if you'd been involved from the outset?

PY Gerbeau
Bauhaus1, I am actually dreaming every night to be able to put the clock back and it be October 1 1999.

Morcheeba
If you had had £750m to spend on something to mark the millennium, do you think you would have built a dome?

PY Gerbeau
It is not only building a visitor attraction. It's also regenerating a derelict, polluted site. And creating thousands and thousands of new jobs. Turning non-skilled people into service experts. The good news is we proved now in the last six months that there was a viable and sustainable business for the dome as a visitor attraction.

rubenruben
M Gerbeau: there have been a lot of unkind comments about the actual role you held at Eurodisney. Come clean now - were you really just in charge of the car parks?

PY Gerbeau
Fact: I have been a kind of success story inside the Eurodisney organisation. I actually got promoted five times in six years. And yes, inside my multiple responsibilities in running the Eurodisney theme park was the management of an 11,000-space car park. Fortunately, I had competent management in the field because I would be, I am sure, a very poor car park attendant.

KennyGee
Don't you think the recent sheep TV ad campaign was likely to drive away as many people as it attracted? It was almost admitting that your product wasn't all that good.

PY Gerbeau
Being a practical marketeer, I've implemented very strict measurables and quantifiables to measure the impact of the new TV ad. The reservations to our call centre raised by more than 35% since the ad was shown.

I agree with you it is controversial, but this is exactly what we needed to convince people because the challenge now is to get people to come to the dome and as soon as they are inside we know they will have a fantastic day.

DMcV
New offers for the "summer" were headlined a week or two ago. When, in fact, Scottish schoolchildren had already been on holiday for over a month. This underlines what we always suspected: that the dome is really an ephemeral fun palace for the south-east, but subsidised by all.

PY Gerbeau
To give you precise numbers, usually 2% of the Scottish population comes to London for a visit. Since the dome is here, 4% of Scottish people came to enjoy the unique experience. That is just one example of the internationality of the dome.

ABC123
Hello PY. What are you going to do when you lose your job at the end of the year? Or are you going to be involved in the Japanese theme park project? What do you think should have happened to the dome after this year? Couldn't you have brought some French influence to bear and got it preserved like they did with the Eiffel Tower?

PY Gerbeau
I am sure I will find another big challenge and something to fix somewhere in the world. Meanwhile I would love to stay in the UK, because I did appreciate the great support from most people that I have met around the dome.

I have to go but thanks for your comments.

webTitle: Ferguson "upset" after move to Everton falls through

fields.headline: Ferguson "upset" after move to Everton falls through
fields.trailText: Duncan Ferguson is bitterly upset with Newcastle after his £3.75m move back to Everton collapsed earlier today, according to his agent Dennis Roach. But despite his anger the Scottish striker has vowed to stay at St James' Park and fight for his place.
fields.body:
Duncan Ferguson is bitterly upset with Newcastle after his £3.75m move back to Everton collapsed earlier today, according to his agent Dennis Roach. But despite his anger the Scottish striker has vowed to stay at St James' Park and fight for his place.

"Everton is the only club that Duncan would have left Newcastle for - and it is his decision now to stay at Newcastle," claimed Roach. "He's upset but he has told me he aims to prove them wrong and make them select him in the side."

"Duncan feels he didn't ask for a transfer, had agreed to a lesser contract with Everton and that he wasn't being treated right. Newcastle have handled this deal poorly. He's virtually been accused of being greedy over this," Roach added.

Roach then went on to blame the board for not paying out the compensation Ferguson felt he was entitled to for leaving with three years left on his contract. "Freddy Shepherd and the board have not given an inch," he said. "They feel that Ferguson has not given them value for money in his time there and they were determined that he would not get a penny to move even if it meant him staying at St James' Park and seeing out his contract.

"Talk of Duncan wanting £1m is rubbish. We didn't instigate the transfer and Duncan knew nothing about it. He had a four-year contract and didn't want to leave. He's just bought a plot of land to build a house next door to Alan Shearer, his wife's just had a baby and he was more than happy to stay at the club.

"I doubt he'll be able to forget what has been said about him but sometimes you have to put things behind you and get on with life. It comes to something that when you turn up for training one day and the manager asks you why you are not down at Everton for a medical. That happened 10 days ago when a previous medical was arranged. Nobody told him about it."

"If Newcastle were so desperate to get rid of him and wanted him to leave, they should have sat down and talked about the situation, there should have been some gesture from the board." Ferguson has decided to stay at Newcastle despite facing a battle to win his place back, with Bobby Robson expected to start the season with Alan Shearer and summer signing Carl Cort in attack.

"I've discussed all the possible problems with Duncan, but he has decided he will stay," said Roach. "Duncan feels he can put anyone out of the side and he has told me he will fight for his place. People forget that Duncan and Alan Shearer turned things round last season at Newcastle, Duncan scored the goal of the season against Manchester United and had a good run of games in the side and the fans were on his side.

"He'll start the season now with Newcastle, there are no other offers around."

Ferguson has decided to stay at Newcastle despite facing a battle to win his place back, with Bobby Robson expected to start the season with Alan Shearer and summer signing Carl Cort in attack. "I've discussed all the possible problems with Duncan, but he has decided he will stay," said Roach. "Duncan feels he can put anyone out of the side and he has told me he will fight for his place. People forget that Duncan and Alan Shearer turned things round last season at Newcastle, Duncan scored the goal of the season against Manchester United and had a good run of games in the side and the fans were on his side. "He'll start the season now with Newcastle, there are no other offers around."

fields.headline: Eyes wide open
fields.standfirst: In the US, anyone can access the names and addresses of sex offenders, but while child murders there continue to rise, in the UK the figures remain low.  Kendra Inman reports
fields.trailText: In the US, anyone can access the names and addresses of sex offenders, but while child murders there continue to rise, in the UK the figures remain low. Kendra Inman reports.
fields.body:
Parents in Benton County in South Carolina know what predatory sex offenders look like. At any time of the day or night they can visit the community notification page on the Benton Sheriff's website and check through the gallery of convicted sex offenders living in their area.

They range from 28-year-old Kenneth Ray Davis, who targets young boys, to 71-year-old Jerry Lee Ray who abuses girls. Both offenders are on parole and banned from having contact with minors including visiting playgrounds, arcades and other places frequented by children.

This is the American way of protecting children. In the UK pressure is mounting for a "Sarah's law", named after the murdered eight-year-old Sarah Payne, to establish a sex offenders' register open to the public. The move would be a British version of the US Megan's Law that allows communities access to the names and addresses of sex offenders.

As ministers decide whether more legislation is necessary, a British academic claims the US measures fail to protect children, and that ministers should give greater protection to children in the UK by ploughing more money into anti-poverty initiatives.

Professor Colin Pritchard, of Southampton University, points to World Health Organisation figures published last month on child homi cides in the western world. In the US, where the number of adult murders has fallen, the number of children being killed has continued to rise, up 58% over the past five years, even after the introduction of Megan's Law. While in England and Wales we have seen the biggest reduction in child homicide in the western world, he says. Pritchard believes that our child protection system, although far from perfect, is succeeding in protecting children.

"In 1974 at the time of the inquiry into the death of Maria Colwell, when the UK was waking up to child abuse, this country was the third highest child killer in the western world. Now we're the fifth lowest," he says.

As the welfare state has been rolled back, so the child murder rate in the US has risen, says Pritchard. "Under Reagan and Bush, they began to dismantle the welfare services. Although we had cuts, we did preserve our child protection services," he says.

It is often said that "stranger danger" is not the biggest threat to children - most die at the hand of someone they are close to. Pritchard says most child murderers are in a parental role. "In the UK in the two years 1996-97, 110 children were killed. Just 19 were killed by a stranger. And for every child homicide, four children are killed in traffic accidents on the roads."

He explains: "We know that most child sex abuse of a damaging kind takes place in families, often poor families. We also know that the nasty malevolent stranger exists. But he targets disadvantaged children -those in poverty are more vulnerable to the lure of the stranger offering them gifts and treats."

By tackling child poverty, we would be cutting the number of children vulnerable to abuse, inside and outside the home, he argues. He points to Sure Start, the government's programme to improve the chances of pre-school babies and children as one answer. "But Sure Start will only be applied to a third of the country," he says. "It needs to be available to all struggling families."

Fellow academic Professor Nigel Parton, from the University of Huddersfield, has written widely on child protection. He agrees that investing in Sure Start would do more to protect children than a "Sarah's law".

However, he stops short of drawing a direct correlation between poverty and abuse. "You can't lump all child abuse in together. For example, there are issues around sexual abuse that are unique to that form of abuse - not just its emotional impact, but in the circumstances that surround it," he says.

Not everyone supports Pritchard's theory that the success of child protection systems can be judged by murder rates. In the past his approach has attracted criticism from the NSPCC, among others.

In a recent statement, the charity said that communities have a right to know if paedophiles living in their area pose a serious risk to their children. Although it recognises that "unmanaged forms of community notification can result in dangerous vigilante actions, mistaken identity and harm inflicted on innocent parties. Its net effect may simply be to drive paedophiles underground".

The NSPCC wants to extend a scheme in Barrow, Cumbria, that recently prevented vigilante action on a housing estate. Childwatch uses appointed adults to keep an eye on designated areas where children walk or play. The adults, called "hidden eyes" are anonymous and look out for people acting suspiciously as they go about their business. If they see something worrying they have instant access to the police.

Graham Brooks, NSPCC area child services manager, says that although the scheme has yet to be systematically evaluated, the indications are that they work on several levels.

When a potential vigilante situation arose, Childwatch met with residents and were able to convince them that the person would be monitored, says Brooks.

Childwatch's "hidden eyes" have found people with a record of offences against children parked outside schools. "There is also anecdotal evidence that children's quality of life improves as parents feel happier about letting them go out and about in Childwatch areas," says Brooks.

Dispelling some myths

In 1998-99 in the UK, there were a total of 26 murders of children aged 5-16 years old, 24 of toddlers aged between one and under five years old and 45 babies under one year. Of these, around six or seven children per year are killed by a stranger and the numbers are not increasing, according to Home Office figures.

In the UK, fewer young children than ever before, aged 0-4, are being killed by abusers, says Professor Colin Pritchard. World Health Organisation statistics show that in the four years from 1974-78, 38 young children per million population died. By 1993-97 this had fallen to 15 - a drop of 61%. Similar falls were also seen in Japan, which saw a drop of 61% and Germany, down 54%. In the US, 38 young children per million population died between 1974-78. But by 1993-97 the figure had risen to 89 - a hike of 58%.

fields.headline: Dreams, Prayers, and Dearest wishes
fields.trailText: GORDON'S GROUNDHOG DAY
fields.body:
GORDON'S GROUNDHOG DAY

Yesterday morning Gordon Strachan woke up to find things eerily repeating themselves. He wrestled a hairbrush through his ginger locks just as he had the year before. He sat down at his breakfast table and ate three Shredded Wheat, just as he had the year before. He picked his nose with the little finger of his right hand, just as he had the year before. And then he went out and spent over £6m on a young, pacy forward with international caps who was too good for the First Division, just as he had the year before. How weird do you want?

The cause of this burp in the space-time continuum is Craig Bellamy, the Welsh Robbie Keane as they're already calling him (and if they're not, what are they doing?). The 21-year-old was set to sign for Coventry from Norwich City today for a reported fee of £6.5m. "We've agreed a fee with the club and terms with the player and Craig is on his way to Coventry for a medical," Cov chairman Bryan Richardson said this morning. "Gordon (Strachan) has had tabs on him for some considerable time and after speaking to several other people about the player to make sure, they all said 'go and get him, he's tops'."

Apart from the fact that nobody on the entire face of the universe says "go get him, he's tops," the Fiver can understand Richardson's excitement at landing Bellamy. He has scored 34 goals in 78 starts for the Canaries, and also notched the winner for Wales against Denmark in Copenhagen not too long ago. In fact, at the end of the 1999 season he was probably a hotter property than Keane himself. "We fully expect Craig to do as well as Robbie, if not better," Richardson said today. And if that proves to be correct, Wee Gord can probably look forward to an eerily familiar call from an Italian giant next summer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

FATHER FIGURES

Earlier today, Pastor David O'Leary was busy bemoaning the state of football. "Players have too much power now," he thundered. "When I was growing up the clubs had all the power and that wasn't right. Now it's the other way. What we need is a balance - as if it continues to go the way it's heading with players, I think football will blow itself up!" Perhaps it was the uplifting power of the altar wine, but the Fiver couldn't help crying out a hearty "Hallelujah" at the power of his oratory. And we left happy, barely fearing the apocalypse because we knew that if it came there would always be a place for us by Pastor O'Leary's side.

So imagine our shock when this afternoon we read that he had splashed out £4.25m Liverpool's Dominic Matteo, and no doubt rewarded him with a hefty contract in the process! Of course Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale tried to smooth over our anger. "He (Matteo) is a proven quality player within the Premiership, which means we are not gambling on whether he can fit into a Premiership team," he said. To which we responded: "But he's not a regular first team player at Liverpool!" "He has played for the England B and U-21 international sides, so he has played beyond the Premiership level," was Ridsdale's rather innovative response to that.

Now Pastor O'Leary has his eyes set on another miracle. Because after he described the deal for Monaco midfielder John Arne Riise as being "dead" this time last week, today it looked like it may be back on. Riise, in particular seems very keen, admitting: "Leeds is still a club I want to play for, and I hope it works out. It's up to the clubs to agree a deal. It should work out if both clubs and myself are willing to ease a bit on our demands." Well that sounds like a balance to us.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I genuinely believe the Premier League is the best league in the worldIt is the media equivalent of a ready meal. It is convenient and it is possible for the public to know about all 20 clubs."

Premier League chief executive Richard Scudamore. The future of the game is safe with him.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

BEDROOM LOCK-IN UPDATE

Yesterday the Fiver locked itself into its room until it could trust the world to tell the truth again. Admittedly an ambitious plan, the attempt was almost instantly scuppered when we realised we'd forgotten to bring any crisps. But small trips to the shop aside, our vigil has been constant. Which is fortunate, given the things that have been going on in football today.

This morning, for example, Gianfranco Zola appeared in the official Big Brother newspaper (and how apt that is) to reveal that ''I am fascinated about returning to Napoli". Heartless managing director Colin Hutchinson had apparently denied the 34-year-old forward a sentimental move to the south of Italy by demanding £3m for his services. "I must confess I thought that was a lot," Zola reportedly said, adding enigmatically: "After Napoli's offer, Chelsea didn't want to know any more. But things can change very quickly."

This afternoon however, a different Gianfranco Zola emerged (it could be an identical twin, we can't be sure). In an interview with London's Evening Standard, the former player of the year denied any talk of a move to Napoli saying: "I am a man of my word. I gave you my word that I'll be staying at Chelsea, so that is what I will be doing." Hutchison chimed in too: "Where did that figure of £700,000 come from? The answer to that is I haven't a clue. He [Zola] was very upset at the way this has all come out." In fact, it turned out that this morning's shocker had come out of an interview conducted last May! And while that remains the case, we're not coming out at all.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Boudewijn Zenden will snub Chelsea and move to Lazio, according to reports in the Spanish media. They quote the player's father, Pierre Zenden, who admits: "The negotiations with Lazio have been reactivated. This time, there will be no problems with the payment, the reason why I believe he will go to Italy."

Borussia Dortmund have denied reports from Brazil that former Arsenal target Edu has signed for £3.3m. Club spokesman Josef Schneck said: "It's like a Latin American fairytale."

Paul Ritchie's agent has confirmed that Manchester City have made an inquiry to Rangers about the availability of the Scotland defender. "It's not a rumour," admitted Ritchie's agent Jim McArthur. "But stories that he's definitely on his way for £1m are not right, it's just an inquiry."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

37 Arsenal fans have been banned from attending games at Highbury this season following the violence that flared up before the Uefa Cup final. An Arsenal spokesman said: "They will not be welcome at Highbury this season. Supporters of this club are generally very well behaved and this represents a very small minority."

Everton's bid to take Duncan Ferguson back to Goodison Park has offically fallen through. A club statement released today said: "Everton have now been informed that the player was not able to agree the terms of his release from Newcastle United and that the transfer was off."

Dick Advocaat has claimed that Rangers must join a European League within two years to survive. "It's only a matter of time before an Atlantic or European league happens," he told the Rangers News. "It will be the only way to survive and if we want to survive then we must join - it's that simple."

Chile's Marcelo Salas subjected Brazil to one of the most humiliating nights in their history, setting up two goals and scoring the other as his team beat the four-times world champions 3-0 in a World Cup qualifier.

Nigerian FA officials have claimed that Kanu and Celestine Babayaro have promised to link up with their Olympic squad "as soon as practicable".

Austria are considering a bid to host Euro 2008 with either Hungary, Croatia or Switzerland as partners.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (2.35am) The same programme as the other night, only even later!

Sky Sports One: You're on Sky Sports! (10pm) The party's still going! Anyone for half a Pringle?

Football Mondial (12.30am) Special coverage of last year's international under-11 5-a-side competition in Sarajevo.

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore interviews (11pm) This week it's Alan Hudson. But let's face it, with the questions Moore-o will ask, it might as well be anybody.

British Eurosport: Pre-season football (9.40pm) It's at this time of year that Eurosport really comes into its own.

Euro 2000 - France v Spain (12.30am) See?

webTitle: Grounded Concorde pilots may be forced to retrain

fields.headline: Grounded Concorde pilots may be forced to retrain
fields.standfirst: Decision to suspend British Airways Concorde flights leaves airline's specialist crew in limbo
fields.trailText: Forty British Airways Concorde pilots are facing up to the fact that they may never fly the legendary aircraft again.
fields.body:
Forty British Airways Concorde pilots are facing up to the fact that they may never fly the legendary aircraft again.

BA said that while it is premature to speculate, the 21 Concorde captains and 19 first officers or co-pilots could see themselves retraining to fly more conventional long-haul aircraft, such as 747s or 767s, rather than the flagship airliner.

Even if Concorde is allowed to take to the skies again, safety modifications to protect the aircraft against future tyre bursts, such as the insertion of protective mudguards, may prevent the jet ever flying at supersonic speeds again.

British Airways spokesman Peter Middleton said the Concorde pilots were a dedicated team of flying enthusiasts with a genuine fondness for the aircraft.

"I am sure that they are quite emotional about the fact that Concorde has been grounded, as are the rest of us at BA. We are very hopeful that we can work our way through this time and get Concorde flying again.

"It would be premature at this stage to consider re-deploying the crew on other aircraft. I don't think we want to go down that line just yet."

Mr Middleton confirmed that under CAA rules, commercial pilots must carry out a specific number of take-offs and landings in the aircraft for which they have a rating.

To keep their flying licences current, the pilots will make full use of the airline's Concorde simulator for essential practice. They will do this during the months the fleet remains under cover.

Mr Middleton said it would be a blow to the crews to be kept away from their beloved fleet, given that they had a particular fondness for flying the supersonic jet.

"Obviously, these pilots have progressed on to Concorde from other aircraft . But there is no standard route into Concorde. Some of the pilots have even gone straight on to flying the plane after piloting turboprops.

"It is a demanding aircraft to fly and does require certain qualities in terms of personality and lifestyle.

"The Concorde pilots tend to be particularly dedicated to flying for flying's sake and probably do a lot of recreational flying in their spare time."

But aviation experts say the Concorde lifestyle is not suited to every pilot, especially those who prefer to travel to more varied routes around the world.

Because of its limited range, the pilots only fly to New York and back and tend to miss out on the lucrative allowances received by pilots spending, say, a week away in Australia.

Last night, it seemed clear that the crews may have to face the grim reality that the seven Concordes may be out of service for months.

Costly modification work may be needed on the supersonic fleet and there are fears that the super jets may never fly again.

The authority had therefore suspended the certificates of airworthiness of each of BA's seven Concordes "until appropriate measures have been taken to ensure a satisfactory level of safety as far as tyre destruction is concerned".

BA responded to the grounding ruling by announcing that it had cancelled all Concorde services until early September but that it could resume operations at 24 hours' notice should clearance be given ahead of that date.

webTitle: Yorkshire suffer as England get heavy-handed

fields.headline: Yorkshire suffer as England get heavy-handed
fields.trailText: The clash of county v country has been resonating for some years now. Warwickshire members used to moan when Bob Willis suddenly developed an extra yard of pace or three for England; David Gower treated the County Championship with about as much respect as Dean Jones treated Martin Bicknell in Australia in 1990-91; and Mike Atherton's views on county cricket make x-rated reading for chief executives throughout the land.
fields.body:
The clash of county v country has been resonating for some years now. Warwickshire members used to moan when Bob Willis suddenly developed an extra yard of pace or three for England; David Gower treated the County Championship with about as much respect as Dean Jones treated Martin Bicknell in Australia in 1990-91; and Mike Atherton's views on county cricket make x-rated reading for chief executives throughout the land.

But the current tug-of-love over Darren Gough between Yorkshire and England is a relatively new phenomenon, and is a direct result of the central-contracts system. England, eager to take on Pakistan with a fully refreshed pace attack, have ordered him to rest after the fifth and final Test against West Indies; Yorkshire, chasing their first title since 1968, would prefer Gough to play in the last two Championship games against Kent and Hampshire. And Gough himself? "I'm sayin' nowt." For a man who likes to speak his mind, his silence is eloquent.

Now the county game has been in thrall to the national side for a long time. Not only are county sides reliant on regular handouts from the ECB to prop them up, but the structure of the game has been fiddled with more times than Dermot Reeve's box. Four-day cricket, two divisions, changes in the bonus-points system - it's all been in the name of improving Team England. (Only when the members stomped and stamped and brought about the reinstatement of the B&H Cup have the counties had their way. And look how that captured the public's imagination.)

England does have to take priority over the counties, if only because international cricket attracts bigger crowds. There are those county members who would rather see their side win the Championship than England regain the Ashes, but in general most cricket lovers in this country are England fans first, and county fans second - if at all. England's pre-eminence is fine. The problem arises when they treat the counties with disdain.

Duncan Fletcher wants Gough to be raring to go on the flat tracks of Karachi and Lahore. But even if Gough did turn out for Yorkshire after the Oval Test, he would still have over a month to recuperate before England take the field in Pakistan (even then it's only a warm-up game). Besides, Gough, whose increasingly occasional appearances for God's Own County are treated like the second coming by the Leeds faithful, would obviously like to give his adoring Yorkshire public something to cheer about. What about his wishes? How long will the Western Terrace continue to roar on their hero in a Test match when he's as elusive as Lord Lucan in the county games? Come to that, how long will they continue to roar on England at all if the decision to rest Gough costs Yorkshire the title?

But there's a more important issue here. England want the county game to be a rampant breeding ground for Test cricket. But by denying Gough the chance to play for Yorkshire, they're not just missing the boat - they're falling over the quayside and performing a spectacular bellyflop as well. Because other young players in those games will miss out on facing one of England's few fast bowlers of world class (no wonder the step up to Test cricket often proves too great); and because Gough himself will miss out on playing in a win-at-all-costs situation, the sort he's likely to encounter in Test matches. If this attitude persists, county cricket will breed Test players as successfully as a nunnery breeds full stop.

This move does more than devalue the County Championship - it emasculates it and thus robs it of the last smidgin of meaning it already had. Give Gough the chance to help Yorkshire when it really matters, and in the long run, it will help England.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. To read his previous column, on the pros and pros of overseas players, click here

webTitle: How pigs, pâté and pettiness can lead to trade wars

fields.headline: How pigs, pâté and pettiness can lead to trade wars
fields.standfirst: Governments find it easy to impose tit-for-tat sanctions in the heat of the moment. But they can take years to be lifted, writes Mark Tran
fields.trailText: Governments find it easy to impose tit-for-tat sanctions in the heat of the moment. But they can take years to be lifted, writes Mark Tran.
fields.body:
Taking its cue from the EU, the US has suspended all swine shipments from Britain following an outbreak of swine fever in East Anglia.

The US agriculture department said it had concerns about the transmission of the disease to America's livestock population, but added that the hold on shipments was "temporary". Canada is imposing similar restrictions.

Although highly infectious - it can wipe out whole pig herds - swine fever is not as lethal as BSE. The virus does not affect humans or cross to other species.

But such details easily get tossed aside in the heat of the moment as nationalist feelings come to the fore. Asda, the British supermarket chain, is already threatening to ban Belgian pork pâté; a move designed to support domestic pig farmers as much as in retaliation for the EU ban.

The fear is that the EU and US ban could escalate into sanctions on pork itself. That would be a devastating blow to British farmers, picking themselves up after the scare on UK beef.

Escalation is not the only danger. Once these bans come into effect, they are not lifted easily. France is still dragging its feet on British beef, even though it has been ordered by the European commission to lift its ban. Although Lionel Jospin, the French prime minister, is inclined to let British beef back into the country, he has buckled to fierce domestic pressure to maintain the ban.

America's move on British pigs adds another layer to the already tangled web of trade disputes. The US and the EU are locked in a row over whether American exports of genetically modified foods should carry labels to that effect. Washington has warned the EU that it is considering making a formal complaint to the World Trade Organisation on the grounds that labelling GM foods is unfair discrimination and therefore a restraint of trade.

The two trading giants are still bickering over bananas, with the US complaining about Caribbean producers getting preferential treatment from Brussels. The British government fears that the Scottish cashmere industry faces heavy job losses as a result of US retaliation in the long-running dispute.

Still, Britain has so far escaped sanctions in the row over the EU ban on the use of hormones in beef, which has led to a 12-year embargo on US beef.

A range of goods, including French cheese and truffles and German and French mustards, have faced 100% US tariffs in tit-for-tat action. But Britain's support for the US position, even though it cannot opt out of the EU ban, has meant British goods have not been targeted.

The best that Britain can hope for is that its swift action in slaughtering 12,000 pigs will mean that the US ban is indeed "temporary" and that the EU will follow suit.

webTitle: Leader: Russia too proud to accept help over submarine accident

fields.headline: Help brushed aside
fields.standfirst:
Pride and caution govern Russia's response
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russia is a proud country and its leadership's refusal of all foreign help in trying to rescue the tragically disabled submarine which now lies at the bottom of the Barents Sea is eloquent proof of that. There may be technical reasons why no outside assistance could contribute, given the size of the craft's escape hatches and their incompatibility with western rescue vessels' underwater docking systems.
fields.body:
Russia is a proud country and its leadership's refusal of all foreign help in trying to rescue the tragically disabled submarine which now lies at the bottom of the Barents Sea is eloquent proof of that. There may be technical reasons why no outside assistance could contribute, given the size of the craft's escape hatches and their incompatibility with western rescue vessels' underwater docking systems. This is not the Mir space station. There are also national security reasons for Russia's decision. Its relations with the west are better than they have been for at least half a century, but naval warfare technology is still jealously guarded. That is clear from the way Nato ships and submarines were closely shadowing the manoeuvres which brought the Kursk to disaster. Manoeuvres provide a key opportunity for foreign experts to gauge a navy's potential and Russia's military chiefs are probably wary of letting outsiders get too near to the stricken boat, even if their ostensible purpose is to help.

Yet pride remains the main factor. The Kursk was the centrepiece of Russia's nuclear deterrent force. While other recent disasters in Russia have been blamed on ageing equipment or technological backwardness, this is less likely to be true for a submarine which was only commissioned five years ago. The Kursk was at the head of the line and it may well be that it was poor maintenance, low morale and lax discipline which brought disaster, rather than design faults. Nevertheless, to accept that foreigners have the wherewithal to save the submarine, while Russia does not, would amount to an admission of technical inferiority that President Putin is unwilling to make.

During the cold war there was a widespread tendency in the west to exaggerate the Soviet Union's strength. Paranoia about the enemy often overcame sound judgment. Today there may be a tendency to exaggerate Russia's weakness. Russia is a major competitor in the world's marketplace for arms and there must be a commercial temptation for western countries to try to undermine the Russian "brand" by constantly highlighting any problems of technology or obsolescence that emerge. Foreign sympathy for Russia's current difficulties can often be more feigned than genuine.

Mr Putin is enough of a realist to know this. As Russia's economy starts on a modest revival, thanks largely to a surge in oil prices, he has been trying to create a new international position for the country. In his recently published "Foreign Policy Concept" not only is the old confidence of superpower status long gone: the president does not even refer to the country as a great or major power. While advocating Russia's full integration into the world economy, he warns of a growing risk that Russia's economy and its "information environment" will depend on outside factors. The subtext is "American cultural imperialism", and France, China, and the Muslim world are other proud cultures which have similar fears. But none of this means that Mr Putin is giving up. As a permanent member of the security council, Russia can still influence the creation of a new world order, he argues, as long as its actions are based on consistency and predictability. He promises to replace ideological stereotyping with pragmatism and says Russia can have good relations with Nato in some fields, even though at other levels Nato's strategy goes against Russia's security interests. These are sentiments which command respect. The Kursk disaster is a grim accident - not a metaphor for humiliation, nor the end of Russian power.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Are the school holidays too long?
fields.trailText: The Question: Are the school holidays too long?
fields.body:
Sue Monk Chief executive of Parents at Work

Many families we talk to, with two working parents, seem to find the summer holidays too long because of childcare difficulties. Care that's OK for a couple of hours after school often isn't available or isn't adequate for several weeks. There's a lot of competition in offices for leave in the school holiday weeks, which can add to a working parent's fraught life. However, more parents are negotiating term-time working now, which would probably be harder to organise if holidays were any shorter because employers would find it difficult to arrange cover for less than six weeks.

 Verdict: Yes

Colette Kelleher Director of the Daycare Trust, child care issues organisation

I think the school holidays are about right - with the national curriculum, school timetables are very rigid these days, and it's good for children to have plenty of unstructured time in the summer to do what they want. But I feel it's a terrible shame that schools are locked up all summer and not used by the wider community. We all pay for schools, so why shouldn't we be able to use their wonderful facilities in the holidays? They could be used for drop-in activities, childcare and one-off events. Far more use could be made of them, and we'd all benefit.

 Verdict: No

Mary Coyne Mother of two children aged 11 and eight

I'd like to see the summer holidays reduced to four weeks, and the half-term holidays in summer and autumn increased to a fortnight each. Then we could choose whether to take our main holiday in May, August or October - unlike now, when we're all forced to go away for two weeks in July or August. It would bring holiday prices down and improve availability - and for many people with young children, going abroad in May or September is preferable because of the temperature. It would also remove the problem of having six or seven weeks to fill.

 Verdict: Yes

John Coe National Association of Primary Education

Education is more pressurised than ever for everyone - children, teachers and parents. The long break is more important than ever. For many primary schools the holiday has already been cut from more than six weeks to just over five, because of inset days. It's very important that teachers are properly refreshed by the break, bearing in mind that they are going to lose days at the start and end of the holidays preparing for the new term. But the break is vital for children too - they need to be away from the routine, to learn about life outside school.

 Verdict: No

fields.headline: Childish things
fields.standfirst: 16: A brief guide to car tapes
fields.trailText: 16: A brief guide to car tapes
fields.body:
Oh No! Not Another . . . Travel Songs Tape, £3.99.
From www.gltc.co.uk

As an initial "let's get into the holiday" mood-enhancer, this tape is a whole lot of fun - once. All the songs have a travelling theme: The Wheels on the Bus, Michael Row the Boat Ashore, and The Pirate Ship for starters. Sung very earnestly by a gang of adults who sound like they never got past the Playschool years.

Playing time: 40 mins

Age: 2+

Kids Rating: 7/10

Driver's Irritability Rating: 7/10

Tightrope by Gillian Cross, read by Sophie Aldred, £7.99.
From major book shops or www.amazon.co.uk

Gillian Cross is famous for the scary Demon Headmaster, and this is too frightening for very young children. By day a good girl, by night a gifted gymnast and "tagger" (a graffiti artist who sprays her ID in impossible places), Ashley is being hunted by a mysterious and dangerous person. The story will have listeners on the edges of their seats.

Playing time: 3 hrs 15 mins

Age: 9+

Kids Rating: 8/10

Driver's Irritability Rating: 2/10

I'm Telling You, They're Aliens by Jeremy Strong, read by Tony Robinson, £7.99.
From major book shops or www.puffin.co.uk

They can't stop listeners expecting a Baldrick impression at any moment by the narrator, but Jeremy Strong's stories keep them riveted. With a "little guy takes on the world" theme, copious aliens and thick adults who never believe a word the children say, this is a winner for a long journey.

Playing time: 2 hrs

Age: 6+

Kids Rating: 9/10

Driver's Irritability Rating: 3/10

Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone by JK Rowling, read by Stephen Fry, £21.99.
From all major book shops or www.tridias.co.uk

Feeling left out because you haven't read Harry Potter? Well, this is a good way to get up to speed with the playground chat. Also brilliant for any parents feeling guilty for not having read it aloud to their offspring yet. Let someone else take the strain, which Fry does brilliantly.

Playing time: 8 hrs 25 mins

Age: 5+

Kids Rating: 9/10

Driver's Irritability Rating: 1/10

Kipper Stories by Mick Inkpen, read by Dawn French, £4.99.
From major book shops or www.amazon.co.uk

Kipper is rather lovely. The stories are gentle, amusing and more-ish, with Dawn giving her all to the role. Annoyingly, one side plays three stories with music and sound effects, and the other plays the same stories without. An untaxing way to pass the time.

Playing time: 50 mins

Age: 3+

Kids Rating: 6/10

Driver's Irritability Rating: 2/10

Six Adventures of Tintin by Herge, with a cast including Leo McKern and Andrew Sachs, £8.99.
From major book shops and www.bbcshop.com

This is a fantastic dramatised version of Belgium's most famous export, with Leo McKern as the best Captain Haddock ever. Wherever you are going to in the car, you will not want to get there until you have heard the ending.

Playing time: 2 hrs 55 mins

Age: 6+

Kids Rating: 10/10

Driver's Irritability Rating: 0/10

Just William by Richmal Crompton, read by Martin Jarvis, £8.99.
From major book shops and www.bbcshop.com

Martin Jarvis might be a bit of a theatrical luvvie, but his reading of the 10 Just William stories on this tape has just the right tone to keep listeners absorbed in William and his gang. Funny, thoughtful and a thoroughly bad example for all children. They'll love it, although the lisping Violet Elizabeth might stretch parents' nerves.

Playing time: 2 hrs 30 mins

Age: 5+

Kids Rating: 8/10

Driver's Irritability Rating: 4/10

The Jungle Book by Rudyard Kipling, read by Tony Robinson, £7.99.
From major book shops or www.amazon.co.uk

fields.headline: Giving birth in America
fields.standfirst: Madonna rejected Britain's maternity wards, but are they really worse than those in the US - or just different?  Lucy Atkins reports
fields.trailText: Madonna rejected Britain's maternity wards, but are they really worse than those in the US - or just different? Lucy Atkins reports
fields.body:
Whether or not you believe the reports of Madonna's dash to the operating theatre, the displaced placenta, the emergency caesarean and so on, there is one thing we do know: she's had her baby. It's a boy, called Rocco Ritchie, and he arrived last Friday, about a month early. We also know which side of the Atlantic Rocco was born on - and it wasn't ours. Madonna, 41, went to Los Angeles to have her second baby.

"So what?" you might ask. Madge is a multimillionairess; she could afford to give birth on the moon if she wanted. But the crucial point is that Madonna, as they say in LA, has "dissed" our NHS. Just a few days before the birth, she was asked if she'd have the baby in Britain. "Come on now," she objected. "Have you been to the hospitals in England? They're old and Victorian." She added: "I like efficiency."

Many British hospitals are, indeed, "old". To an American, your average British hospital might well look alarmingly like something out of Oliver Twist. Tessa Keating, who had four of her five children in the States, says she was shocked when she first saw the British hospital where she was to give birth to her third child: "It was like something out of a black and white film, totally prehistoric." And Tessa's English.

So they're not pretty, but are they inefficient? Tessa says not, "though the British antenatal system felt impersonal, my midwife throughout the birth was a dream". In Britain you typically see your midwife or GP for monthly checkups, have a couple of routine scans at the hospital, and a midwife-led birth. After the birth you'll get midwife visits, then health visitors take over. Obstetricians tend to appear largely if things start going wrong.

In America, the system is led by obstetricians. And you have to have health insurance before you even fantasise about chucking out the contraceptives. Insurance plans are complex, expensive and what they cover varies enormously. With most, you can only register with a doctor (an "OBGYN") from the insurance company's list. And, as Karen Allen, a Seattle OBGYN, puts it: "Those with a good reputation tend to have full lists. Midwife-led births are still, in most cities, considered a little alternative."

So is it all efficient in the US? For the insured, it certainly is. Once you're in it, the system is personal and thorough, and resources are plentiful. You can, for instance, have a scan whenever you want.

Since you're going to rely on your OBGYN during the birth, a good relationship with her can be invaluable. Englishwoman Joanna Bayle had her baby, Nicholas, in New York 10 weeks ago. She says trust in her OBGYN was crucial: "Every ache or complaint I had when pregnant was met with total understanding and attentiveness. She guaranteed to be there for the birth, and stayed at the hospital for the whole 16 hours of my labour." No over-stretched British obstetric consultant could possibly make such a promise.

As for the hospital, Joanna found it "new, slick looking. I had a private room afterwards, with a phone and a TV, and after my son was born, my OBGYN posted a pic ture of us on her website so that friends and family could log on and see how we were doing."

Joanna wanted "maximum pain relief" and her anaesthetised experience was, she says, "fantastic". But for women who want a "natural" birth, US hospitals might be less wonderful.

Sarah Butterworth, another Englishwoman in New York, had her first baby by home birth in Britain. When it came to having her second, though, she was in New York. She found an OBGYN and explained how easy and quick her first home birth had been. "The doctor immediately suggested that I schedule an induction a week early because the birth might be even quicker this time and I might not make it to a hospital in time."

So while the American system can be, as Tessa puts it, "customer friendly", with plush birthing rooms, attentive doctors and - if your health plan covers it - great resources, it can also be inflexible and, given the litigious nature of American society, highly interventionist (the caesarean rate stands at around 22%).

Of course, we don't need a pop star to point out that British hospitals are under-resourced. Karlene Davis, general secretary of the Royal College of Midwives, certainly agrees that some British hospitals "badly need investment" and that midwives across the country often have to cope with "difficult circumstances". But then our system does have its benefits: not having to pay to give birth is quite handy, as is not paying £300 a month for family healthcare.

fields.headline: A second chance
fields.standfirst: When  Diana Melly, wife of jazz singer George Melly, had a baby at 17, she struggled to cope. Her son had an unhappy childhood and later died of an overdose. Now her grandchild has moved in and she's learning to be a parent all over again
fields.trailText: When Diana Melly, wife of jazz singer George Melly, had a baby at 17, she struggled to cope. Her son had an unhappy childhood and later died of an overdose. Now her grandchild has moved in and she's learning to be a parent all over again
fields.body:
I live with my husband George, who is 74, and my granddaughter Kezzie, 13. A few months ago I walked out on them both. We were all having dinner and, as usual, they were talking at me at the same time. George interrupts Kezzie because he's deaf and can't hear that she's in the middle of a story. Kezzie interrupts him when he interrupts her.

That night I stood up with a glass of wine in my hand and said: "If I leave home, you'll have to talk to each other." I went next door and introduced myself to a rather startled new neighbour. After half an hour I went back. They were both ashen-faced and very conciliatory. George had cleared the table, and Kezzie, who had got her maths books out, said: "You must always say if you're feeling upset."

My daughter Candy is a single mother, and when she decided to work for a degree we agreed that Kezzie should live with me. It's only in retrospect that I feel my own experience must have influenced me to help Candy as much as I could. I became a single mother when I was 17, and often left my baby son Patrick to cry while I worked as a waitress in the evening. I needed the money but I also hated staying in with him. I worked in one of the new coffee bars in the King's Road; it was fun. When Patrick was two, I sent him to live with my aunt in the country. I made infrequent visits. He didn't come back until I married George four years later. His muddled and unhappy early childhood contributed to his death of a heroin overdose when he was 25.

Today I'm lucky: I have enough money for saxophone lessons, holidays and books; I have a nice house, a cottage in the country and a softy for a husband. More importantly, I now have time and patience. When I married George I had neither.

Being a grandmother seems much easier than being a mother. There are none of those frantic evenings trying to get dressed glamorously while helping with the homework, sorting out a quarrel and searching for the gym kit. During the 1960s, when I had three children, I felt torn in so many directions and I was always tired. Nowadays, I don't much care what I look like: I sleep in a T-shirt, and spend the day in my pinny.

My social life is dictated by having to get up early for the school run. I wouldn't leave Kezzie alone in the evening with only Latin homework and a fishfinger for company. I don't know how she feels about living with me, as opposed to living with Candy; I don't think she would like to be asked. One of her many qualities is loyalty: to me and to Candy. For her to admit to a preference either way would put her on the spot, but she certainly appreciates that her school is nearby and that therefore her friends are too. Also, Candy has a full-time job and gets home long after school finishes.

Most weekends she spends with Candy; when I say: "You're going to Mum's this weekend," she says: "Oh, good." If I tell her she's staying with me, at least she doesn't pull a face as if she's been given an aubergine to eat. She isn't given the chance to play us off against each other. Candy and I are not a separated, quarrelling couple but mother and daughter, sharing her care. Candy often comes to my house for the night and we tell each other if there have been problems. We have a united front in the face of teenage demands. I wouldn't ring Candy at work with a long moan, and I have my ways of dealing with misdemeanours, such as when Kezzie does not get enough homework done because of watching too much TV. I have tried to be more easy-going than I was 35 years ago: sulks are best ignored; if tempers have been lost, we are better off in different rooms; and if she has been impossible I simply withdraw my friendship.

But at 13 the hormones are buzzing; school is hard work, friendships are volatile. Also adolescents get depressed; these days I don't, so I have the advantage.

Kezzie is also very loyal about George - but then she's always on the side of the underdog. She's the only one who hears me being snappy with him and will accuse me of shouting at him or not letting him win an argument. I point out that the "wing-co" as George calls me, is always right, and that shouting when the hearing-aid battery has faded is a necessity.

She's quite proud of him, telling children to "come and see my grandad. He's very famous and he has got psoriasis." Now that she is older they are finding things in common - not art, she dreads a lecture on that, but they both love horror stories, Buffy the Vampire Slayer and dirty jokes.

George is not the only man in Kezzie's life: she has Uncle Tom, who took her to Disneyland Paris and failed to teach her maths; his son Django, the only small child she's ever liked; Candy's partner Mark, who plays video games with her; and most importantly, Bradley, her best friend and the boy next door. He's two years older and better than a brother: he fixes her computer, finds her shoes and never interrupts.

What Kezzie and I share is a liking for a good story. She likes to know the plot of what I'm reading, and when she eventually reads Daniel Deronda, Framley Parsonage or The Woman in White, they will seem very familiar.

I know how lucky I am. I love her company, I gave up smoking because of her and I think through her I was given another chance.

webTitle: The fate of six flawed embryos

fields.headline: The fate of six flawed embryos
fields.standfirst: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.trailText: Trying: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.body:
There were eight fertilised embryos sitting in eight little dishes. The cytogeneticist showed us their photographs - enough for any family album, except these black and grey forms had nothing discernibly human about them. An amoeba would have looked more engaging. One was clearly oblong. This was alarming. I envisaged a child with a long rectangular head, square eyes, diamond-shaped nostrils and a mouth with a little pointy, cornered smile, like a pixie. But then it was rather early to be envisaging any child at all. These embryos were the size of a pinprick, just eight cells - seven now that one had been removed to test for my genetic condition. They'd been sitting in the dishes for five days.

It was the morning of my embryo transfer, when any unaffected embryos would be put into my womb. The cytogeneticist showed us the result of the tests on each extracted cell. Of the eight, only two were shown to be clear of my genetic condition. The doctor recommended that both of these were transferred. That left the question of what should happen to the remaining six, doomed to early death due to their genetic flaws. I signed a bank of forms to give permission for them to be examined, dissected and dosed with whatever scientists wish to dose them with.

At present, there are very strict limits on that research. Infertility, reproduction and congenital diseases are the only permissible areas of investigation. But all that will soon change. Today, the chief medical officer's cloning report is published, recommending that therapeutic cloning be allowed on such embryos for the first time. An outcry is predicted.

The word cloning itself is extremely scary. And there are objections from the religious and the right that this is somehow sacrificing one human life for another. But in all this furore, there is one voice missing: mine. The majority of embryos for research come from people like me, as the unwanted by-products of infertility treatment.

Without the infertile, the debate about embryo research would be merely academic. There would be hardly any embryo research at all.

The "stem cells" in embryos up to 14 days old are capable of becoming almost anything. They could, in theory, be developed into skin, lungs or kidneys. The potential for medical advances is obvious. No one disputes that it could lead to cures for many diseases, from Huntington's chorea to cancer. The debate is over whether or not it is moral.

I don't think of my embryos as in any way human. But I do think of them as potentially human, each a promise of a life. And I regard my rare ability to donate a part of my body to science with similar sorrow, perhaps, to that of a family donating a relative's kidney, heart or eyes. I wish it wasn't like this. But given that it is, some good should come out of it. If a family has a close member die, it is their right to decide whether any organs are donated. I regard my decision on my spare embryos in the same way. They will die. I can donate some of them to further science that will save the lives of others. Is it morally better to throw away my six spares into a sterile bin?

I nfertility treatment will always produce "spares". It is deliberately designed that way, to maximise the chances of conception. If only two embryos were cultivated in the dish, then the chance that both would be good enough to transfer would be slim, and the chance of pregnancy even slimmer. To object to the use of my embryos for research and therapeutic cloning is, in essence, to be against infertility treatment itself.

My two unaffected embryos - one of them oblong - were prepared for insertion. The doctor tried to get my boyfriend and me to hold hands as he pushed in the impossibly long, narrow tube along which they would travel to my womb. But despite the doctor's repeated attempts to make us demonstrate affection, neither of us did. As long as we kept this on a medical level, we could cope.

If we thought of it as anything else - as an intimate moment - those stirrups, the long tube and that scanning machine would become unbearable encumbrances. How did we end up here, like this?

There is little that is positive about being infertile, but the possibility that the embryonic by-products might help to cure disease is a compensation. I hope those six embryos will help steps towards providing a prolonged and healthy life to others. And I hope the two transferred embryos - their biological brothers and sisters - may bring joy to me.

leahwild@cswebmail.com

But I do think of them as potentially human, each a promise of a life. And I regard my rare ability to donate a part of my body to science with similar sorrow, perhaps, to that of a family donating a relative's kidney, heart or eyes. I wish it wasn't like this. But given that it is, some good should come out of it. If a family has a close member die, it is their right to decide whether any organs are donated. I regard my decision on my spare embryos in the same way. They will die. I can donate some of them to further science that will save the lives of others. Is it morally better to throw away my six spares into a sterile bin? I nfertility treatment will always produce "spares". It is deliberately designed that way, to maximise the chances of conception. If only two embryos were cultivated in the dish, then the chance that both would be good enough to transfer would be slim, and the chance of pregnancy even slimmer. To object to the use of my embryos for research and therapeutic cloning is, in essence, to be against infertility treatment itself. My two unaffected embryos - one of them oblong - were prepared for insertion. The doctor tried to get my boyfriend and me to hold hands as he pushed in the impossibly long, narrow tube along which they would travel to my womb. But despite the doctor's repeated attempts to make us demonstrate affection, neither of us did. As long as we kept this on a medical level, we could cope. If we thought of it as anything else - as an intimate moment - those stirrups, the long tube and that scanning machine would become unbearable encumbrances. How did we end up here, like this? There is little that is positive about being infertile, but the possibility that the embryonic by-products might help to cure disease is a compensation. I hope those six embryos will help steps towards providing a prolonged and healthy life to others. And I hope the two transferred embryos - their biological brothers and sisters - may bring joy to me. leahwild@cswebmail.com

fields.headline: For the child's sake
fields.standfirst: In yesterday's Guardian poll, 64% of those questioned said unhappy parents should split up. But what's best for the children, asks  Adrienne Katz
fields.trailText: In yesterday's Guardian poll, 64% of those questioned said unhappy parents should split up. But what's best for the children, asks Adrienne Katz
fields.body:
Having two homes is like putting your life in a couple of carrier bags every week," says Selina, 16, whose parents have split up. But in the swirling debate about whether parents should stick together for the sake of the children, young people like Selina hardly get a look in.

The "experts", like the parents, are divided into two warring camps. There are those who argue, based on a large body of research, that conflict in the home is harmful. On the other hand, based on equally valid evidence, there are those who say responsible adults should "think of the children" and keep on working at their relationship.

The truth, as usual, is more complex. With so much attention focused on the breakdown of the traditional family, the issue of how good a job parents are doing is often overlooked. How well are they handling the split? What arrangements have they made for the children? Is their depression affecting their parenting?

One recent study suggested "the absence of a parent figure is not the most influential feature of separation for children's development". The authors pointed out that separation is part of a process beginning long before the split itself and continuing long after. For a minority there are greater risks than for those in intact families, but communication, contact, reassurance and stability will limit long-term difficulties.

Indeed living for years in what Will Self has described as "the standard from-Woolworths unhappy family" can affect children more than the split itself. Although Bobby is only eight years old he agrees: "It was good when they splitted up because they used to argue a lot... It's better now, lots better." It's better too for the large number of mothers who want to remove their children from domestic violence.

Some of the most recent research has at last begun to focus on the child's experience and feelings, as opposed to simply assessing the "outcome". What's interesting is that children actually seldom seem to care what form their family takes and whether or not there are pieces of paper holding it together. Hope, 14, insists: "My family just is. It's different from other people's families, but I don't mind because who says what a family should be like?"

Hope, Bobby and Selina (not their real names) have all been interviewed as part of a post-divorce childhood study at Leeds University. "It is generally believed that children are harmed by divorce," says co-author Bren Neale, "but there is limited evidence on whether children themselves feel harmed." She adds that we know little about children's views on family decision-making or whether they want to take part in legal proceedings. Would being consulted and not excluded from the process help some young people to feel less isolated in the chaos?

Ursula 19, says: "The children should get a say and the parents should be able to sort things out for everyone - they should be able to act like adults about it really."

To help us act like adults, the authors of the Leeds study have produced a book for children and parents. In it, children shed light on how they have coped with the difficulties of being integrated into a "new" family. This is the human side of the statistics which tell us how many fathers lose contact with their children within two years of a split, or how many lone mums have various men wandering in and out of the household. Here, laid bare, is the pain, the struggle to adjust and the sometimes callous treatment of the child. For some, the situation turns out as an acceptable compromise. "Before they broke up mum always seemed tense and dad never smiled," says David, 15. "I was a bit upset at first but you learn to live with it. When I look back it's probably the best thing for us, and the way we live now is fine. It makes no difference really."

Others are less happy. "I haven't seen dad this past year, but I have talked to him on the phone," says Don, five. "He's got to do a lot of travelling and his exhaust pipe falls off and then he can't come. He writed today and sent me a book. I'm glad when I see him 'cos, well he hugs and kisses me and then I jump on him and we do something fun, like go swimming."

Some parents handle things pretty insensitively. One teenager says: "I remember when dad first picked me up from the train and his new girlfriend was with him, and he said: 'Oh you know Sylvie don't you?' And I said: 'No,' and I felt shocked and upset 'cos he hadn't warned me she was going to be there. Then we were going out one day with her and her children and he said: 'It'll be like a family outing,' and I went: 'No it won't.' It felt as though he was rejecting us as a family although he didn't mean that."

There are children who have to become their parents' parent, or remain the go-between in rows. But Elizabeth, nine, says: "I like it how it is. If I said I wanted my mum and dad to get back together then we wouldn't have Sam or Rod [the step-parents] and we wouldn't have Ronan, or Jane or Jacob [new brothers and sisters]."

 Parent Problems by Bren Neale and Amanda Wade, priced £9 including post and packaging, is available from Young Voice, 12 Bridge Gardens, East Molesey, Surrey KT8 9HU.
