webTitle: Stranded sub: Russians accept British offer of help

fields.headline: Stranded sub: Russians accept British offer of help
fields.standfirst: 'No signs of life' from stricken vessel
fields.trailText: The Russian navy today accepted an offer of British help to rescue more than 100 sailors on board the grounded nuclear submarine, Kursk, amid reports that signs of life are no longer being heard from the stricken vessel.
fields.body:
The Russian navy today accepted an offer of British help to rescue more than 100 sailors on board the grounded nuclear submarine, Kursk, amid reports that signs of life are no longer being heard from the stricken vessel.

Commander Admiral Vladimir Kuroyedov said: "Rescue equipment and experts from the British Navy will be used to rescue the crew of the Kursk."

Britain has already sent rescue equipment to the Norwegian port of Trondheim. in readiness to attend the submarine which has sunk in 350ft of water in the Barents Sea.

Russian navy commander Admiral Vladimir Kuroyedov said today that Moscow would make use of British help. "Rescue equipment and experts from the British Navy will be used to rescue the crew of the Kursk."

Previously Russia had not accepted offers of help, although officials denied they had refused assistance.

Deputy prime minister Ilya Klebanov, in charge of the investigation of the accident, was earlier quoted by Russian news agencies as saying the crew were no longer showing signs of life, although this did not mean they were dead.

President Vladimir Putin was quoted as saying the submarine's situation was "critical" and that everything was being done to try to reach the Kursk. . As Russia's own rescue operation continued, conditions on the sea floor were very bad with rescuers able to see just a few inches through the muddy water even though they had searchlights.

"Sand and silt envelop the capsule causing zero visibility," said a navy officer, who did not wish to be named.

A rescue capsule was almost lost during the operation because of the strong currents and bad weather, said navy spokesman Igor Dygalo.

The rescue work was very dangerous, he said. The navy was determined to continue the rescue effort, but the weather in the Barents Sea was deteriorating with high winds and waves buffeting rescue ships. About 20 ships were taking part in the operation.

webTitle: Government approves plans to relax human cloning

fields.headline: Government approves plans to relax human cloning
fields.trailText: The government has today approved plans to clone embryo cells into human tissue for the treatment of currently incurable diseases. If they are adopted, the law on human cloning will be relaxed to allow scientists to take cells from young embryos and use them to grow skin and other tissue, which may help find cures for many diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and cystic fibrosis.
fields.body:
The government has today approved plans to clone embryo cells into human tissue for the treatment of currently incurable diseases. If they are adopted, the law on human cloning will be relaxed to allow scientists to take cells from young embryos and use them to grow skin and other tissue, which may help find cures for many diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and cystic fibrosis.

Ministers have endorsed the report by the Chief Medical Officer, Professor Liam Donaldson, on the issue of human embryo cloning, although MPs will decide on the proposals in a free vote later this year.

However, the new legislation will ban human cloning for reproductive purposes, ensuring scientists can never clone a whole baby.

The plans will allow all-purpose "stem cells," from which all embryos first develop, to be taken from human embryos under 14 days old and used in medical research.

Such research would necessarily involve cloning human cells to make embryos, which would be used to harvest healthy tissue to treat degenerative diseases. It is this aspect of the research which has today provoked controversy amongst religious and pro-life groups in the UK. Religious groups which believe any embryo is a human life are fiercely opposed to any relaxation of the law.

However, under the 1990 Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act, embryos of up to 14 days old can already be used for research into specific areas such as fertility, contraception, miscarriage and congenital disorders. The use of young embryos, many of which never fully develop, is an integral part of the long-accepted fertility treatment of IVF. Shadow Health Secretary Dr Liam Fox said that he intended "on principle" to vote against any relaxation of the rules. "There is genuine and deep-rooted political unease about many of the medical techniques we can now employ," he said.

At present there is no law expressly forbidding human cloning using the technique which produced Dolly the sheep, because such advances were not envisaged when the legislation was drafted. In practice, the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority would never grant permission for reproductive human cloning.

However, the Government's plans will prevent any possibility of such work taking place. The new law will make it illegal to produce an embryo clone and plant it into a woman's womb.

Embryonic stem cells can develop into any kind of tissue in the body, including nerves, muscle, organs and bone, depending on which chemical signals they are given. Stem cells may be used in the future to make replacement tissue, which would revolutionise the treatment of burns, degenerative conditions such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's disease, and spinal injuries.

Such therapeutic cloning also offers the possibility of overcoming the problem of transplant tissue rejection. An embryo cloned from a patient would yield stem cells which could be used to grow tissue compatible with the patient.

In December 1998 two advisory bodies, the Human Genetics Advisory Commission and the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority, recommended that the law should be relaxed to allow the use of early-stage human embryos for stem cell research.

The Medical Research Council today welcomed the recommendations in the report. Dr Diana Dunstan, the MRC's director of research management, said: "We welcome the report's recommendation that stem cell therapy and cell nuclear replacement should be permitted under strict legal controls, enforcing clear ethical principles.

"While growing whole organs for transplantation may be many decades away, the production of human nerve cells to treat people with Parkinson's and Huntington's disease could be an early benefit of this type of research."

Professor Liam Donaldson said: "Stem cell research... offers enormous potential for new treatments of chronic diseases and injuries, and the relief of human suffering.

"Our report offers a way to ensure that this potential can be fully explored, whilst ensuring full and rigorous safeguards. In particular reproductive cloning - the cloning of individuals - will remain banned in the UK."

A spokesman for the charity Life, which is strongly opposed to abortion and cloning, pointed to new research where stem cells had been taken from adults: "We do not need human cloning. We are on the brink of a major revolution in medicine using adult stem cells and exploring another recent discovery, namely that differentiated adult cells are capable of adaptation and mutation.

"Therapeutic cloning means killing. It is a further trivialisation of human life. It exploits human beings at the most vulnerable stage of their lives - it is neo-cannibalism."

fields.headline: Shipman patient was unlawfully killed
fields.trailText: A verdict of unlawful killing was today recorded on Sarah Ashworth, 74, who died while being treated by convicted murderer Harold Shipman.
fields.body:
A verdict of unlawful killing was today recorded on Sarah Ashworth, 74, who died while being treated by convicted murderer Harold Shipman.

The South Manchester coroner, John Pollard, recorded the verdict after hearing that traces of morphine were found in Ashworth's body. But the pathologist, John Rutherford, said there was insufficient evidence to prove how the 74-year-old widow died.

Ashworth, of Hyde, Greater Manchester, died in April 1993. She was one of 12 patients of the GP to be exhumed during the investigation into his crimes. Shipman, 54, now serving life for 15 murders, had certified her death as being caused by heart failure.

At Tameside magistrates court in Ashton-under-Lyne, Dr Rutherford told the coroner that he could not exclude natural causes, but said that morphine poisoning remained a "reasonable alternative explanation". Because of the state of the exhumed body it was impossible to carry out sufficient analysis. But he said Ashworth's history of respiratory problems would cause a doctor to use "extreme caution" before giving such a drug, which would further slow down breathing.

The inquest heard that Shipman had called on Ashworth she allegedly telephoned his surgery complaining of breathing difficulties. Shipman withdrew 30mg of diamorphine in Ashworth's name from a pharmacy on the day of her death - more than six times the recommended maximum dose.

Asked if, as a doctor, he would take diamorphine on such a visit, Dr Rutherford said: "There would be no reason for me to take diamorphine with me, either then or in today's practices."

Dr Rutherford said it was "very surprising" and "unlikely" that Ashworth died of the type of heart failure that Shipman had recorded on her death certificate. Had Shipman administered the 30mg of morphine he had collected from the pharmacy on the day of Ashworth's death, it would very probably have been fatal. But Dr Rutherford said he could not say with certainty that morphine toxicity had killed Ashworth. Forensic scientist Julie Evans, who examined three samples taken from Ashworth, found possible traces of morphine in initial tests, but further tests proved inconclusive.

She said she was breaking new ground in examining a body which was so decomposed. "It was possible that there were large quantities of the drug in Mrs Ashworth's body when she died, but it may have broken down during the five years between death and postmortem examination," she said.

She added: "Morphine or the breakdown of morphine was present. There is insufficient research to say beyond doubt that this was morphine."

fields.headline: The Concorde crash
fields.standfirst: Concorde has been grounded less than a month after the crash near Paris which killed 113 people. Keith Perry explains what this means for the future of the supersonic jet
fields.trailText: Concorde has been grounded less than a month after the crash near Paris which killed 113 people. We explain what this means for the future of the supersonic jet.
fields.body:
What caused the Concorde to crash?
Air crash investigators have revealed that a burst tyre caused the Air France Concorde flight AF4590 to crash on July 25 on to a hotel north of Paris, killing all 109 passengers and crew and four people on the ground.

How could a burst tyre lead to such a disaster?
The plane is thought to have struck a shard of metal lying on the runway. At least one fuel tank was ruptured, leading to a major fuel leak. The leaking fuel ignited, leading to an intense fire. Two engines lost thrust. The crew, unaware of where the fire was or how it started, could not contain it.

What does this mean for future flights?
Since the burst tyre was "the primary cause of the accident" and that there was no guarantee this would not occur again, British Airways and Air France have grounded their fleets of Concorde and the plane's airworthiness certificate has been withdrawn while the Civil Aviation Authority investigates Concorde's tyre problems.

Is it all over for Concorde?
The Anglo-French manufacturers of the plane, together with the French civil aviation authority, will now put together an action plan to ensure that any future burst tyres would not imply such a high level of risk. British Airways does not know how long this will take.

Has problem arisen before?
Concorde pilots have long complained about burst tyres. Records from the US national transportation safety board list a number of incidents, including one particularly serious blow-out in June 1979. The problem became so acute that BA installed an alarm system on the cramped Concorde flight deck to alert pilots.

Can Concorde be made safer?
It could be months rather than weeks before the necessary modifications could be made to enable Concorde to fly again. The CAA's design and production standards division said the work will probably have to be done after investigators complete the reconstruction of the fuel-tank area and a section of wing from the crashed Concorde. The CAA will hold a series of meetings with the British manufacturers of Concorde - BAE Systems - to develop modifications. The CAA will decide whether each of the seven BA Concordes can regain its operating certificate. The modifications could also be prohibitively costly.

Should Concordes have still been flying?
BA maintains that there was no reason why Concorde, which first flew in 1969, should not carry on in service well into the 21st century. Although travelling at vast speeds, the supersonic jets have not endured the tremendous workload of some of the hardworking subsonic aircraft such as the early Airbus aircraft and various Boeings including the jumbo jet, the Boeing 747.

Have any other aircraft ever been grounded?
US authorities temporarily grounded the DC-10 in 1979. Britain's de Havilland Comet was permanently stopped from flying 50 years ago.

Is Concorde worth keeping?
Concorde's four Rolls-Royce engines guzzle 5,638 gallons of fuel an hour. Its heavy fuel consumption, coupled with small tanks, meant that Concorde was unable enter the increasingly lucrative trans-Pacific market. BA says its fleet turns a profit. The standard fare for a return trip from London to New York is £6,636.

Aside from heavy fuel consumption, Concorde flies much higher than normal jets and the nitrogen oxide expelled from its engines contributes to the destruction of the ozone layer. Concorde is much noisier than other aircraft, and has a special exemption from noise pollution guidelines. Any successor to Concorde would have to meet today's more exacting environmental standards.

fields.headline: Liverpool
fields.trailText: Back in 1990, Maggie Thatcher was still in power; Betty Boo was Doin' The Do; and Liverpool were marching imperiously to their 18th League title. They had been the team of the 70s and 80s - and looked almost certain to be the team of the 90s too.
fields.body:
Back in 1990, Maggie Thatcher was still in power; Betty Boo was Doin' The Do; and Liverpool were marching imperiously to their 18th League title. They had been the team of the 70s and 80s - and looked almost certain to be the team of the 90s too.

But that was then, and this is now. In the past decade Manchester United have become like the old Liverpool - hegemonic and hated - while Liverpool have become a big club, with equally big names but with very little to show for it. Remind you of anyone pre-1990?

Yet this year the old order could be restored. Money has been spent, Michael Owen is injury-free, and Parma have been defeated 5-0 in pre-season. No wonder Anfield expects - and this time Liverpool might just deliver.

The good signs are everywhere. Last season Gerald Houllier's side had the meanest defence in the Premiership, and with Markus Babbel signed up and Christian Ziege almost certainly on his way, it should be even stronger. With Owen back, Fowler on his way, and Emile Heskey on hand to cause trouble in the attacking third (if not actually score), the Reds should not have to turn to Eirk Meijer too often in the hunt for goals. What's more, in Steven Gerrard, they have their first true box-to-box midfielder for some time.

Yet there are still some nagging doubts about Gerald Houllier's side. As their puzzling dip at the back end of last season highlighted, they lack width. And if teams sit back against them - as they increasingly do - you can't see any of the current wide men taking on their marker and getting a cross in.

Take a look at the candidates: Diomede seems is the most likely contender for the job - but he didn't impress at all in the World Cup. Barmby can also play on the left, but he is right footed and his best position is probably behind the front two or on the right. And Smicer (who certainly has the skill to come good, but his tendency to pick up injuries and his frailty don't help) and Berger aren't natural wide men either. That's why signing Ziege - who can make overlapping runs for fun - could be so important.

But that's probably Liverpool's only weakness. Expect them to come close - and maybe just nick it. But Manchester United will be mighty tough to dethrone.

In Pegguy Arphexad (Leicester), Markus Babbel (Bayern Munich), Bernard Diomede (Auxerre), Gary McAllister (Coventry), Nick Barmby (Everton), Robbie Shields (Tallaght).

Out Phil Babb (Sporting), Stig-Inge Bjornebye (Blackburn), David Thompson (Coventry).

Odds 11-2

Football Unlimited writers' prediction 2nd

fields.headline: Manchester City
fields.trailText: When Manchester City won promotion in May, Joe Royle announced that: "The Premiership needs Manchester City as much as Manchester City needs the Premiership." Well if the Premiership needs another team built on strength and aggression, sprinkled with a smattering of sporadic skill, as much as Man City needs one of the world's richest leagues then I'd say Uncle Joe has got it just about right.
fields.body:
When Manchester City won promotion in May, Joe Royle announced that: "The Premiership needs Manchester City as much as Manchester City needs the Premiership." Well if the Premiership needs another team built on strength and aggression, sprinkled with a smattering of sporadic skill, as much as Man City needs one of the world's richest leagues then I'd say Uncle Joe has got it just about right.

Of course, I am exaggerating a little bit for effect. But amidst all the sentimentalising that surrounds City, their hordes of loyal fans, and their return to the big time, it's worth remembering that this particular side is unlikely to produce much in the way of fantasy football. Their success last term was built on the reflexes of Nicky Weaver, the hard tackling of Gerard Wiekens, the industry of Kevin Horlock and the extremities of Shaun Goater. Only the wing play of Mark Kennedy really offered something out of the ordinary, and the Republic of Ireland international is likely to stand out less in the Premiership (he has been there before, you remember).

But the quality of football is unlikely to trouble most City fans this season, as long as the club does the decent thing and stays up. And that, in this pundit's worthless opinion, they will do. Joe Royle has kept smaller clubs than City (namely Oldham) in the top flight before, and his teams are usually too well organised to start throwing away the sort of points that, say, Sheffield Wednesday did last season. And while his squad is still threadbare by Premiership standards, Royle's close season signings - Wanchope, Weah and Howey - all have a ring of quality about them.

All in all, it should be a season of consolidation for City, perhaps even punctuated by the odd derby point or six. And I back Goater's arse to get on the scoresheet on more than the odd occasion too.

In: George Weah (AC Milan), Paulo Wanchope (West Ham), Steve Howey (Newcastle).

Out: Craig Russell (St Johnstone), Lee Peacock (Bristol City), Jamie Pollock (Crystal Palace), Robert Taylor (Wolves).

Odds: 350-1

Football Unlimited writer's prediction: 16th

fields.headline: Whingeing
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about moaning Minnies, and why they are psychologically   better off than cheerful Charlies.
fields.trailText: 1. The American Psychological Association, in its annual conference, has heard that forced cheerfulness can be bad for you.
fields.body:
1. The American Psychological Association, in its annual conference, has heard that forced cheerfulness can be bad for you.

2. Dr Barbara Held told the shrinks that "if you are having a hard time it can make it harder to cope if you feel pressure to act okay when you are not".

3. Dr Held is the Barry N Wish professor of psychology and social studies at Bowdoin College, Maine, and is clearly a specialist in what laymen call the No Shit, Sherlock approach to academic research.

4. She has written an entire book on why whingeing can be good for you. It's called Stop Smiling, Start Kvetching. It's still available, as is a T-shirt bearing the same mantra.

5. 'Kvetch' is an excellent Yiddish word which means, erm, whingeing.

6. It has been adopted, to great effect, by the US Complainers and Moaners Society.

7. Americans are much better at whingeing than anybody else. They specialise in really obscure complaints.

8. The Brits are also noted for grizzling, but are less stylish.

9. Back to Dr Held: Her thesis in praise of pouting was backed up by fellow academic Julie Norem, of Wellesley College in Massachusetts. A few years back she wrote a snappy little number entitled 'Reflection and Distraction: Defensive Pessimism, Strategic Optimism and Performance". Basically, her case is that if you set your sights low enough, you always succeed.

10. These thoughts about whingeing are provoked by a piece in the Daily Telegraph, which was inspired by the New York Times', report on the APA conference of more than a week ago. Dear oh dear. You call that news? I ask you.

webTitle: Russia launches mission to save sub

fields.headline: Russia launches mission to save sub
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
Bellona - Nuclear Russia
fields.trailText: Nearly four days after the Russian nuclear submarine  Kursk sank to the bottom of the Barents sea, in the  worst naval accident in more than a decade, Russia  last night launched a rescue mission in an attempt to  save 116 crewmen running short of oxygen aboard the  stricken vessel.
fields.body:
Nearly four days after the Russian nuclear submarine Kursk sank to the bottom of the Barents sea, in the worst naval accident in more than a decade, Russia last night launched a rescue mission in an attempt to save 116 crewmen running short of oxygen aboard the stricken vessel.

Battling against rough seas and strong currents, the Russian navy said it had lowered a manned escape capsule to the sunken submarine, the first time that rescuers were anywhere near the submarine.

There was no immediate word that the capsule had made contact with the Kursk. The navy said visibility near the sub was two to five metres and there were strong underwater currents.

The rescuers repeatedly tried to lower the escape apparatus, but their attempts were frustrated by the stormy conditions, Russian officials said.

Moscow also appeared to have relented on its refusal to ask for outside assistance. Russia has previously refused offers from the US and Britain to send trained rescue personnel and equipment, even though the Russian navy lacks sophisticated rescue gear.

A navy spokesman, Captain Igor Dygalo, said yesterday that coordinating the rescue with other countries would take too much time.

But last night Russian military personnel met Nato officials for half an hour to discuss the accident. A Nato source said the Russians had asked what assistance Nato could provide, but no formal request for help had been made.

During the meeting the Russian representatives also spoke via teleconference with alliance naval experts in Northwood, the headquarters of Nato's naval command for the eastern Atlantic. The source said the meeting had been initiated by the Russians.

Some 15 miles off Russia's northern coast, the surface rescue ship, Rudnitsky, was last night said to be at the site of the sinking in the Barents sea. From the ship the rescue capsule was lowered 350ft to try to evacuate the crew via the main escape hatch, situated on top of the vessel's stern.

Russia's navy chief, Admiral Vladimir Kuroyedov, reported to President Vladimir Putin that the chances of a successful operation were slim, because of the windy conditions and treacherous currents underwater.

"Our hopes are receding daily," Admiral Kuroyedov said last night. "Experts believe the submarine will run out of oxygen before August 18. We must act fast... The only certainty is that people inside the submarine are alive and sending SOS signals."

But information from the navy, the defence ministry, and the Russian government has been contradictory. Last night sources in the Russian navy said the accident had taken place on Saturday, a day earlier than previous official accounts indicated.

The cause of the sinking of the Oscar-II class nuclear-powered submarine, while taking part in northern fleet war games, remained unclear.

"We haven't the slightest clue as to what could have caused the accident," said Igor Baranov, one of the submarine's designers.

Navy officers and government officials said three main causes were being considered: that the submarine had hit an old mine from the second world war; that it had collided with another vessel, perhaps a foreign surveillance craft; or that there had been an accident on board while firing torpedoes, which caused the front of the vessel to take on water.

Navy headquarters last night said the latest evidence from the site supported the notion that there had been a huge explosion on board, perhaps caused by torpedoes which failed to fire and instead blew up the nose of the vessel.

Admiral Kuroyedov spoke of an internal explosion, a blast outside the hull or a crash.

Reconnaissance photographs showed that the submarine's missile silo cover had been blown off, the conning tower dented, and material from the vessel scattered across the seabed.

Some experts said the crew could survive until Friday. Mr Baranov, the designer, said the 116 men had only two days. Other navy sources compounded the confusion by saying said there was an emergency oxygen system "capable of long-term functioning without power supplies", but a northern fleet spokesman said oxygen on the Kursk was running out.

Valentina Starotseltseva, the mother of one of the 116 crewmen, said: "The information is not adequate. The whole family is just sitting in front of the TV for the second day.

"We don't understand why they're not saving our children."

Relatives of most of the crew were taken to the northern navy base of Severomorsk where they were confined to a navy hospital ship.

Dmitry Lachkov, a naval cadet whose father, Gennady, is the northern fleet captain commanding the submarine, said: "We've only one wish, that this all ends well as soon as possible."

Alexander Nikitin, a former St Petersburg navy officer and military analyst, said the capsule being used in last night's rescue attempt dated from the early 1980s. He noted that a similar operation to evacuate crew from a stricken sub in the far east in 1983 had resulted in most of the sailors' deaths.

The Russians are said to have 11 such rescue vessels, all ageing, each capable of carrying 20 men. The capsules resemble mini-submarines equipped with special lighting and video equipment.

"Everything depends on the weather," Admiral Kuroyedov said. Winds at gale force five or six raged for most of yesterday in the Barents sea, shifting the crippled submarine on the seabed and scattering most of the surface ships involved in the rescue mission.

Each of the capsule descents and rescue missions would take some seven hours and would need to be repeated six times to save the entire crew.

Last night Admiral Kuroyedov was quoted as saying that if the escape capsules could not bring the crew to the surface, the navy would try to lift the crippled submarine from the seabed with inflatable pontoons.

Last-minute preparations were being made last night to send a British submersible to the aid of the submarine crew.

The British government has chartered an aircraft, which is due to arrive at Prestwick airport in Scotland this morning to pick up the submersible.

"The offer was made yesterday and we are waiting to see if the Russians respond," a Ministry of Defence spokesman said.

webTitle: Comment: Putin's stock may sink with the fleet

fields.headline: Putin's stock may sink with the fleet
fields.standfirst:
Plans to show off the Russian navy may have to be shelved

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: If it has been a good year for Vladimir Putin, it has been an extremely bad week for the Russian president.
fields.body:
If it has been a good year for Vladimir Putin, it has been an extremely bad week for the Russian president. Putin's claim to the affections and the votes of a majority of Russians lies in his promise of being his country's new strongman - not flinching from brutally putting down the Chechen insurgency, restoring law and order to the streets of Russia's cities, rebuilding the former superpower's military might and projecting that muscle overseas.

The bomb and the boat have spoiled the party. A bomb blast a week ago killing 12 and maiming dozens in the very centre of Moscow came on the eve of Putin's prime ministerial birthday, marring the congratulatory mood. Sunday's nuclear submarine disaster in the Arctic was a huge setback for the president, since the northern fleet's manoeuvres at the weekend were a prelude to a major exercise in power projection planned by Putin for later this year - the return of the Russian navy to the Mediterranean for the first time since the Soviet military heyday.

In between the two tragedies, in the Kremlin last Friday night, Putin refereed a four-hour power struggle between his two top military officials, ordering the top brass to mend their fences and turn their sights on a decade of ambitious military reform.

The challenge is daunting. Putin is aware that his inheritance from the Soviet collapse and the decade of revolutionary turmoil under Boris Yeltsin is a Russia that is now a third-rate military power, albeit nuclear-armed. For the second time in five years, the vast Russian army is proving incapable of pacifying the Chechens. The bomb in Moscow, blamed on Chechen "terrorists", shifts the war from the periphery to Russia's core and gives the lie to Putin's pledges of stability and security where it hurts most, on the streets of the capital.

A cursory inspection of the troops in Chechnya reveals the chronic condition of the Russian army, while the drama now being played out at the other end of the country, at the bottom of the Barents sea, highlights the dismal state of affairs in the navy. A fortnight ago the navy chief, Admiral Vladimir Kuroyedov, expounded his grandiose vision of increasing Russian naval might, his claim to a bigger share of the shrunken defence budget. In April the president went up to the northern fleet's headquarters and paraded with the sailors for some morale-boosting TV footage.

Away from the cameras, however, the reality for the Arctic sailors is as grim as it gets. On paper the northern fleet has 42 nuclear-powered submarines, including seven like the Kursk, which is now probably irretrievably lost. But there is no money for fuel, there are rarely emergency generators on board the subs (a factor that may have contributed to the current sinking), and at least 70% of the fleet is in need of repairs.

The northern fleet's five bases along the Kola Peninsula bordering Norway are littered with the toxic, rusting carcasses of up to 100 nuclear submarines, according to Norwegian environmentalists. Only three of the fleet's submarines are on patrol at any one time because of the cost of keeping them at sea. And this sad state of affairs applies to the strongest of Russia's four fleets. The Pacific fleet is in worse condition, the Black sea and Baltic fleets have been left even weaker by the disintegration of the Soviet Union.

Earlier this year the authorities in the northern port of Severodvinsk slapped a ban on any more nuclear submarines arriving for decommissioning, while navy headquarters concluded that the fleet's six Typhoon-class submarines, the biggest in the world, were already useless and that the Oscar-class vessels (like the Kursk) would be inoperable within four years. Two of the Soviet navy's most prestigious training centres were in Estonia in the Baltic and in Sebastopol on the Black sea, now in Ukraine. They have never been replaced. Against this background, the plan for the northern fleet looks like a folie de grandeur.

The admirals and generals are among Putin's biggest supporters because he gave them the green light to take their revenge on the Chechens for the lost 1994- 96 war, because he promises them more money and restored prestige, if not a return to what they regard as the Soviet glory days. The weekend wargames that ended so disastrously, the navy spokesman, Igor Dygalo, confirmed yesterday, were a dress-rehearsal for October when a northern fleet battle group led by the Admiral Kuznetsov aircraft carrier was to set sail for the Mediterranean to rub shoulders with the US Sixth Fleet.

It would have been the first time that independent, democratic Russia had put such an expedition in the Med, a symbol of a proud and assertive Russia under a new strongman. The prospects for the expedition are now in doubt. The aircraft carrier is anchored in the Arctic, leading the rescue mission.

webTitle: 'Monstrous' Brando wreaked havoc on film set

fields.headline: 'Monstrous' Brando wreaked havoc on film set
fields.trailText: Marlon Brando this week flies out from the set of The Score, his latest (and some say last) picture, amid reports that the ageing actor made life hell for his fellow cast and crew
fields.body:
Marlon Brando this week flies out from the set of his latest (and some say last) picture amid reports that the ageing actor made life hell for his fellow cast and crew.

The 76-year-old star of On the Waterfront and The Godfather was headlining as a retired jewel thief in The Score, alongside Robert De Niro and Edward Norton. But insiders on the set claim that Brando's behaviour was eccentric to say the least. On several occasions, the heavyweight actor allegedly arrived on set nude from the waist down (see last week's story).

Sources reckon that Brando used the nudity ploy as a means of forcing director Frank Oz to refrain from shooting him below the shoulders. Apparently Brando was happy to appear in close-up, but unwilling to be seen in his full big-bellied glory. "He was kind of monstrous," said one unnamed source. "At first I thought that the guy might be senile and had simply forgotten to get dressed, but it was part of this weird tactic. Nobody knew where to look."

Since his early years as America's most admired actor, Brando's career has weaved a strange and haphazard course. He showed up on the set of Apocalypse Now without having learned his lines, publicly criticised The Freshman while still shooting the film and famously goofed around on the set of The Island of Dr. Moreau.

Yesterday, in the wake of Brando's latest shenanigans, the Los Angeles Daily News interviewed further unnamed sources on the set of The Score. "Whatever you heard, it was worse," one said. "He was misbehaving, to say the least." Asked whether the reports of Brando's nudity were true, the source quipped, "you haven't heard any requests for retractions, have you".

fields.headline: Burst tyre caused Concorde crash
fields.trailText: The Civil Aviation Authority today confirmed that a single burst tyre caused the "catastrophic accident" which brought down the Air France Concorde, killing 113 people, and announced it was officially withdrawing Concorde's certificate of airworthiness.
fields.body:
The Civil Aviation Authority today confirmed that a single burst tyre caused the "catastrophic accident" which brought down the Air France Concorde, killing 113 people, and announced it was officially withdrawing Concorde's certificate of airworthiness.

Safety experts say that a burst tyre should never be enough to bring down a passenger plane and that British Airways' seven-strong Concorde fleet will remain grounded indefinitely while an action plan to reduce the risk is worked out.

The airliner was officially grounded today by the CAA as investigators in France revealed that the shredding of the number two tyre on the left main landing gear was the "first significant event" in the Paris disaster last month.

BA ceased all its Concorde operations yesterday ahead of today's official announcement. Air France cancelled all its supersonic flights on the day of the crash.

The CAA chairman Sir Malcolm Field, said that the burst tyre was the primary cause of the accident. He said that such an incident should never destroy a passenger plane.

But Sir Malcolm said: "We fully support British Airways' operation of Concorde after the crash."

BA is expected to look at ways of modifying the airliner to get it back in service, although no timescale was given.

Mike Bell, of the CAA safety regulation group, said he was confident that BA could carry out the necessary measures.

Ken Smart of the Air Accident Investigation Board said that in-service experience showed that tyre damage during the taxiing, take-off or landing was "not an unlikely event on Concorde and that it may actually lead to damage to the structure and to systems. However, this has never led to a fuel-fed fire".

He added: "The July 25 accident has thus shown that the destruction of a tyre - a simple event which cannot be asserted not to recur - has had catastrophic consequences in a very short timescale without the crew being able to recover from this situation."

Consequently, the AAIB and its French equivalent had made its recommendation about suspending Concorde's airworthiness certificate "until appropriate measures have been taken to ensure a satisfactory level of safety as far as the tyre destruction-based risk is concerned".

Sir Malcolm said that CAA support for the BA decision to carry on flying continued until the first evidence from the joint investigation team was received.

"During the last three weeks BA has introduced a number of extra maintenance and operational procedures and, short of significant design changes, has done everything possible to ensure a safe operation.

"Their results have justified these actions. At this stage of the inquiry what is uniquely different in this case is that tyre debris alone is thought to have led to this catastrophic accident, which has persuaded us to accept the recommendation from the investigation team."

Sir Malcolm said that the safety experts' recommendation had led to the suspension of certificates of airworthiness for each of the seven British-registered Concordes.

He added that together with the French civil aviation authority, the Anglo-French manufacturers of the plane would be asked to recommend an action plan.

Sir Malcolm went on: "At this stage it is not possible to say how long these studies will take, and if there will be a requirement for any modifications, but we will conduct this work as thoroughly and quickly as possible."

Investigators have said that a piece of metal found on the runway probably caused the tyre burst. It has not been determined where the metal came from but it does not appear to be part of Concorde.

Mr Bell, head of the CAA's design and production standards division, said after the news conference that it could be "some time" before the necessary modifications could be made to enable Concorde to fly again. "It will be months rather than weeks," he said.

BA ceased all its Concorde operations yesterday ahead of today's official announcement. Air France cancelled all its supersonic flights on the day of the crash. The CAA chairman Sir Malcolm Field, said that the burst tyre was the primary cause of the accident. He said that such an incident should never destroy a passenger plane. But Sir Malcolm said: "We fully support British Airways' operation of Concorde after the crash." BA is expected to look at ways of modifying the airliner to get it back in service, although no timescale was given. Mike Bell, of the CAA safety regulation group, said he was confident that BA could carry out the necessary measures. Ken Smart of the Air Accident Investigation Board said that in-service experience showed that tyre damage during the taxiing, take-off or landing was "not an unlikely event on Concorde and that it may actually lead to damage to the structure and to systems. However, this has never led to a fuel-fed fire". He added: "The July 25 accident has thus shown that the destruction of a tyre - a simple event which cannot be asserted not to recur - has had catastrophic consequences in a very short timescale without the crew being able to recover from this situation." Consequently, the AAIB and its French equivalent had made its recommendation about suspending Concorde's airworthiness certificate "until appropriate measures have been taken to ensure a satisfactory level of safety as far as the tyre destruction-based risk is concerned". Sir Malcolm said that CAA support for the BA decision to carry on flying continued until the first evidence from the joint investigation team was received. "During the last three weeks BA has introduced a number of extra maintenance and operational procedures and, short of significant design changes, has done everything possible to ensure a safe operation. "Their results have justified these actions. At this stage of the inquiry what is uniquely different in this case is that tyre debris alone is thought to have led to this catastrophic accident, which has persuaded us to accept the recommendation from the investigation team." Sir Malcolm said that the safety experts' recommendation had led to the suspension of certificates of airworthiness for each of the seven British-registered Concordes. He added that together with the French civil aviation authority, the Anglo-French manufacturers of the plane would be asked to recommend an action plan. Sir Malcolm went on: "At this stage it is not possible to say how long these studies will take, and if there will be a requirement for any modifications, but we will conduct this work as thoroughly and quickly as possible." Investigators have said that a piece of metal found on the runway probably caused the tyre burst. It has not been determined where the metal came from but it does not appear to be part of Concorde. Mr Bell, head of the CAA's design and production standards division, said after the news conference that it could be "some time" before the necessary modifications could be made to enable Concorde to fly again. "It will be months rather than weeks," he said.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Harry Potter movie set to be disrupted by determined Christians, Liz Hurley to go up in a cloud of smoke, Salma Hayek has to move quickly and gorgeous George Clooney turns down Hornby role
fields.body:
 The filming of the Harry Potter (pictured) movie looks set to be disrupted by a small but vociferous group of Christians who are protesting the use of Gloucester Cathedral as the film's primary location. A team of seven, led by Derek and Paula Clare who run the religious website New Day, are to organise a permanent picket outside the set when the film begins shooting later this year. "If Jesus was at the cathedral, he would not allow this," reckoned Paula Clare. "People think the Harry Potter books are fun, but they should not be using this cathedral, which is a house of God. The character of Harry Potter is a wizard encouraging witchcraft, which is contrary to the word of God." The Dean of Gloucester, the Very Rev Nicholas Bury, has meanwhile admitted to being a huge fan of Potter and claims to have avidly read the first three books in JK Rowling's series.

 Smokers rights group Forest have approached Liz Hurley to be their guest of honour at their first annual smoker's award last year. The model-actress is believed to be sympathetic to the group and interested in taking part in future events. "So many celebrities smoke but always steer clear of our parties because their agents advise them against attending," said Forest director Simon Clark. "Liz Hurley would be perfect to show people that supporting Forest and standing up for smokers is no bad thing." For Hurley, however, this could be the latest in a series of moves guaranteed to attract criticism. Just last month, she was criticised for her decision to appear in a TV commercial in apparent contravention of the terms of an actor's strike.

 Jennifer Lopez's decision to press ahead with a film on the life of Mexican artist Frida Kahlo (see yesterday's news) looks certain to annoy Mexican actress Salma Hayek, who has been nurturing hopes of playing the same role for years. Hayek has had her project - based on the book Frida: A Biography of Frida Kahlo - in development with Miramax since 1997 but has yet to find a director. By contrast, the fledgling Lopez film is backed by United Artists, has director Luis Valdez (La Bamba) on board and will be executive produced by Francis Coppola. Hayek had better move swiftly if she doesn't want to be seen as a Johnny-come-lately.

 Nick Hornby's characters have been played on-screen by the likes of Colin Firth (Fever Pitch) and John Cusack (High Fidelity). But George Clooney is reported to have turned down the chance to follow in their footsteps - because he reckons he's too good-looking. According to an interview with Hornby in the Daily Express, the novelist tentatively offered the ER graduate the chance to play the lonesome, single-man hero of his last book About a Boy in the upcoming movie adaptation, only to be knocked back. "You would need someone more average looking," Clooney reportedly told him.

webTitle: Bellamy off to Coventry in £6.5m deal

fields.headline: Bellamy off to Coventry in £6.5m deal
fields.trailText: Norwich City striker Craig Bellamy is set to join Coventry City in a £6.5m deal.
fields.body:
Norwich City striker Craig Bellamy is set to join Coventry City in a £6.5m deal.

The move was agreed late last night - after the 21-year-old Welsh international rejected a last minute offer of a lucrative new contract at Carrow Road.

"We've agreed a fee with the club and terms with the player and Craig is on his way to Coventry for a medical," Coventry chairman Bryan Richardson told the Eastern Daily Press, after a week of speculation surrounding Bellamy and possible moves to both Newcastle and Totenham. "It is fantastic news for the club - especially considering the calibre of opposition we were up against."

"Gordon (Strachan) has had tabs on him for some considerable time and after speaking to several other people about the player to make sure, they all said 'go and get him, he's tops'. I can safely say it is down to Gordon Strachan and his commitment that Craig chose to come to Coventry," Richardson said.

"He is a manager who is only interested in talking about football with the player and Craig has realised that this is someone who will look after him as he did with Robbie Keane. We fully expect Craig to do as well as Robbie, if not better."

Bellamy is understood to have discussed the finer details of his five-year deal with representatives of the Premiership club last night. Bellamy is expected to make his debut on Saturday in Coventry's match with Middlesbrough.

Canaries manager Bryan Hamilton revealed that the club had done their best to keep hold of the young striker. "We offered him a new contract with an extension included, and we told him we would have been happy to offer whatever extension he wanted.

"But Craig felt it might be time to look for pastures new. He felt it was right to accept the offer and that he should be allowed to speak to the other club. So we gave the club the opportunity to speak to him."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's transfer gossip led into the diary room and forced to nominate two of their closest friends for eviction
fields.trailText: Boudewijn Zenden will snub Chelsea and move to Lazio, according to reports in the Spanish media. They quote the player's father, Pierre Zenden, who admits: "The negotiations with Lazio have been reactivated. This time, there will be no problems with the payment, the reason why I believe he will go to Italy."
fields.body:
Boudewijn Zenden will snub Chelsea and move to Lazio, according to reports in the Spanish media. They quote the player's father, Pierre Zenden, who admits: "The negotiations with Lazio have been reactivated. This time, there will be no problems with the payment, the reason why I believe he will go to Italy."

And it's not a good day for Chelsea in general, as Gianfranco Zola has reiterated his desire for a move to Napoli. "I cannot deny the idea of going back to the team which made me famous excites me very much, he admitted. "A new TV deal has made Napoli wealthier, and the chairman says he is looking for me."

Meanwhile Leeds have agreed a £4.75m fee for Liverpool defender Dominic Matteo - and the deal should be completed before Saturday's game against Everton.

Duncan Ferguson's on-off £3.75m transfer to Everton has finally collapsed after the Newcastle striker failed to turn up to a medical yesterday according to all the papers today. But Walter Smith will keep himself busy, reports the Star, by selling Thomas Myhre to Sheffield Wednesday for £500,000.

Joe Royle is another manager who has been active in the transfer market. According to Planet Football the Manchester City manager is set to launch a £750,000 bid for Rangers' Paul Ritchie, who has failed to make the expected impact at Ibrox following his Bosman transfer in the summer. And onefootball reckons Royle will further strengthen his defence by signing Ecuadorian international Ulises de la Cruz from Liga Deportiva Univesitaria de Quito. They say the 26-year-old will arrive in Manchester on Saturday and quote LDUQ director Rodrigo Paz, who days: "He will have a 10-day trial. If he passes, he will be sold to Manchester City. The transfer has already been agreed."

Derby are lining up a move for Sunderland winger Nicky Summerbee reports the Star - and the deal could see Rory Delap going the other way in a swap deal involving Summerbee and a cash sum of £2.5m

Former French international striker Patrice Loko has been handed a trial with Charlton reports the Star.

webTitle: Oi, ref. You've sent our hair off as well!

fields.headline: Oi, ref. You've sent our hair off as well!
fields.standfirst: After Sunday's Charity Shield it's clear what this year's football haircut is. Fashion editor  Jess Cartner-Morley analyses the rise of the slaphead
fields.trailText: After Sunday's Charity Shield it's clear what this year's football haircut is. Fashion editor Jess Cartner-Morley analyses the rise of the slaphead.
fields.body:
Sunday's Charity Shield victory might not have won Chelsea any points, but it proved beyond doubt that Gianluca Vialli is the most influential man in the current game. For, over the summer break, the Chelsea manager's signature bald head has become the footballing hairstyle of choice. But although his team has a respectable on-pitch double in the form of Roberto Di Matteo and Frank Leboeuf, with "Jimbo" Hasselbaink easing into the swing of things with a bare millimetre of hair, Manchester United have surged ahead already. With Roy Keane, David Beckham, the newly arrived Fabien Barthez, and Jaap Stam, who replaced the woeful (and relatively hairy) Silvestre, United had scarcely a hair between them.

Vialli has long been miles ahead of his rival managers in the style stakes, although to be fair, the competition is not tough. Like a thrifty market shopper, Arsene Wenger is too busy scouring France for £2m bargains to have time to spend at the barbers. Alex Ferguson has a knighthood and more silverware than Buckingham Palace but looks like a ticket inspector. For the foot soldiers on the pitch, however, looks and image - and specifically, hairstyle - have become a major fashion statement.

Because they work in uniform, as it were, footballers can't make style statements with their clothes, so their hair becomes disproportionately significant. When Beckham cut his blond locks, the fuss generated could scarcely have been greater if his fringe had been essential for taking free kicks. The public's interest can be a double-edged sword, though: Everton's Abel Xavier became a household name by dyeing his hair; Jason Lee, however, never recovered from the obsession of some football fans, Skinner and Baddiel included, with his dreadful pineapple hairstyle.

What makes the bald look so striking is that until recently, footballers have been associated with long, floppy hair. The English pitches of the 70s were a sea of long hair and short shorts (the look now modelled by the Italians), while the 80s were awash with perming lotion. Through most of the 90s, the pin-ups of football - Ryan Giggs, Jamie Redknapp, both of whom are now short-haired - sported public school-ish floppy fringes. Until recently, the skinhead was the hairstyle of the football hooligan, the bouffant do the hairstyle of the football professional.

It's amazing that the slaphead look didn't catch on before. Long hairstyles need to be kept in place, and not even Charlie's Angels quantities of hairspray could keep a coiff fixed through 90 minutes of careering around in the wind and rain. But sensible though the skinhead style undoubtedly is, what it suggests most strongly is not practicality, but aggression. There's no getting around the fact that not having any hair makes you look like a nutter - particularly when combined with running around kicking people and swearing. Long hair gives a slightly feminine air: think how much more menacing Emmanuel Petit, whose strawberry-blond ponytail is now bouncing around Barca, would be with a grade one skinhead. Roy Keane, hardly lacking what is politely called the competitive instinct in the first place, looks absolutely terrifying with no hair. (And if Sunday's performance is anything to go by, the United captain is more aggressive than ever.)

Whether the skinhead look actually suits anyone is another matter entirely. True, it's an excellent foil for an unsightly bald patch, but such a huge expanse of skull tends to make eyes look shrewishly small by contrast, which is another reason that Keane looks scary. Blonds - unless they have Beckham's cheekbones - tend to look oddly undefined, like new potatoes. And while the severest of crops might be winning the full three points just now, any football pundit can tell you that a lot can change between now and the end of the season.

Manchester United, Liverpool and Chelsea, three of the teams expected to do well in the Premiership season which kicks off on Saturday, all have a high slaphead quota, but there is still plenty of hair around. Benito Carbone, newly arrived at Bradford, shuns the clippers and sports a rather fetching white headband to keep his shoulder-length hair out of his eyes, and Ipswich golden boy David Johnson sports a fashionable Craig David mop of short twists. Let's hope they don't succumb to clipper peer-pressure: a whole league of skinheads would be a sinister sight. But I'm not too worried, to be honest. Can you see David Ginola shaving his head?

webTitle: Prince William opts for Scottish university

fields.headline: Prince William opts for Scottish university
fields.standfirst: St Andrews School of Art History
fields.trailText: Prince William wants to attend St Andrews University to study art history, it was reported today.
fields.body:
Prince William wants to attend St Andrews University to study art history, it was reported today.

Providing that his A-level grades meet expectations, he plans to take a gap year and begin the degree course in 2001. St Andrews usually asks for 28 points (AAB) at A-level for the four-year MA course.

Earlier reports suggested that the prince considered Edinburgh, East Anglia and Bristol before settling on the small Fife-based university.

Founded in 1411, St Andrews is the oldest university in Scotland and preserves a number of distinctive traditions. These include Raisin Weekend - when freshers are dressed in costume by their third- and fourth-year academic "parents" and paraded through the town - and the wearing of scarlet undergraduate gowns.

The Kate Kennedy Club, an all-male university society, dates from 1926 and recruits many former public schoolboys. It commemorates the niece of St Andrews' founder, raising money for charity and organising marches depicting characters from the town's history.

fields.headline: Clinton's 'Oscar' win slammed by Academy
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton's Oscar for "being the best president", presented to him at the Democratic national convention, described as no more than "a fibreglass prop"
fields.body:
Bill Clinton's farewell speech to the party faithful at the Democratic national convention could have been described as the performance of his life, but its aftermath landed the departing president in some last-minute hot water. The "Oscar" that Clinton received from California governor Gray Davis was revealed to be a fake.

A swift disclaimer from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences described it as no more than "a fibreglass prop" taken from the lot at Paramount studios.

Davis, a Democrat, had presented Clinton with the phoney Academy Award on Monday night, saying: "I want to give the Clinton family the highest award Hollywood can give for an extraordinary performance - an Oscar for being the best president."

Clinton, who famously posed with Kevin Spacey's Oscar in the spoof video Clinton: The Final Days, appeared delighted with the award. "I had Kevin Spacey's Oscar and he was ungracious enough to come and take it away from me," he told the assembled crowd. "Now that I have one of my own, I'll be able to lord it over him."

But yesterday brought a swift rebuttal from the real-life Academy. "Our concern is that people are commenting that the president got an honorary Oscar," said Academy spokesman Jon Pavlik. "We want people to understand that it wasn't really an Oscar. It was a counterfeit Oscar being used in an inappropriate way."

In a statement, Academy president Robert Rehme stressed that "both in its bylaws and in 72 years' worth of careful practice, the Academy is resolutely non-political. Unfortunately the prop looks to have been an awfully accurate counterfeit, and it was identified as an Oscar."

Yesterday the Democrats were sounding a contrite note. "It was a prop presented as a way to honour the president and have fun," said a spokesman for the governor. "We didn't mean any disrespect."

Since coming to office in 1992, Clinton has been known for his high-profile supporters within Hollywood, and there is even speculation that he may take a job within the industry - possibly with Spielberg's DreamWorks - when he leaves office next January.

However, the current Democrat hopeful, Al Gore, already appears to be keeping Hollywood at arm's length. Gore's choice for vice-president, Joseph Lieberman, has regularly criticised what he regards as the movie industry's corrosive influence, echoing traditional Republican concerns. With Clinton's departure, the federal government's love affair with Tinseltown could be drawing to a close.

webTitle: Pride returns to the boys in maroon

fields.headline: Pride returns to the boys in maroon
fields.trailText: There's a spring in the step of West Indies cricket once again. Not only did they turn the tables on England so impressively in the third Test at Manchester, but their master batsman Brian Lara is back on song. Then there's the feeling that the future doesn't seem so bleak after all, now that the Windies Under-15 team have shown they're the best in the world by winning the recent World Cup in England.
fields.body:
There's a spring in the step of West Indies cricket once again. Not only did they turn the tables on England so impressively in the third Test at Manchester, but their master batsman Brian Lara is back on song. Then there's the feeling that the future doesn't seem so bleak after all, now that the Windies Under-15 team have shown they're the best in the world by winning the recent World Cup in England.

But while Headingley vindicates their policy of four fast bowlers, history has shown that it's the quartet from the home side that's more likely to prosper. Remember Graham's Gooch's brave, skilful unbeaten 154 nine years ago that won it for England? Headingley has not been that happy a hunting ground for West Indies. It's probably the Test venue they like least. But at least they are going into the match in greater heart than they began the Old Trafford game.

The main reason for that is Brian Lara. The great man reckons he'll get most of his runs towards the end of tour - and England will hope he's wrong. He left it late on the 1995 tour and could well do the same here. He sets himself 500-run goals as often as a Soviet collectivist sets five-year targets, and if the odds are against him getting to that total, well, he will try. He does still look at least 10 pounds over his fighting weight (poor Andrew Flintoff has been grabbing all the headlines in this respect) but if his eye problems are serious and his hamstring and overall fitness remain suspect, then his mid-innings net at Manchester shows he's got his focus and determination back.

At Manchester, Adams helped Lara stage the Windies' fightback, though he must take some of blame for getting them into a bad position through his extraordinary decision to bat after winning the toss. On a first-day pitch, under overcast skies, and with a debutant to face Ambrose and Walsh, Adams was being almost too clever in thinking about not wanting to bat last rather than making use of the helpful conditions. His belated declaration on the last day showed up the real game plan - to avoid defeat rather than go all out for victory. As they'd tell him down at Elland Road, Leeds is a difficult place to pack your midfield. Adams will have to be attacking from now on, and make sure his side secures the results.

And his captaincy skills could again be tested by sessions like the first one of the second day, when Stewart and Trescothick were galloping away with the game, and the Windies gave the worst exhibition of fielding I've ever seen from a Test side. One of the most painful incidents to watch was when three lethargic fielders all failed to go for a catch any of them could have taken to dismiss Trescothick. They can go to pieces with alarming ease, and Adams has to react more quickly to that than he did at Old Trafford.

Ridley Jacobs will be pleased about ending his run of low scores, but appalled by his terrible miss of Nasser Hussain in the second innings. This is no time for him to revert to his old reputation for having the iron gloves of a young Rodney Marsh - a reputation he shed so decisively in the 21 months he's been a West Indies regular. For the Scotland game, he gave the gloves to his work-experience understudy Wayne Phillip, and should be fresh for Headingley.

The dependable Shiv Chanderpaul is still injured, and his wonderful innings at Edgbaston shows how much he is missed. His neat-looking replacement Ramnaresh Sarwan continues to suffer from indifferent form in the tour matches, and hasn't quite reproduced the kind of batting that brought him 84 not out on his debut against Pakistan earlier this year. Adrian Griffith helped the second innings cause in Manchester, in what may have been a career-saving knock.

And the bowling? Franklyn Rose and Reon King in particular bowled some pretty brainless stuff to Alec Stewart in the third Test - lots of short balls to one of the best back-foot players in the game today. Some armchair experts in Guyana (where I am at the moment) think there's a case for King taking the new ball with Courtney Walsh, with the reasonable explanation that he'll have to do it in Australia if Ambrose goes as he said he will at the end of this tour.

King's biggest advance came in New Zealand last winter, where he was forced to take the new ball and the responsibility, and responded by bowling better than even Courtney Walsh (Ambrose missed that tour). Curtly needs two wickets to reach 400, and they'll have to tear the new ball out of his hands. I doubt whether Jimmy's that brave.

Here in the Caribbean they're making a big deal out of the victory of the Under-15s. They haven't forgotten the youngsters' sense of occasion, when they put on their maroon West Indies blazers and cheered the senior players on at Old Trafford. They were there with Lara as he closed in on his century, and he had to have felt a responsibility to demonstrate to them - big brother to little brother, teacher to pupil - what skill and commitment are all about. The youngsters showed by their actions on and off the field that the pride is back, and that can clearly be felt in the region. Caribbean people reckon their team is harder to beat when they're playing with that pride.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for six years and currently works as a broadcast journalist. To read his previous Anglo-Caribbean View, written before the third Test at Old Trafford, click here

fields.headline: Concorde 'may never fly again'
fields.trailText: The civil aviation authority today suspended the airworthiness certificate for Concorde, casting doubt on whether the supersonic airliner will ever fly again.
fields.body:
The civil aviation authority today suspended the airworthiness certificate for Concorde, casting doubt on whether the supersonic airliner will ever fly again.

CCA chairman Sir Malcolm Field said the suspension would last until "appropriate measures" were taken. Aviation authorities confirmed that a tyre burst was the "primary cause" for the Air France Concorde crash in Paris in which 113 people died. Such a burst on its own should never cause the loss of a passenger plane, Sir Malcolm said.

The CAA said it was asking Concorde's manufacturers to recommend an action plan to ensure the aircraft's safety, but could not say how long it would be before this would happen and the plane could fly again. France was today set to take the same steps.

Britain's move will keep the seven Concordes operated by British Airways on the ground until further notice. The airline suspended all Concorde flights on Tuesday ahead of the move. Air France stopped its flights immediately after the crash.

fields.headline: Jackson brings radicalism to Democrats
fields.standfirst: It fell to the Rev Jesse Jackson to remind the convention what inclusivity means, reports Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles
fields.trailText: It fell to the Rev Jesse Jackson to remind the convention what inclusivity means, reports Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles.
fields.body:
There have been at least three different conventions taking place in Los Angeles this week: the official Democratic National Convention; the Shadow Convention, dealing with the issues allegedly not being addressed by the Democrats; and the convention - if that is the right word - on the streets, in the form of protest.

Last night the Reverend Jesse Jackson became the first politician to bring all three together. Jackson, once a candidate for the presidency himself, got a standing ovation from the official convention after invoking the memory of Martin Luther King and calling for an America that included everyone. By everyone, he stressed, he also meant the protesters whose causes should be respected.

The previous night, the Los Angeles police had waded in with rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse the crowd that had gathered to hear the band Rage Against the Machine. Earlier in the day, Jackson had addressed a packed Shadow Convention that is meeting a few blocks away about the "war on drugs".

If Jackson was making an effort to bridge the divides between the different parts of America, the speakers who followed him at the main convention bridged a different gap. Caroline Kennedy, the daughter of the late president, recalled that it had been in Los Angeles in 1960 that her father had been chosen to run in his successful campaign against Richard Nixon.

"It is time once again to ask more of ourselves," she told the delegates, to applause. She said that as she and her late brother were growing up, hardly a day had gone by without someone telling them how much their father had meant to them. Many people, including the Democrats' vice-presidential candidate, Joe Lieberman, had been inspired to enter public office because of JFK's memory.

She also stressed the differences between the Democrats and Republicans on issues such as abortion and gun control. She introduced her uncle, Ted Kennedy, now the patriarch of the country's best-known political family. He used his time to eulogise Al Gore, who has so far been overshadowed at the convention by the Clintons.

Ted Kennedy said that Gore was the only candidate for president who could help bring about the dream of universal healthcare for all Americans, which he described as a "life or death issue."

The session closed with Bill Bradley, who lost in the primaries to Al Gore, making a further plea for Gore in November. "Our country needs a Democratic conscience," he told a cheering crowd. He, too, harked back to a different time and the "ideals of Jack, Bobby and Martin, the ideals they died for".

The day's speeches gradually spelled out the differences between the two major parties with a reminder from speakers that George W Bush was one of the most anti-abortion governors in the country and that his election might lead to an end of a woman's right to choose.

Many speakers also claimed that the Democrats were the party of diversity while the Republicans used "window dressing" to try and persuade voters that they represented more than just white America.

Outside the convention centre a rally opposing the sanctions against Iraq took place peacefully as hundreds of riot police stood by.

fields.headline: Child sex attacks 'merit vengeance'
fields.standfirst:
Feminist author says she admires woman who shot paedophile

Special report: child protection
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: The feminist writer Andrea Dworkin last night entered the Sarah Payne debate by declaring that the victims of child sex abuse have the right to kill paedophiles.
fields.body:
The feminist writer Andrea Dworkin last night entered the Sarah Payne debate by declaring that the victims of child sex abuse have the right to kill paedophiles.

Ms Dworkin, a rape victim herself and former prostitute whose seminal and controversial books Women Hating and Pornography have turned her into the bogey woman of the right, said: "The women have to have the right to avenge crimes on their children. A woman in California shot a paedophile who abused her son; she walked into the court and killed him there and then.

"I loved that woman. It is our duty as women to find ways of supporting her and others like her. I have no problem with killing paedophiles."

Dworkin said women and children were not protected by the law as it stood from "men who rape, rape, rape" and would themselves have to take the law into their own hands if justice was ever to be done. Because "men abuse prostitutes and rape women" laws had to be written which would allow women to "defend a larger space around them. Women should get guns and should be allowed to use them to defend themselves."

Dworkin claimed that women had to learn from the experience of other "oppressed peoples" and carve out a homeland for themselves like the Jews in Israel where they could be "safe from men".

The outspoken feminist said that men had to "identify more with their mothers" if the world was ever to improve. Her comments were in contrast to those made on the same platform the previous day by the veteran American novelist Norman Mailer, who insisted that if "men were to have a hope in the next century they need to rediscover the warrior inside them". Mailer said the American male had been castrated by corporate culture.

Dworkin, who has been ill of late and was pushed to the stage in a wheelchair, said the mass rape of women by men throughout history had been overlooked and played down just as it had been in Auschwitz.

"The Nazis liked to present their wholesale raping of Jewish women as 'affairs' camp guards had with Jewish women, contrary to the Nuremberg laws which did not allow such racial defilement. The men were supposedly moved by the Jewish women's great beauty into breaking the law."

She said of The Merchant of Venice: "I don't know whether it should be performed at all or whether it should be rewritten, but we need to look at it."

Dworkin was speaking at the Edinburgh International Book Festival about her latest volume, Scapegoat, which maintains that the Jewish oppres sion of the Palestinians came about through the need for Jewish men to adopt a "tough guy" persona after the humiliation and horror of the Holocaust.

Describing herself as a pacifist who has "reluctantly come to accept the need for violence in certain situations when women have no other choice," she said her ideal women's homeland would not be a perfect Utopia because "not all women are good and not all men are bad - the difference is that men rape, and women need protection from that."

Dworkin, who recently revealed in the Guardian that she had been drugged in a hotel room and raped again, said she was saddened by the reaction of some women who doubted her. "If the Holocaust can be denied even today, how can a woman who has been raped be believed?"

She said there were no easy answers to the problem of paedophilia, but it was time for women to actively protect their children from men. Nor would she condemn the "mob rule" on the Paulsgrove estate in Portsmouth.

"I am not completely up to date about what is happening in Portsmouth. But I understand people's anger.

"I feel sorry for the women and children in the families who have been driven out of the estate, but often in these cases the men have been involved in incest on their children."

Women who were turning away from feminism were misguided and would eventually see the folly of embracing the post-feminist willingness to allow "men to be lads."

"To those women I say would there be women's refuges if it wasn't for feminism? Where would the rape crisis centres be?"

Dworkin's comments came as several women last night walked out of The Barbaric Comedies, a centrepiece of the international festival, because of prolonged rape scenes in Frank McGuinness's abridged version of the Spanish theatrical epic.

webTitle: View from elsewhere: Show me the money

fields.headline: Show me the money
fields.standfirst: In a rural Italian town, a 77-year-old man convinced his neighbours to swap their lire for a brand new currency, reports Rory Carroll in Rome
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 11.45am: In a rural Italian town, a 77-year-old man convinced his neighbours to swap their lire for a brand new currency, reports Rory Carroll in Rome
fields.body:
An Italian pensioner's dream to transform his town's economy by minting an independent currency flowered into a local boom before withering into ruin and accusations of chicanery. Convinced conventional economics had missed a trick, Giacinto Auriti, 77, persuaded neighbours and shopkeepers last month to ditch the lire in favour of his new currency, the simec.

Its value was equal to the lire, but the self-appointed central banker offered an unbeatable deal: for every lire he received, he handed over twice the number of simecs. Residents in Guardiagrele, a rural town in the region of Abruzzo in central Italy, queued up to change currencies and doubled their spending power.

More than 40 retailers joined the new economy after realising they would lose newly flush customers. They accepted the notes, which carried the retired university professor's signature, and on request he converted them back into lire. By last week, total turnover was estimated at £1.6m as shopkeepers and consumers raced to cash in on a deal they suspected was too good to be true. It was.

Mr Auriti dreamed of the simec going national, perhaps even international, but he was financing the experiment with his own fortune, and it was disappearing fast. "I know what I'm doing. I understand that a lot of people believe I'm crazy, but I have my own theory to prove, that's the objective of my life," said Mr Auriti.

"Money belongs to citizens because they are the ones who are producing consumer goods in the first place." A long running vendetta against Italy's central bank, which he accused of fraud, galvanised his initiative. Tax police who tried to intervene were gobsmacked.

Colonel Sante Mappa confessed: "Obviously this is not a case of fraud, but we will have to figure out something. This Abruzzo saga will have to end. "We are at a complete loss on how to deal with this case because the currency is not counterfeit and Mr Auriti, far from making money, is actually losing his considerable family fortune."

The professor's supporters cited a 1991 precedent in New York where a journalist, Paul Glover, persuaded hundreds of people to circulate his currency, called hours. Concerned that Mr Auriti's bankruptcy would leave hundreds in the town holding worthless paper, Col Mappa continued to try to find a way to squash the simec.

He succeeded last weekend when a minority of shopkeepers, holdouts against the simec, complained they were disadvantaged. Police raided Guardiagrele's central bank and sequestered the bank notes. The professor was charged with abusing the financial system and people's savings. He is defiant and, according to police, penniless.
