webTitle: MPs attack 'abysmal' MoD as costs of weapons soar above estimate

fields.headline: MPs attack 'abysmal' MoD as costs of weapons soar above estimate
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence, reeling under attacks on its performance, faces renewed criticism today by a committee of MPs which denounces delays and cost overruns amounting to nearly £3bn in procuring weapons systems - including weapons that could have been used instead of cluster bombs in the Kosovo war.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence, reeling under attacks on its performance, faces renewed criticism today by a committee of MPs which denounces delays and cost overruns amounting to nearly £3bn in procuring weapons systems - including weapons that could have been used instead of cluster bombs in the Kosovo war.

The MoD's "current performance in procuring equipment to cost and time is unacceptable, and there is no evidence that the department are controlling projects any better now than in the past", said the cross-party Commons public accounts committee.

David Davis, its Conservative chairman, piled on the agony for the MoD, describing its track record in procuring equipment as abysmal. He made it clear the committee was fast losing patience with the ministry's promises for potential savings in its "smart procurement" programme.

One project highlighted by the MPs is the Brimstone air-launched anti-armour weapon, already 10 years late. Its unavailability "has had an adverse effect on the United Kingdom's operations against armoured threats during the 1990s, including Kosovo", they said.

Sir Robert Walmsley, chief of defence procurement, admitted in evidence to the committee that it would have been better to have had Brimstone instead of relying on cluster bombs during the Kosovo war.

In a letter subsequently sent to the committee, the MoD admitted that "the limitations of the BL755 and RBL755 [cluster bombs] were well understood".

According to the UK working group on landmines, Nato cluster bombs are estimated to have killed between 90 and 150 civilians in the Kosovo conflict, and unexploded cluster bombs have since caused more than 200 casualties.

An MoD report leaked this week - not disclosed to MPs - estimated that 60% of the 531 cluster bombs dropped by the RAF missed their intended target or remain unaccounted for.

The MPs, in their report released today, point to a six-year delay in the Bowman battlefield radio system. This month the MoD announced it was launching a new tender for the system after dismissing the consortium that had been developing it for three years at a cost of £212m.

The MoD continued to make basic errors in estimating progamme costs, the committee said, pointing to a missing £2m VAT bill on a new air-to-air missile project.

It was unacceptable that defence inflation - which accounted for £400m of the cost increases in 1998 - was running at 5%-6% when factory gate prices were falling.

They scrutinised 25 big defence projects with a total cost of £38.3bn compared with the original total estimate of £35.4bn. The cost overrun would have paid for 15 destroyers or 40 minehunters, the MoD confessed to the committee.

The average delay in the projects has slipped to more than three-and-a-half-years. The largest single overrun - over £1.5bn - is for the Eurofighter, although the MoD said the cost increases had now peaked.

John Spellar, the armed forces minister, said in a statement that the MPs reflected the position as it was more than two years ago, before the introduction of "smart procurement".

However, the MPs said the MoD had provided no evidence about how it would secure the promised £2bn savings. One described the figure last night as "Treasury imposed".

fields.headline: In and on the net
fields.trailText: So, "Football is back" (Front page, August 14).
fields.body:
So, "Football is back" (Front page, August 14). Yes, and it's been back in Scotland since July 29 and the rest of England since last weekend. As for the BBC's site having "no great new ideas", doesn't the Beeb's live internet broadcasts of every single Scottish Premier league match count? This is the first time anywhere in the world that a national league has had all its top division's matches covered on the web. Pretty groundbreaking, I would have thought.

David Ross
Penzance, Cornwall

 Football is back? Did it ever go away?

Dorothy Keeley
Altrincham, Cheshire

 Every day a group of regulars come to our café to check out the form and tips from your racing page. I don't need to tell you how confused they were when you printed the page from June 5 (Corrections, August 15). Any chance of making their day by printing August 19's page tomorrow?

Tony Day
Sunrise Cafe, Cromer
sunrise@paston.co.uk

 How apt that the correspondent who reminded us of Gary Sprake's error-prone career (Letters, August 14) should come from Liverpool, Anfield being the scene of his classic howler when, in attempting to hurl the ball to a colleague, he only succeeded in spinning right round and throwing it into his own net.

Phil Lightfoot
London

 I have two searching questions about Mick Jagger and co's antics (An inspector calls, G2, August 15). Was the wrapper taken off the Mars Bar? Who ate it afterwards?

Jack Hill
St Albans, Herts

 Re the current TV commercials: how much work does a McDonald's employee have to do to afford a McDonald's quarter-pounder?

Mandy Colvin
Wadhurst, E Sussex

fields.headline: Rape myths
fields.trailText: I fail to see how a post-mortem can show that "Kirsty had initially consented to sex" (Thai maid lied over body find, August 15).
fields.body:
I fail to see how a post-mortem can show that "Kirsty had initially consented to sex" (Thai maid lied over body find, August 15). Consent is a mental function and cannot be demonstrated at post-mortem. A woman may be sexually aroused, which would be evident on PM, but despite this may not wish to have sexual intercourse. This kind of statement perpetuates the myths around rape which has meant that in this country, despite women increasingly having the courage to report rape, the number of convictions have not risen.

Wendy Savage
London

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A leader yesterday, page 21, erred in saying that the magazine Flight International was "served with a D notice" to deter it from revealing failings in the RAF's bombing record in Kosovo last year. The magazine now says that the defence advisory committee expressed its concerns in a letter sent to the editor.
fields.body:
A leader yesterday, page 21, erred in saying that the magazine Flight International was "served with a D notice" to deter it from revealing failings in the RAF's bombing record in Kosovo last year. The magazine now says that the defence advisory committee expressed its concerns in a letter sent to the editor.

The Times's leader headline reacting to controversial drugs sentences against two members of the Rolling Stones read as follows when it was published on July 1 1967: "Who Breaks a Butterfly Upon a Wheel?" Minus the upper-case style that, including the question mark, is how it was written by Alexander Pope in his Epistle to Dr Arbuthnot. Stories on page 2 and in G2, pages 2-3, yesterday slightly varied the quote and attributed it to William Blake.

Minehead was put in Devon rather than Somerset in Play dough, page 16, Jobs and Money, August 12. The same article needlessly rechristened the so-called English Riviera on the south-west coast as the British Riviera.

The US gymnast who collapsed at the 1996 Atlanta Olympic games was Kerri Strug, not Shrug, as given on page 7, Sport, August 14.

A Diary item on the Yelverton Paperweight Centre yesterday, page 20, associated Sir Francis Drake with potatoes. It was Sir Walter Raleigh who in legend (largely discredited) brought the potato to the British Isles. And the paperweight centre is on Dartmoor, not in Dartmouth.

Amelia Earhart's plane was was lost over the Atlantic in 1937, according to a BBC2 TV listing on page 24, G2, August 10. It was the south Pacific.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • The details are vague and the police say it may be weeks before the whole story emerges... but, just as we feared, it seems that Gerald Kaufman, who vanished from this office over the weekend and was last spotted on Sunday evening by a party of tourists in London's glittering theatreland, has been kidnapped. Shortly before noon yesterday, a note (made up of letters cut from newspapers) was received. "We have him," it read, "and he is safe. For now. Remember Getty, and stand by for instructions."
fields.body:
 The details are vague and the police say it may be weeks before the whole story emerges... but, just as we feared, it seems that Gerald Kaufman, who vanished from this office over the weekend and was last spotted on Sunday evening by a party of tourists in London's glittering theatreland, has been kidnapped. Shortly before noon yesterday, a note (made up of letters cut from newspapers) was received. "We have him," it read, "and he is safe. For now. Remember Getty, and stand by for instructions."

While unwilling to commit themselves on the record, sources in the Yard's Organised Crime Group believe that this has all the hallmarks of the splinter group Real GAF (Garland Appreciation Front), an obscure but ruthless terrorist outfit dedicated to lowering the price of dress circle tickets to all musical entertainments around the world. Until we receive a specific ransom demand, however, there is nothing to do but sit by the phone. And wait. And pray. Light a candle, and pray for him.

 The irony is truly dreadful, but yesterday a press pack arrived from Rolls-Royce concerning the loan of the Corniche convertible RR1 for... sorry, I'll be fine in a second... for Gerald's tour of... no, it's too distressing. Later.

 Tom Freeman writes from north London enclosing a questionnaire from Metrotravel, a page in a free newspaper "brought to you by London underground", with someone well known to Gerald as the Tory spokesman on culture, media and sport. Much of what my friend Peter Ainsworth has to say is fascinating, not least his confession to fare-dodging in Strasbourg and his theory that tube travel is better in London than Paris - but nothing more so than the line at the top of the page: "Continuing our series on what the stars think of London's transport." Stars, eh? It was this column that campaigned to raise Little Ainsworth's profile, as with Andrew Smith before... and look at them now. I could weep with pride.

 Thank God for the Financial Times. The pink 'un is a model of sober reflection in a sea of silly season hyperbole, and never more so than on August 3 when Alison Beard looked at the effect of technology on one profession. "Accountancy: the worst of times at the best of times," reads the headline. "With internet start-ups it is no longer a glamour profession." Ah well, nothing lasts for ever.

 Thanks to all who have pointed out that the Yelverton Paperweight Centre is on Dartmoor, and not in Dartmouth, 50 miles away. Meanwhile, Dave Cohen emails to say: "I think you have already written about the magnificent Barometer World, but don't know whether you've come across Britain's first sheep-oriented theme park, the Big Sheep, also in north Devon. Here one can groom sheep and see them in their natural habitat - fields." What a glorious county Devon is.

 A test case with potentially dramatic consequences has been brought in Sydney by widow Pilar Allen. Mrs Allen is suing to recover the organs of her late husband. "He needs to be whole," she insists. "He can't go to heaven without his heart, eyes and kidneys." Four Australians are thought to be taking an unusually close interest in the case: if the court finds for Mrs Allen, one organ recipient will die, another will go blind and two more will be forced on to dialysis machines.

webTitle: Oil price soars as West's stocks dwindle

fields.headline: Oil price soars as West's stocks dwindle
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: World oil prices hit their highest level since the Gulf War yesterday amid fears of dwindling stockpiles in the West and tough talk from the cartel of producing countries. The price of Brent Crude jumped by $1.27 or 4% to $32.75 (£21.77) a barrel, way above a previous peak of $31.95 on March 7.
fields.body:
World oil prices hit their highest level since the Gulf War yesterday amid fears of dwindling stockpiles in the West and tough talk from the cartel of producing countries. The price of Brent Crude jumped by $1.27 or 4% to $32.75 (£21.77) a barrel, way above a previous peak of $31.95 on March 7.

News last week that US oil reserves are at their lowest level since 1976 sent prices above $30 a barrel on Friday. The rise was triggered by comments from Venezuela's president, Hugo Chavez, about the need for oil revenues to boost the economies of members of the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

The 11-nation group, which pumps most internationally traded oil, suffered a drop in earnings following a price slump in 1997/98 that was pulled back only by Opec output cuts.

"It's a silly price, an extraordinary price. But you can explain this largely in terms of the trauma of 1997/98," said John Toalster, director of oil and gas research at SG Securities.

In June, Opec agreed an output rise to cool prices but with little effect. Traders fear the Saudis have reconsidered their production strategy as there are fewer barrels of Saudi crude on the market.

On Monday US energy secretary Bill Richardson reiterated that oil prices should be in the "low $20s". Opec ministers meet in Vienna on September 10 to set autumn quotas.

"It's a silly price, an extraordinary price. But you can explain this largely in terms of the trauma of 1997/98," said John Toalster, director of oil and gas research at SG Securities. In June, Opec agreed an output rise to cool prices but with little effect. Traders fear the Saudis have reconsidered their production strategy as there are fewer barrels of Saudi crude on the market. On Monday US energy secretary Bill Richardson reiterated that oil prices should be in the "low $20s". Opec ministers meet in Vienna on September 10 to set autumn quotas.

webTitle: Phone call that ended BA's flights

fields.headline: Phone call that ended BA's flights
fields.standfirst:
Yesterday's decision proved more clear-cut than British Airways' immediate response to the Paris crash that killed 113

Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: When the news broke shortly before 4pm on July 25 that an Air France Concorde had plunged from the skies above Paris just moments after take-off, the top brass at Waterside, British Airways' Heathrow headquarters, knew they had little choice but to cancel their next flight.
fields.body:
When the news broke shortly before 4pm on July 25 that an Air France Concorde had plunged from the skies above Paris just moments after take-off, the top brass at Waterside, British Airways' Heathrow headquarters, knew they had little choice but to cancel their next flight.

There were less than two hours to go before the BA003 flight taxied down the runway bound for JFK, New York, and the news of the Paris tragedy would begin to filter through to passengers arriving at the Concorde lounge in Terminal 4.

In fact when BA announced at 5.25pm that it was taking the unprecedented step of grounding the supersonic jet, passengers were already aware of the disaster.

"I was very apprehensive," admitted one who had been steeling himself to join the flight when the announcement came just half an hour before take-off. "I had not made up my mind about whether to board it."

For the directors and technical flight specialists hastily assembled in the boardroom less than a mile from the airport, and under Concorde's flight path, chancing a flight was a risk they could not contemplate.

"There was very little discussion," said one BA official. "Both out of respect for those 113 who died, and because we simply didn't have any reasonable information at that point on which to make a decision."

Both flights due that day, the 17.55 and the 18.45 from New York, were suspended but, in announcing its decision, BA gave no indication this would be anything but temporary. In a statement, the airline stressed: "We will be holding discussions with our technical counterparts at Air France and reviewing tomorrow's operations overnight."

And, when morning came, it appeared to be business as usual for the British limb of the Anglo-French Concorde partnership: Air France might have indefinitely grounded its five remaining planes, a move which now looks increasingly permanent, but in London the BA001 10.30 flight took off as usual, albeit with just 37 passengers.

The decision was criticised by Jean-Pierre Blazy, the mayor of Gonesse, where the Concorde came down. As the town held a silent march to commemorate the 113 dead, he accused BA of showing "indecent haste" in resuming its service. "It is imperative that Concorde remains grounded," he railed. "I deplore the decision by the British to continue flying."

Accused of being insensitive in putting economic preoccupations above the feelings of the victims' families, the airline last night remained unrepentant. "We have the utmost respect for the victims and their relatives but we saw no reason and we haven't had any subsequent notification of any by the Civil Aviation Authority before today to suggest we should suspend our operations," BA said.

But, as more details emerged of safety checks ordered by Christian Marty, the captain of the ill-fated AF4590, as well as of a safety record that appeared less pristine than previously noted, the public perception of Concorde's safety all but disappeared. And, in an atmosphere of increasing paranoia, BA was forced to admit earlier this month that it had had four Concorde scares in as many days.

On August 1 a back-up Concorde had to be used after one scheduled to fly to New York was taken out of service at the last minute for further adjustments to engine work carried out at the weekend.

Emergency alert

Another plane was grounded indefinitely after cracks were found in wing frames, while another prompted a full emergency alert at Heathrow when it reported a problem with an engine BA later dismissed as "no more serious than a car backfiring".

In the most serious incident, on July 30, a Concorde bound for New York was diverted to Gander, Canada, after passengers complained of smelling fuel in the cabin. "It was purely a precautionary measure," said BA spokeswoman Jemma Moore.

Within a couple of days just two of BA's seven-strong fleet were in service, but officials refused to concede there were serious problems with the ageing crafts and insisted they were being "exceptionally vigilant at the moment".

That vigilance, BA said yesterday, was reflected in increasingly extensive checks made on each plane and daily discussions with accident investigators conducting the 18-month inquiry into the Paris disaster.

"Since the accident we have liaised on a daily basis with all the regulatory authorities involved and we have acted on any information available to us. At no such point were we provided with any facts or information that lead us or the CAA to question the safety of our fleet or the decision to continue operations," said BA spokesman Peter Middleton.

Before the crash four engineers inspected the exterior and engines of each Concorde about to fly as well as testing the brakes and tyre wear. Similar checks on the engine oil levels, tyre pressure, external lighting and emergency cabin equipment were conducted after each flight, with a more intense examination of the oil levels, windows and cabin interiors after every 30 flying hours.

But last night BA admitted the checks were brief - "we're not talking hours" - and said that, following the tragedy, they had been stepped up in length, thoroughness and intensity. "An extensive series of additional procedures and checks on the aircrafts' airframe, engines, tyres and wheels, hydraulics and other systems and operating procedures" were carried out after the crash, Mr Middleton added, refusing to go into greater detail.

In the end, no amount of checking or fevered reassurance could prevent the discovery of what appears to be a structural flaw, and when the air accidents investigation bureau rang BA at 10am yesterday to warn it the CAA would be grounding its Concordes the next day, the airline's decision was even more clear-cut than in the immediate aftermath of the crash.

A call was made to the CAA to confirm that the certificate of airworthiness would indeed be taken away, and then to the captain of flight BA001, who by this stage was taxiing towards the runway, in readiness for the 10.30am take-off.

The plane stopped, and the passengers heard they must disembark to meet a BA director. His message was simple: Concorde's services had been indefinitely withdrawn.

Timetable: Three weeks of uncertainty

July 25 All Concorde flights grounded after flight AF4590 crashes into a hotel in the Paris suburb of Gonesse, killing 113 people. BA's two evening Concorde services do not fly.

July 26 BA Concorde services resume while France orders indefinite suspension of all Air France Concorde flights. Crash investigation initially centres on the engines.

July 27 French air accident investigators say the crew of the crashed Concorde had problems with both port engines and were unable to retract the undercarriage.

July 28 Investigators reveal that "certainly one, and possibly two" of the tyres on the left hand side of the supersonic jet shattered before the crash.

July 29 Concorde suffers three safety scares in one weekend. A BA Concorde flight bound for Heathrow from New York suffers a mixture of fuel and air in the engine, causing a loud bang inside the jet.

July 30 A BA Concorde is prevented from taking off because of a refuelling problem. On the same day 57 passengers are stranded at Gander, Newfoundland, after their New York-bound flight is forced to divert when smell of fuel is detected in the cabin.

August 1 A BA Concorde is taken out of service for "minor adjustments" shortly before it was due to leave Heathrow. Its 33 passengers are switched to a back-up Concorde.

August 9 A study of Concorde's engines carried out before the crash found 55 "significant risks", it is revealed. New Scientist magazine reports it has seen details of the study which showed some of the risks could lead to "catastrophic problems" including uncontrolled fire and multiple engine failure.

August 10 Investigators say the crash was probably caused by a punctured tyre. A strip of metal found on the runway pierced the jet's tyre. Fragments probably then shot into fuel reservoirs.

webTitle: Comment: The consequences of the new Terrorism Act

fields.headline: Draco would be proud
fields.standfirst: The new Terrorism Act will have far-ranging consequences for liberty both in Britain and abroad
fields.trailText: The new Terrorism Act will have far-ranging consequences for liberty both in Britain and abroad
fields.body:
Draconian new legislation designed to curtail the activities of foreign opposition groups based in Britain slipped quietly on to the statute book last month, the few whimpers of protest silenced by the public panic over paedophiles. Barely six months since these columns were warning of its implications, the Terrorism Act has been bludgeoned through without any alterations worth mentioning.

The government would have us believe it is a timely replacement for the Prevention of Terrorism Act 1989, which dealt primarily with Northern Ireland, bringing the law up to date with the changing nature of terrorism. Critics counter that its indiscriminate scope is designed to harass and intimidate into silence all opposition deemed a hindrance by Whitehall. They are right. The main feature of this legislation is its deliberate bluntness. It is intended not to strike dread into the hearts of those who cannot distinguish between bullet and ballot box, but to cow all legitimate opposition to foreign regimes with whom our foreign secretary wishes to carry on his "ethical" business.

At a stroke the act has reshaped the landscape in which opposition groups can work. It is now illegal to call for the violent overthrow of unelected, despotic governments in countries such as Algeria; to campaign for the liberation of occupied lands such as Kashmir and Palestine; or to engage in weapons training for the purposes of freedom and self-determination.

The act affects Muslim groups more than most. After the demise of communism, the role of challenging the political and cultural hegemony of the west was thrust upon a reluctant and out-of-shape Islam. Muslim governments were in no position to rise to the challenge. Since independence, most Muslim countries, especially in the Middle East, have acted as client states for the west, enjoying a symbiotic relationship by which their monarchs and oligarchs have been kept in power in return for access to cheap oil. As usual, it is the man and woman on the street who have paid the price. Many have gravitated towards opposition groups which, with no democratic avenues for dissent, have ended up moving abroad.

London has been a popular choice. Leaders of groups ranging from the militant Egyptian Gama'a Islamiya to Tunisia's pacifist an-Nahda movement have all enjoyed the freedoms that have earned the city a deserved reputation as an international safe haven. The Terrorism Act signals they have overstayed their welcome.

Middle Eastern regimes, along with Israel and the US (to whose regional hegemony such groups now provide the only resistance), have urged Britain to adopt a more draconian view of terrorism, one that further blurs the distinction between freedom fighter and terrorist. Whereas the PTA concerned itself with threats to the United Kingdom, the tentacles of the new act extend worldwide. It is now an offence to campaign for - this includes raising funds for or otherwise promoting - the assassination of an Assad or Mubarak, on the grounds that it represents a call to murder.

In fact, the act is so broad it may well prove unworkable. It defines terrorism as the use or threat of force "designed to influence the government or to intimidate the public or a section of the public, and advance a political, religious, or ideological cause". That includes the students who raise money outside the mosque for the mujahideen in Chechnya. It includes the imams who pray for their success in their sermons. And it includes those who rally in Trafalgar Square to espouse jihad as a weapon of political liberation. Another damaging consequence of the act is the power it gives the police to stop and question and arraign suspects. Under the act it is enough for an officer merely to entertain a suspicion that somebody is breaching the law in order to justify a stop and search or an arrest.

The new act cements a definition of national security established in May in the case of Shafiq ur Rehman, a Pakistani imam who was ordered to be deported for his (unproven) links to the Kashmiri liberation group the Lashkar-i-Toiba. Mr Rehman was given his marching orders under the Immigration Act 1971 after the judge decided that his activities endangered Britain's relations with India. Whether Mr Rehman had actually threatened relations was not the point, the judge ruled. The material consideration was that he was capable of doing so. "The promotion of terrorism is capable of being a threat to our own national security," he said. Great. You are now a threat to national security if you merely hold certain views or associations even if you don't follow them through. Such a view of national security is far too broad. It holds out the prospect of arrest for, say, the comedian Mark Thomas for opposing controversial schemes like the Turkish dam project, or for Greenpeace activists disrupting French nuclear tests.

Mr Rehman is appealing the decision. If he fails he stands to be deported, but it could have been worse. Had the Terrorism Act been in place when he was charged, he might have been facing the next decade behind bars.

 Faisal Bodi is a British Muslim journalist.

webTitle: US loan for animal tests lab

fields.headline: US loan for animal tests lab
fields.standfirst: Anti-cruelty protesters vow to pursue campaign against new financiers
fields.trailText: Animal testing laboratory Huntingdon Life Sciences yesterday secured finance from a specially created US private investment firm in the hope of deterring further intimidation by animal rights protesters.
fields.body:
Animal testing laboratory Huntingdon Life Sciences yesterday secured finance from a specially created US private investment firm in the hope of deterring further intimidation by animal rights protesters.

News of the fresh financing comes two weeks before a crucial £22.5m debt facility provided by Royal Bank of Scotland expires. The Guardian revealed two months ago that the loan would not be renewed after bank staff were repeatedly threatened.

The Edinburgh-based bank inherited the relationship when it bought NatWest, which provided the facility two years ago. At the time the laboratory had installed new management after it was exposed over cruel treatment of puppies.

Huntingdon Life Sciences, whose shares have collapsed as big investors have pulled out following intimidation, said Royal Bank would extend the facility until the new arrangement with FHP Realty is completed, expected to be in place by the end of October.

By achieving financing from FHP Realty, which is backed by Huntingdon shareholders, directors and other employees, the laboratory hopes to avoid high-profile stunts by protestors, such as vandalised cash machines and hoax bomb alerts. An asset-backed £10m loan provided by an unidentifed US-based lender is also part of the arrangement.

Among the investors in FHP Realty is Huntingdon chairman Andrew Baker. Stop Hunting Animal Cruelty campaigners said yesterday they would now turn their attentions on the group as well as Bank of New York which owns shares in Huntingdon.

A spokesman for Huntingdon said: "We were particularly eager not to be persistently associated with highly visible retail banks which can easily be targets for animal rights protesters."

The spokesman said FHP Realty would provide longer-term finance for the laboratory than it had previously been able to secure, perhaps for as long as 50 years.The new financing, announced with its results which showed a widening in six month losses to £2.4m from £2.2m, will involve the sale and lease back of Huntingdon's properties.

Huntingdon, which carries out safety trials for pharmaceutical companies, hoped it would encourage more companies to place orders in order to increase its revenue flow. Huntingdon managing director Brian Cass highlighted the explosion in research surrounding new gene technology as a possible area of growth for the business.

Huntingdon has not appointed a new corporate broker to replace German banking group WestLB which severed its ties earlier this year. So did former 11% shareholder Phillips & Drew, which held shares for the Labour Party's staff pension fund, but now owns no Huntingdon shares which were unchanged at 8.75p. Both institutions said their decision had been precipitated by attacks from anti-vivisectionists.

As many as 50% of its investors are now estimated to be in America though possible changes to company law in Britain next year may mean that investors' names could be suppressed from its share register, one of the main sources of information for animal rights protesters.

Huntingdon hopes that such measures, along with those being considered by the Home Office to tighten up the laws on harrassment, might encourage investors to reconsider holding shares in the company.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: New move in Microsoft case
fields.body:
New move in Microsoft case

The US supreme court should hear the Microsoft anti-trust case, bypassing the court of appeals, the department of justice said yesterday.

Microsoft asked the supreme court in late July not to grant the department's request for an immediate transfer of the monopolies case to the supreme court. It filed a brief to the court requesting that an appeals court first hear the company's appeal.

"Microsoft opposes expedition of its own appeal. We submit, however, that direct appeal to this court is warranted," the department said in its filing to the supreme court.

Firms miss export boat

British companies could be missing out on export business worth up to £10bn a year because they do not coordinate their overseas sales drives with trade bodies and government departments.

Trade Partners UK, the umbrella body for all government-related trade support services, urged industrial sectors to recoup lost export opportunities.

Consultants Arthur D Little, in a report for Trade Partners UK, said that companies with poor export performances failed to invest in strong trade bodies, take part in overseas fairs or use government services.

IFA sales boost Allied Zurich

Allied Zurich, the British holding company of Anglo-Swiss insurer Zurich Financial Group, yesterday reported a 16% increase in new UK life and investment premiums in the first half, driven by strong sales via independent brokers.

Total UK first-half sales were £1.5bn, while new business sales on an annual premium equivalent basis were up 12% to £267m.

Zurich Financial Services UK finance director Brian Thomas said the group had outperformed the UK market on the volume side. The group performed well on sales through independent financial advisers, where its share has been growing over recent years.

Mutual Federal buys CGU

Old Mutual said its 51% owned South African general insurance group, Mutual & Federal Insurance Company, is to buy CGU Holdings, a subsidiary of CGNU, for £98.2m.

Mutual & Federal said substantial areas of synergies are expected between the two businesses and the acquisition also offers efficiencies in operations and technology to facilitate expansion into the southern African region.

NTT close to Verio purchase

webTitle: Panel leaves Hyder's fate hanging in the balance

fields.headline: Panel leaves Hyder's fate hanging in the balance
fields.trailText: The fate of Hyder, the Welsh utility group, hung in the balance last night as a full meeting of the City's takeover panel struggled to decide who had made the highest valid bid for the group.
fields.body:
The fate of Hyder, the Welsh utility group, hung in the balance last night as a full meeting of the City's takeover panel struggled to decide who had made the highest valid bid for the group.

Shareholders were still left in the dark four days after the final bid should have been lodged and a winner announced under a procedure imposed by the takeover panel executive in the middle of last week.

Both Western Power Distribution, a US-owned energy group, and Nomura, a Japanese investment bank, claim to have won, with bids valuing Hyder at £565m.

The executive backed a 365p a share bid by WPD, even though it had not been announced by Friday's deadline, and Nomura appealed against the decision. The panel's failure to clarify the position, even after a day-long sitting, left City institutions questioning its effectiveness.

City sources said they were astounded that the panel was taking so long to make a ruling. One of the panel's strengths in the past has been its ability to resolve takeover problems quickly.

Its speed and flexibility have frequently been cited as reasons for retaining the self-regulating body to oversee the conduct of takeovers.

Hyder's shareholders and employees have been left in a state of uncertainty since Nomura first announced its bid plans at the end of March.

Under the takeover code, the rival bidders would not have been able to increase their offers after midnight on Friday. But the panel executive, fearing an unseemly flood of bids and counter bids in the dying minutes, imposed an unusual sealed-bid procedure.

This required an increased offer to be made in a sealed bid by 1pm Friday and announced by the victor by 4.30pm. Nomura decided not to increase its 360p a share offer and was subsequently trumped by WPD with a sealed bid worth 365p a share.

Nomura appealed against the panel executive's decision to allow the WPD bid even though it had not been announced by 4.30pm as a result of what was described as "a technicality".

City investors have criticised the panel's decision to end the Hyder bidding through the sealed bid procedure, which it has only used once before, and then inconclusively.

They have objected to the formula which rounded down the highest offer made under the procedure to just 5p-a-share above the lowest offer, claiming that this was not in shareholders' interests.

WPD is thought to have indicated that it was prepared to bid as much as 375p a share. But under the formula this was reduced to 365p, because Nomura had not increased its 360p bid.

The Nomura bid is being masterminded by Guy Hands, head of the bank's London-based principal finance group. Mr Hands has made a reputation by buying distressed assets, putting in new management and investment, and eventually selling the firms at a handsome profit.

WPD, a joint venture between Pennsylvania Power and Light and Southern Company, has put forward plans to bring in United Utilities, the north west multi-utility group, to run Welsh Water, Hyder's regulated water business.

A watchdog ruled by City grandees

The strength of the takeover panel is that almost all its members are, or have been, leading practitioners in the City. They will need all their collective experience to sort out the mess that the panel executive have made of supervising the final days of the bidding war for Hyder.

The panel is chaired by an outsider, Sir David Calcutt, a former chairman of the bar. He is one of the six members of the 16-strong panel appointed by the governor of the Bank of England. Only five are needed for a quorum.

Deputy chairman John Walker-Howarth is a former managing director of UBS Warburg while counterpart Antony Beevor is a senior adviser to SG Hambros and a former director general of the panel executive. Other panel members include Don Cruickshank, chairman of the London stock exchange, who is now deeply involved in the exchange's planned merger with Frankfurt.

Judith Hanratty, the only woman on the panel, is company secretary of BP, which in the last year or so has mounted takeover bids for Burmah Castrol, Amoco and Arco.

The panel executive is a mixture of seconded and permanent staff. Its director general, Patrick Drayton, has been seconded from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, while Tim Cargill, one of the executive's four secretaries and the man who arranged the sealed bids for Hyder, has been seconded from lawyers Lovells.

fields.headline: Cut-price fashions rein in inflation
fields.standfirst: UK rate on target - while Irish prices are rising by 6.2% a year
fields.trailText: The steepest fall in prices of clothing and footwear for more than half a century kept inflation below the government's 2.5% target for the 16th month in a row in July, according to official figures published yesterday.
fields.body:
The steepest fall in prices of clothing and footwear for more than half a century kept inflation below the government's 2.5% target for the 16th month in a row in July, according to official figures published yesterday.

Despite a sharp rise in seasonal food prices, the government's targeted measure of inflation, excluding mortgage interest payments, held steady at 2.2%, said the office for national statistics. Headline inflation, widely used as a benchmark for wage negotiations, was also unchanged at 3.3%.

City analysts said the figures suggested that the Bank of England's monetary policy committee had been right to leave interest rates on hold at 6% when it met this month, though Philip Shaw, chief economist at Investec bank, said today's labour market data and tomorrow's retail sales figures would be crucial to the outlook for the cost of borrowing.

"We still feel it is a little too early to call the top of the base rate cycle," said Mr Shaw.

With unemployment falling below 4%, there are lingering fears that wage inflation could pick up speed again after the recent deceleration.

The ONS said that seasonal food prices rose between June and July for only the third time on record as wet weather hit supplies of potatoes, fresh fruit and vegetables.

But inflation was held in check by a 7.1% fall in prices of clothing and footwear, the biggest drop since records began in June 1947.

Statisticians said the decline reflected the unseasonal weather and cut-throat competition between retailers. Inflation was also restrained by lower increases in car insurance costs and petrol and a fall in second hand car prices.

Ciaran Barr, chief UK economist at Deutsche Bank, said that without the blip upward in seasonal food prices, underlying inflation would have fallen to as low as 2%.

"This will not go unnoticed by the MPC, with evidence of continued high street deflation suggesting that sterling's strength is still working through the system," he said.

Overall goods inflation was 0.5%, up marginally from 0.7% in June, while service sector inflation fell to 3.3% from 3.5%. Mr Barr said the decrease in service sector inflation, the main source of upward price pressure, was particularly encouraging, though he noted that the level could become problematic if goods deflation begins to unwind.

The harmonised EU measure of inflation, which is calculated on a different basis from the British retail price index, was 1%, up from 0.8% in June. Ireland's EU rate is running at 5.9%. The country's domestic measure of inflation hit an annualised 6.2% last month, according to data published yesterday.

fields.headline: Pifco holds merger talks
fields.trailText: Kitchen appliance manufacturer Pifco Holdings has announced it is holding merger talks with a number of European and British rivals.
fields.body:
Kitchen appliance manufacturer Pifco Holdings has announced it is holding merger talks with a number of European and British rivals.

The group which makes Russell Hobbs, equipment, has long tried to merge with Kenwood Appliances, but the deal is unlikely at the moment, according to Pifco chairman Michael Webber.

Pifco made its announcement after the release of the group's preliminary results for the year to April 2000.

The results were slightly better than analysts expected, with an increase in pretax profits from £2.5m to £4.5m. Sales were 16% ahead at £48m, buoyed by the strong Russell Hobbs favourites.

The dividend rises 10% to 7.26p.

Analysts said they would marginally upgrade their figures on the back of the results.

The share price closed yesterday at 157p, up 4.5p.

webTitle: Economices Notebook: Bank may be too downbeat

fields.headline: Potato effect that gives the lie to pessimism
fields.standfirst: Bank may be too downbeat
fields.trailText: July's inflation figures were a story of skirts and spuds, according to one City analyst. Women's outwear - statisticians' jargon for skirts and shirts - led the decline in clothing and footwear prices, now falling at their fastest rate in 50 years. These latest figures will add to the debate at the Bank of England over whether aggressive discounting on the high street is a temporary phenomenon or a permanent feature of the new economy.
fields.body:
July's inflation figures were a story of skirts and spuds, according to one City analyst. Women's outwear - statisticians' jargon for skirts and shirts - led the decline in clothing and footwear prices, now falling at their fastest rate in 50 years. These latest figures will add to the debate at the Bank of England over whether aggressive discounting on the high street is a temporary phenomenon or a permanent feature of the new economy.

On the other side a 50% rise in the price of the humble spud helped push seasonal food prices up by 4.9% over the month. An abundance of summer produce usually pushes seasonal food prices down in July, and without the potato effect underlying inflation would have been even more benign.

Overall, yesterday's figures leave the Bank's most recent inflation forecast, issued just last week, looking a little pessimistic. Threadneedle Street has pencilled in a rise in inflation during the third quarter; many analysts expect a continued decline.

The only nasty surprise in store is climbing oil prices. Although - as Monday's factory gate price data demonstrated - manufacturers are finding it difficult to pass rising fuel costs down the supply chain, higher oil prices will inevitably push up costs at the pump after the recent petrol price war.

Analysts at Lombard Street believe that Opec is doing the west a favour by meeting the responsibilities of the US Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan. Higher prices, they argue, are restraining demand in industrialised countries and could even deflate the American bubble economy. An oil price rise which provides a beneficial shock for the world economy? Now there is a thought.

What are words?
The Chicago board of trade and derivatives exchange Eurex yesterday put out a brief press notice headlined "CBOT and Eurex deny merger plans". Simple enough, you might think.

The start of the release, however, is a comment from Eurex chief executive Jörg Franke that casts a slightly different light on the relationship between the two exchanges. "Eurex sees benefits in a merger, but there are currently no plans to expand upon the alliance."

Dr Franke might not have a plan, but he appears to have a preference. If Eurex and the CBOT were quoted British companies the takeover panel might well spare an executive or two from trying to sort out the Hyder mess to have a word with Dr Franke and ask him to explain his intentions rather more fully.

It was the panel, after all, which once defined one executive's comment that he had "no present intention" of launching a much rumoured bid in - for him - uncomfortably precise terms.

Bid logic
The City takeover panel is much admired, and rightly so. Compared with statutory systems it is quick, flexible, cheap and usually effective. But its reputation has been damaged by the Hyder debacle.

With the best of intentions the panel executive imposed a system of sealed offers on the two bidders. The aim was to prevent any attempt to exploit the exactitude of the takeover timetable, to stop one bidder slipping in an offer at literally the last minute.

But instead of producing a clear-cut result, as intended, the outcome has been messy in the extreme. Hyder's shareholders, bondholders, customers and employees have been left in limbo for far too long, and the intervention of m'learned friends, not unprecedented in takeover panel annals but still extremely rare, cannot be discounted.

The takeover panel must have known that it was running a risk by opting for the sealed bid procedure rather than sticking to the timetable. The only previous time the tactic was used was not an unparalleled success and this time around, neither bidder seems to have been enthusiastic. If bidders cannot make up their minds what the target is worth and put their money on the table in the time allowed and are outmanoeuvred, that is their problem.

It is unfortunate, too, that the imbroglio centres on Hyder. The regulated side of the water industry is seeking to restructure. The process is proving difficult - the regulator has rejected Kelda's plans to turn its bit of that business into a mutual. The endgame at Hyder will not assist in creating the climate of sentiment needed if the process is to get the kick-start it seems to need.

But the Hyder failure should be set alongside the panel's previous record. The new directive on takeovers will make it much simpler for takeover bids to be resolved through a visit to the courts. It would be unfortunate if, as a result of the failure of the Hyder case, such action was to become the rule, rather than the exception it should be - even under the new regime.

fields.headline: Mersey profits as Ireland flourishes
fields.trailText: Ireland's booming economy has lifted Mersey Docks and Harbour Company to record profits after a 21% increase in ferry traffic through Liverpool.
fields.body:
Ireland's booming economy has lifted Mersey Docks and Harbour Company to record profits after a 21% increase in ferry traffic through Liverpool.

Ship operators such as P&O have increased sailings across the Irish sea to take advantage of growing trade. But Mersey Docks and Harbour Company has also benefited from higher road costs which have encouraged shipping firms to switch to Liverpool from rivals Stranraer and Holyhead.

This allowed the owner of Liverpool and Sheerness docks to produce pre-tax profits of £27.2m, up 6%, in the first half of the year on turnover up 9% at £101.1m. Earnings per share rose 6% to 22.19p, and the dividend was raised 9% to 6.0p. Analysts are expecting full year profits of about £55m.

Shares ended up 2.5p at 515p. They have already outperformed the overall London market by nearly 16% this year.

Meanwhile Mersey Docks and Harbour Company has dropped plans for mergers with other quoted port groups and has refocused its activities on buying cargo handling facilities in mainland Europe.

Chief executive Peter Jones said it had become clear that shareholders of other dock companies would prefer premium cash offers to all-share mergers, so consolidation would have to wait. He said inconclusive talks had been held with "most" of the five other quoted companies.

fields.headline: 900 go in Carillion 'blunder'
fields.standfirst: Losses come to light at Crown House Engineering subsidiary
fields.trailText: Carillion, Tarmac's former construction arm, yesterday announced plans to axe senior management and 900 jobs at its Crown House Engineering subsidiary after uncovering loss-making contracts.
fields.body:
Carillion, Tarmac's former construction arm, yesterday announced plans to axe senior management and 900 jobs at its Crown House Engineering subsidiary after uncovering loss-making contracts.

The blunders have surfaced at a difficult time for Carillion, which has been seen as a potential takeover target for predators such as Skanska of Sweden seeking to enter the British market.

Shares in Carillion fell 7% as analysts estimated the problems would wipe £34m off this year's annual profits. Carillion, hived off from Tarmac 12 months ago, is now expected to produce pre-tax profits of about £12m after an exceptional charge of £25m is taken against the contracts, with a further £9m for redundancies.

Crown House employs 2,200 full-time staff and 500 agency workers and has a turnover of £240m, about 12% of the Carillion total. Crown House specialises in mechanical and electrical engineering.

It will be concentrating on larger projects, according to new Carillion finance director Chris Girling, who discovered the problems during a review of group operations.

He dismissed suggestions that the parent group had been weakened by the forced restructuring and pointed out the rest of Carillion was performing very strongly.

The company is now the leading participant in the private finance initiative, set up by a Conservative administration during the 1980s and adopted by Labour when it came to power in 1997.

Carillion has recently landed a £600m deal to build and manage for 25 years a new communications headquarters for the MoD. It has also won a contract worth £100m a year to manage BT's buildings.

Stephen Williams, analyst at Williams de Broe, said the Crown House problems might damage the standing of the firm's management if restructuring did not materialise.

But he added: "My own view is that Carillion should not be pilloried for putting up its hands and admitting mistakes. It shows the company is serious about introducing more transparency to its accounts in a notoriously difficult sector."

Carillion shares ended the day down 9p at 119.5p. The firm had been enjoying a good run, outperforming the sector by 20% so far this year.

Carillion has recently landed a £600m deal to build and manage for 25 years a new communications headquarters for the MoD. It has also won a contract worth £100m a year to manage BT's buildings. Stephen Williams, analyst at Williams de Broe, said the Crown House problems might damage the standing of the firm's management if restructuring did not materialise. But he added: "My own view is that Carillion should not be pilloried for putting up its hands and admitting mistakes. It shows the company is serious about introducing more transparency to its accounts in a notoriously difficult sector." Carillion shares ended the day down 9p at 119.5p. The firm had been enjoying a good run, outperforming the sector by 20% so far this year.

fields.headline: No place for the poor
fields.trailText: Christopher Hart is right to lament the imminent extinction of the rural working class (All farmed out, August 12; Letters, August 15).
fields.body:
Christopher Hart is right to lament the imminent extinction of the rural working class (All farmed out, August 12; Letters, August 15).

My recent report for the Rowntree Foundation, Exclusive Countryside, identified housing markets as the principal mechanism through which poorer people, whether from town or country, are systematically excluded from residence in rural areas. Young people are similarly excluded: our research found that even with a good job young people were forced to move to towns and cities once they left the parental home. The provision of affordable housing opportunities is crucial to the sustainability of a living, working and inclusive countryside, but this requires both greater investment in social housing and more imaginative housing and planning policies.

Prof Mark Shucksmith
University of Aberdeen
m.shucksmith@abdn.ac.uk

 My income as a tenant dairy farmer has dropped by 80% in four years. The problem comes down to whether we have the correct balance in the marketplace. Many sellers and many buyers have in the past produced a sound balance in the market. However, today the supermarkets have total control both of the producer and the consumer. They have virtually killed off the smaller independent shopkeeper.

The solution is in the hands of consumers. If they want to see the countryside as it used to be, they have to break the power of the supermarkets. If they don't care about the countryside and are happy eating repackaged chicken from Thailand, pork grown in crates from Holland, fed on meat and bone meal, or milk products produced under god knows what condition in Poland then they should do nothing. I fear that's what the public will do. It wouldn't happen in France.

Peter Webster
Cheshire

webTitle: Leader: Concorde may fly again, but for how long?

fields.headline: The writing on the wall
fields.standfirst:
Concorde may fly again, but for how long?
Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: No one in authority actually said it yesterday, but serious doubts are now being entertained as to whether Concorde will ever fly again. And even if it does survive the latest intense scrutiny, it can never occupy quite the same place in the public's affection as it has for nearly 30 years. Other planes have been grounded before or had their airworthiness certificates withdrawn and then gone on to give further service. Concorde is different. Its appeal was not that of any other passenger plane going about its business.
fields.body:
No one in authority actually said it yesterday, but serious doubts are now being entertained as to whether Concorde will ever fly again. And even if it does survive the latest intense scrutiny, it can never occupy quite the same place in the public's affection as it has for nearly 30 years. Other planes have been grounded before or had their airworthiness certificates withdrawn and then gone on to give further service.

Concorde is different. Its appeal was not that of any other passenger plane going about its business. It had a special place of pride in the hearts not just of its well-heeled customers, but of ordinary people who could never hope to travel in it. It turned heads because of an unusual chemistry between its sleek, bird-like, profile, its leading-edge technology - and its safety record. Its admiring fan club was almost prepared to forget the public money squandered by building such a hopelessly uneconomic plane in the first place because of the pride generated by the achievement.

For almost 30 years it flew without the loss of a single life through a crash. That record was shattered on July 25 outside Paris when all 109 passengers and four people on the ground lost their lives. In future people will not look at Concorde flying overhead with undiluted pleasure: instead they will be worrying if everything is right on board.

This is doubly tragic: not just for the dreadful fact of lives lost - though that is paramount - but because of the sense that this was an accident that was not inevitable and should not have happened. If, as seems likely, the proximate cause of the disaster was a piece of metal lying on the runway, then that was something that due diligence could have prevented. It may be that there ought in any case to have been some form of protection built into the superstructure of the plane itself. This might have prevented flying objects having such a catastrophic effect on the fuel tanks and engines - but that only underlines how avoidable it all was.

If Concorde does not fly again, it will close a chapter in our aviation history. There will be hardly any passenger jets built (or mainly built) in this country that are still in regular passenger service. Britain does not make them any more, though UK companies manufacture the wings of the highly successful European Airbus and have a major presence in engines through Rolls-Royce. Concorde is more than airborne nostalgia. Its loss would truly be the end of an era.

fields.headline: Prescott mocks 'caring' Hague
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: John Prescott yesterday launched a withering attack on William Hague's attempts to rebrand the opposition as American-style "compassionate Conservatives" after the failure of his recent hardline tactics to close the gap with Labour.
fields.body:
John Prescott yesterday launched a withering attack on William Hague's attempts to rebrand the opposition as American-style "compassionate Conservatives" after the failure of his recent hardline tactics to close the gap with Labour.

"Hague and Portillo, Widdecombe and Redwood - compassionate Conservatives? Just look at their record. If you have to tell people you've got compassion, you've already lost the battle," he said, before denouncing the 18-year Tory record in office as that of "callous Conservatives".

Labour strategists are determined to cut off the Tory escape route now that a clutch of new opinion polls, including today's Guardian/ICM findings, suggest that Mr Hague's success on populist law and order issues has proved ephemeral.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, yesterday joined in, calling Mr Hague a frivolous and evasive opportunist, who would do anything for a headline. "All froth and trivia," he said in a reference to Mr Hague's beer-drinking achievements, which Mr Prescott also mocked.

Accusing the Conservative leader of "trying to hitch on to the Bush bandwagon" in the US presidential race, Mr Prescott said that Mr Hague was resorting to the "old Tory way" of stoking up "fear of foreigners, particularly of our fellow-Europeans", and "prejudice and bigotry towards any known minority, no matter who they hurt".

Labour wants to prevent Mr Hague repositioning himself as a more caring figure, now that he has consolidated his hold on core Tory voters. Speaking in Enfield, north London, Mr Prescott urged grassroots activists to keep hammering away at the £163.24m per constituency cuts which Labour says a Hague government would make.

Conservative HQ immediately retaliated in kind, pointing to a sharp rise in out-patient waiting lists in Enfield, a 12.6 % rise in London crime, and the poor state of Enfield's education services.

The deputy prime minister - in charge during the Blair family holiday - had made a foray into suburban Enfield, where Labour now holds all three seats, including the former constituency of Michael Portillo, who lost Southgate to Stephen Twigg in 1997.

Addressing party activists with Mr Twigg at his side, he repeatedly urged them to get out and sell Labour's message to voters who did not know it - or who misunderstood the details of the government's much-criticised pensions package.

It was far more generous, Mr Prescott insisted, than the basic 75p a week rise and included a tax-free £163.3 a week towards winter fuel costs.

A question and answer session revealed a mixture of praise and complaint from activists, evidently wary of recent Tory poll gains and the government's disarray, but also concerned that voters "feel we've deserted them a bit" on transport policy, pensions and other public services.

An ebullient Mr Prescott, keen to disappoint Tory tabloids on the Prescott gaffe-watch, admitted that Gordon Brown's initial adherence to Tory spending plans meant that "in the first two years ... we took a bit of stick, but we were taking a long term view" to deliver social justice from the proceeds of a strong economy.

fields.headline: More part-time students
fields.trailText: You erroneously assert (Women winning, by degrees, August 15) that the introduction of the new student support system has led to a decline in participation in higher education by mature students.
fields.body:
You erroneously assert (Women winning, by degrees, August 15) that the introduction of the new student support system has led to a decline in participation in higher education by mature students. The statistics quoted refer only to full-time enrolments. Most mature students choose to study part-time and have done so in increased numbers since 1994. Between 1994 and 1999 the number of part-time mature students increased by 36,000 (29%). There is now a long-established trend for mature students to learn whilst they earn.

Moreover, some 85% of full-time mature students do not pay tuition fees. In total, over 40% of those entering higher education do not pay fees, and a further third pay only a part contribution. Generous student loans are available, and these are now repaid from future graduate earnings, on an income-contingent basis.

Baroness Blackstone
Minister of state, Department for Education

 Dr Gabriel is right (Letters, August 15), but the other thing every academic knows about the research assessment exercise is that it takes full-time teaching staff away from students. While lecturers are writing their often unwanted and unread research papers, the money they earn through the REA is increasingly used to employ postgraduate students at part-time rates to teach undergraduates.

Dr Geoffrey Turner
Harrogate, N Yorks

fields.headline: The first casualty of war
fields.trailText: Far from Nato's claim that the Kosovo bombing campaign was "the most accurate ever conducted", we now learn that only 2% of unguided bombs and 40% of all bombs dropped on Yugoslavia reached their target. No wonder the Ministry of Defence made "determined efforts" to suppress this news (MoD leak reveals Kosovo failure, August 15).
fields.body:
Far from Nato's claim that the Kosovo bombing campaign was "the most accurate ever conducted", we now learn that only 2% of unguided bombs and 40% of all bombs dropped on Yugoslavia reached their target. No wonder the Ministry of Defence made "determined efforts" to suppress this news (MoD leak reveals Kosovo failure, August 15).

They must have known at a press conference of February 10 that claim was wrong. Twenty-four hours later the figures of bombing were announced at a secret session. For Downing Street to call this "a video game" and that "nobody would expect 100% accuracy" is distasteful as it is evasive. I have visited Serbia, including Kosovo, and can testify first-hand to what so-called collateral damage was wreaked on the population of Yugoslavia. Nato bombs that did hit their targets destroyed schools, hospitals, houses, factories - maiming and killing thousands of civilians.

Ministers owe us an explanation of what did happen on 10 and 11 February. They have to explain the discrepancy be tween what was said to the press and what appears to have been said in private.

Tam Dalyell MP
Committee for Peace in the Balkans

 It's interesting that Nato seems so concerned about stopping a Serb-run mine (one of the few enterprises in Kosovo that employs its dwindling Serb population) from polluting the atmosphere in Kosovo (Serbs turn on British troops, August 15), but had no problems with poisoning the entire Balkans by bombing chemical plants and oil refineries (releasing tons of chemical toxins such as ethylene dichloride, cynanide, and heavy metals into the atmosphere, ground, and the Danube river); and using depleted but still radioactive uranium ammunition and cluster bombs. The issue for Nato isn't about air pollution - it's about stealing the massive Trepca mining complex for western capitalists like George Soros.

Dr Michael Pravica
Las Vegas, USA
pravica@yahoo.com

 I shall not respond to Radomir Putnikovich's views about the recent history of Yugoslavia (Letters, August 12). But I would like to put the record straight on the arrests of Adrian Prangnell and John Yore by the Yugoslav Army.

Mr Prangnell and Mr Yore were held as they came back from a weekend break in Montenegro with two Canadians. They had entered Montenegro at an official crossing point, showing their passports, and had registered at their hotel. They were not violating Foreign Office travel advice in force at the time. After their arrest they were held for 10 days without consular access or contact with their families - a breach of both international and bilateral consular conventions. They were paraded on Serbian television and branded as "terrorists", despite the lack of evidence and the fact that no charges had been laid.

Keith Vaz MP
Minister for Europe

 A Foreign Office spokesman states that air strikes on Iraq are carried out "in response to direct threats to our aircraft" (US and Britain resume Iraq raids, August 14). Last year, the Pentagon told the Washington Post that the "payback" for Iraqi "provocations" "usually comes hours later and miles away, and ... may be delivered by different aircraft".

"Pilots now regularly carry a list of pre-approved 'response options' that can be bombed if the patrol encounters something considered an Iraqi threat ... the attack planes go directly to a target and drop bombs as a response to a perceived provocation".

The Post observed that "except in cases where they are in immediate danger ... pilots rarely respond directly".

Andrea Needham
Voices in the wilderness UK
voices@viwuk.freeserve.co.uk

webTitle: We still aim for an Aura of success

fields.headline: We still aim for an Aura of success
fields.trailText: The caricature painted of Eve Pollard and Parkhill Publishing by Marcelle D'Argy Smith is both spiteful and distorted (Ab Fab meets Fawlty Towers, Media, August 14).
fields.body:
The caricature painted of Eve Pollard and Parkhill Publishing by Marcelle D'Argy Smith is both spiteful and distorted (Ab Fab meets Fawlty Towers, Media, August 14).

Eve Pollard and the Parkhill staff produced two top-quality magazines - Wedding Day and Aura - on limited resources. Eve originated the ideas for both the titles. Ms D'Argy Smith's suggestion that she lacks magazine experience is ridiculous for the woman who was editor of Elle in the US, editor of You magazine, launched the Sunday Mirror magazine and began her journalistic life on Honey and Petticoat. Ms D'Argy Smith's assessment of the experience of other senior management was also wide of the mark.

Wedding Day's sale to Crimson Publishing, ensuring work for many of the staff, is evidence of the attractiveness of this title in a crowded market place.

When Eve addressed the staff to tell them that a voluntary liquidation was a possibility, she pledged to fight to save the magazines and that is what she is doing. Eve and Parkhill's management have talked to over 40 potential investors of buyers in order to save Aura and the company. Eve is the largest individual shareholder and, apart from the venture capitalists, has by far lost the most money.

The management decided to suspend Parkhill's operations when it appeared that the working capital requirements over the summer months would exceed the cash available. This is a direct function of the very long periods it takes to collect advertising and circulation revenue. The management hope to be able to safeguard creditors' positions by this rapid and responsible action. The sale of Wedding Day enhances the position of creditors including, of course, all freelance contributors.

Perhaps unwittingly, Ms D'Argy Smith has given an excellent pen portrait of a typical entrepreneur in full flight. If this effort had the side effect of ruffling a few feathers in the genteel world of magazine editorial, this is probably a price worth paying to ensure the commercial success of the enterprise. Full marks to Eve for having the courage to try.

Finally, if she had been a man, would the struggles of her small company have been so newsworthy? We doubt it.

George Moore, Carol North, Richard Burton, Wendy Henry
Parkhill Publishing

fields.headline: Vote for Toad
fields.trailText: We are not all nimbys in Cookham (Storm in the willows, August 15).
fields.body:
We are not all nimbys in Cookham (Storm in the willows, August 15). Some of us think the proposed car park - sympathetically landscaped in a tiny corner of the vast expanse of Marsh Meadow - will be of great benefit, enabling the existing car park, a terrible eyesore, to be removed. The Marsh Meadow Preservation Society is a tiny, although vociferous, minority, and the National Trust is in favour of the new proposals.

I hope the many visitors who come to Cookham will enjoy the scenery and the views for generations to come and be able to park their cars within easy reach of those things they have come to see.

Michelle Jones
Cookham, Berks

fields.headline: Goliardo Fiaschi
fields.standfirst: Anarchist loyal to his cause against fascist Italy and Franco's Spain
fields.trailText: In 1943, the young Italian anarchist, Goliardo Fiaschi, falsified his birth certificate - to make himself seem older than his 13 years - and joined the wartime Italian partisans. Armed with a captured rifle almost as big as himself, he accompanied the women who regularly crossed the Apennines on foot to carry food from Parma, Reggio or Modena, some 150 miles away, back to the starving inhabitants of his Tuscan birthplace, Massa di Carrara. fields.body:
In 1943, the young Italian anarchist, Goliardo Fiaschi, falsified his birth certificate - to make himself seem older than his 13 years - and joined the wartime Italian partisans. Armed with a captured rifle almost as big as himself, he accompanied the women who regularly crossed the Apennines on foot to carry food from Parma, Reggio or Modena, some 150 miles away, back to the starving inhabitants of his Tuscan birthplace, Massa di Carrara. In 1944, he was adopted as a mascot by the Costrignano Brigade, and, in that role, entered Modena as standard-bearer on its liberation in April 1945.

Fiaschi, who has died aged 69, was one of the youngest of the generation of anti- fascist partisans who fought against Mussolini's rule in Italy and Franco in Spain.

The natives of Carrara are reputedly descendants of Phoenician slaves who quarried marble for Rome. The city is also the cradle of Italian anarchism and a historical centre of rebellion. The fascist years in Italy, from 1922 onwards, were particularly bitter in Carrara. The city itself was twice liberated from the Nazis by anarchist partisans prior to the arrival of allied troops

After the liberation, Fiaschi returned to the quarries, where he had worked from the age of eight, alongside his father and uncle. fields.headline: A sporting chance
fields.trailText: Has the market mispriced Enic, the sports and media investment vehicle run by Daniel Levy? According to City dealers, Enic is valued at only a slight premium to its holding in intelligent software company Autonomy and its cash pile.
fields.body:
Has the market mispriced Enic, the sports and media investment vehicle run by Daniel Levy? According to City dealers, Enic is valued at only a slight premium to its holding in intelligent software company Autonomy and its cash pile.

Back-of-the-envelope calculations reveal that Enic's 4.5m Autonomy shares are worth around £156m. Added to its cash pile of £8m, this gives a figure of £171m, or 176p per share, which compares with last night's closing price of 183p and market capitalisation of £176m.

Of course there is more to Enic than cash and a stake in a high-flying software company. It also has a holding in Rangers FC worth £40m, stakes in a number of European football clubs worth about £25m, not to mention a £13m slice of AIM-listed Paradigm Media Investments and an online betting deal with Victor Chandler.

With downside limited, Enic shares look like a low risk flutter.

webTitle: How my good name was Wipo-ed out

fields.headline: How my good name was Wipo-ed out
fields.standfirst:
Net news

Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: My business has just been punched in the stomach. I paid $1,000 (£665) for the privilege. Eventually it might easily cost me over $100,000.
fields.body:
My business has just been punched in the stomach. I paid $1,000 (£665) for the privilege. Eventually it might easily cost me over $100,000.

I had asked the World Intellectual Property Organisation in Switzerland (Wipo) to help resolve a dot.com dispute. For almost 20 years I have been running a successful media business called Look-Hear. I own the registered trade mark in the name and have a thriving media website, www.look-hear.com, with visitors from around the globe.

But last year I discovered that a rival London media firm had registered www.lookhear.com. I knew there could not be two media businesses called Look Hear, just as there cannot be two businesses called Coca-Cola.

This is where Wipo came in. It has a division that deals with just this type of problem. Since last year it has decided on 369 dot.com cases.

In each case the decisions appeared to be consistent. When one side owned the business name and the registered trademark, and the other side had absolutely no rights or interests in the name, Wipo ordered that the domain be transferred to the rightful owner of the name.

But not in my case. The arbitrator, a London solicitor, ruled against me. He stated that, apart from the fact that I had a trademark certificate, he could not see what reputation I had in the name Look-Hear. In one sentence he appeared to blow away two decades of my hard work.

I admit that my business is nowhere near as famous as Coca-Cola, but over the years I have been building a genuine going concern. I went to the trouble of registering Look Hear as a trademark.

But all this counted for nothing. To help the arbitrator come to a decision, I prepared a 62-page document about the history of my business. I told them how, in 1983, I had left Roger Cook's BBC investigative programme at the BBC to start Look-Hear. How I had incorporated Look-Hear Ltd in 1984. And how I had also started Look-Hear Music in 1985. I showed them press clippings, company literature and photos of my multimedia products. But it did not impress the arbitrator.

I pointed to my website where I give details of my customers, multimedia programs and sales turnover. Just one of the programmes, People Power at Work, presented by Sue Lawley and John Humphrys, has achieved sales of about £1m. I told the arbitrator how successful I had been in stopping others from using the brand name. Usually such success is taken to indicate solid reputation in a trademark.

My lawyers assure me that were the rival site to be launched as a media website in any country where I own the trademark, I would have grounds to take action for trademark infringement and passing off. But that is little comfort to me.

Unfortunately, Wipo has no appeals procedure.
