fields.headline: Lord Scarsdale
fields.standfirst: Unlikely aristocrat who fought to save his stately home
fields.trailText: Lord Scarsdale, who has died aged 76, fought a dozen years of battles against the National Trust over its alterations to his ancestral home, Kedleston Hall in Derbyshire, and another 10 years trying to persuade the trust to take the place off his hands.
fields.body:
Lord Scarsdale, who has died aged 76, fought a dozen years of battles against the National Trust over its alterations to his ancestral home, Kedleston Hall in Derbyshire, and another 10 years trying to persuade the trust to take the place off his hands.

Francis John Nathaniel Curzon, the 3rd viscount, saw himself as "the 30th Lord of Kedleston in an unbroken male line of descent". His family stretches back 900 years, but his position was the result of the typical stipulation in the Scarsdale title - that it, and the estate, could go only to a male heir.

It was only after the first wife of his predecessor, the 2nd viscount, had produced four daughters, got divorced, and fathered no heirs with his second wife, that the 2nd viscount gave up hope of a male heir. As next in line, Francis Curzon, an old Etonian captain in the Scots Guards, and son of the third son of the 4th Baron Scarsdale, was invited by a cousin he hardly knew to see the estate for the first time in 1959.

Kedleston Hall has been one of the glories of Britain since the young Robert Adam rebuilt it for the first Baron Curzon in the 1760s, around his collection of Tintorettos, Poussins and Chippendale furniture. As the centre of an estate of 5,700 acres, it included a 500-acre park and an 18-hole golf course.

From 1970, Scarsdale took charge of his future inheritance as estate manager. He knew, even before death duties of £2.5m, that he could not keep up the property on the basis of income from the estate's 17 farms. "The house is a gigantic headache," he moaned.

Wanting to preserve it intact, he offered the pile to the nation, in lieu of death duties. The environment secretary Michael Heseltine was sympathetic, as were arts ministers Norman St John-Stevas and Lord Gowrie. Even Mrs Thatcher went to have a look.

But while waitingfor a decision, Scarsdale came into conflict with his son Peter, to whom he had promised a tenth of the estate if sold. Peter wanted to wait for a £25m offer from overseas, which never materialised. It took until 1987, a full decade, before the National Trust was willing to take over Ked- leston Hall and its estate, financed by an unprecedented £14m, mainly from the National Heritage Fund.

Lord Scarsdale made what seemed a generous deal with the trust. He and his family could live rent-free in a 23-room wing, with an adjoining garden and two rent-free flats for his servants or other family members. He could play billiards and hold parties in the main block, and shoot pheasants on the estate when it was closed to the public. Mean- while, the annual maintenance costs of £400,000 were to be met by members of the National Trust and 20,000 visitors.

The irritation came from differing interpretations of the word "consult" in Scarsdale's agreement with the trust. He thought he could veto any changes; the trust insisted he would only be informed, as a courtesy. He wanted the current hall reserved as a "family home"; the trust wanted it restored to its 1760s glory. Scarsdale attacked the trust's "arrogance", "vandalism" and "sacrilege" for such things as removing a fountain or a favourite piece of furniture.

He leaves two sons and a daughter by his first wife, Solange, and two sons by his second wife, Helene, whom he married in 1958. His eldest son, Peter Ghislain Nathaniel Curzon, becomes the 4th viscount.

 Francis John Nathaniel Curzon, 3rd Viscount Scarsdale, born July 28 1924; died August 2 2000

fields.headline: Benny Fenton
fields.standfirst: Footballer and manager devoted to his London clubs
fields.trailText: The footballer and manager Benny Fenton, who has died aged 81, was the quintessence of Cockneyism. Born in West Ham, he, like his older brother Ted, began his career with that club, but while Ted, a centre-half, stayed at Upton Park, Benny would migrate, though never very far from home. fields.body:
The footballer and manager Benny Fenton, who has died aged 81, was the quintessence of Cockneyism. Born in West Ham, he, like his older brother Ted, began his career with that club, but while Ted, a centre-half, stayed at Upton Park, Benny would migrate, though never very far from home. Initially an inside-right, at times a centre-forward - with quick responses and good feet - he moved to Millwall and, in January 1947, to Charlton Athletic, a top division club.

He was signed too late to figure in the ensuing FA Cup Final, which Charlton won, but went on to play in 264 games, scoring 54 goals for the club. He had succesfully converted to right-half and, a wily player rather than a hard one, was known for the innocence of his expression - "What, me ref?" - when typically stealing ground at a throw-in.

In the 1950-51 season, Fenton was made Charlton's captain, which, said a contemporary account, "sobered and improved his play immensely. An inspiration to his team." On retirement, he became, like Ted, a manager, and both of them in their turn took charge of Colchester United. Ted led them as a player-manager on a celebrated FA Cup run, when they were still a non-league side in 1947-48; Benny managed them between 1955 and 1963.

But Fenton's best years in management were at Millwall, between 1966 and 1974. Billy Gray, his predecessor, aided by his coach, Bill Dodgin Jr, had weaned the team on to a more technical, progressive game, and Fenton continued in this vein, though his ducking and diving under any kind of pressure became a byword.

There was, for example, the notorious Saturday afternoon when Millwall fans invaded the pitch and the referee was punched in the stomach. Ground closure loomed, by no means for the first time, and Fenton had to be very quick on his feet. Punched in the stomach, he said, never! Which raised the interesting possibility, as was said at the time, that the punch was self-inflicted.

Millwall, when Fenton took over, was still the only London club never to be promoted to the top division, and he could not quite get them there himself. In 1972, a single point divided them from Birmingham City, who beat them at St Andrew's in a crucial game. The very word "promotion" had been taboo to Fenton - and, at the mention of it, he reacted like a vampire confronted by a wreath of garlic.

Eamonn Dunphy's celebrated diary, Only A Game, the product of his days as a creative inside forward, somewhat lampoons Fenton, but Dennis Burnett, a defender, once persuaded to play with a burst blood vessel, called him "a good manager of men," while his centre-forward, Barry Bridges, an ex-England player said: "I've never seen a bunch of lads who put everything into their training as much as these lads. Benny's doing it all himself, and he's doing a hell of a good job. He wants everybody to look the part. Before you go out for the game, everything's got to be right, shorts have got to be pulled up, socks have got to be straight."

Alas, when it came to that Birmingham game, Fenton's nerve failed him. He played an ultra-defensive system and lost to what seemed an offside goal.

He was, nonetheless, a beguiling raconteur. One remembers, especially, a tale he told about Leslie Welch, the "memory man" who answered an infinity of sports queries on radio and in the music halls.

"Me and Ted are down at Southend, walking along the promenade, when who do we meet? Leslie Welch. He says, 'Hello lads, lovely to see you. I'm in a show down here; there's a couple of tickets. And lads, do me a favour. When I come on tonight, ask me this question!'

"And he gives it to us. So we're sitting there, Leslie comes on, Ted asks the question, and you know what he says? You know what he says? He says: 'Would you mind repeating that."'

Fenton's later years were spent, in various capacities, with Charlton. He latterly lived in Dorset, and is survived by his wife Winnie, whom he married on Christmas Day 1939, their daughter, two grandchildren and one great grandchild.

fields.headline: Dishing the dirt
fields.trailText: Anatomy Of Disgust | Brain Story | Glasgow Kiss | What A Performance!
fields.body:
It's nice to know that underneath all that artistic megalomania, boundless talent and Grand Guignol vision, Orson Welles was no scatologist. After all, you hear stories all the time - well, occasionally - of (self) important folks who have strange fetishes in that direction, as if high achieving is linked to weird pastimes like wearing nappies. (Indeed, if rumour is to be believed, there is a certain newspaper publisher who likes nothing better than a Saturday night in squatting over a glass coffee table). But not our Orson, as the excellent Anatomy Of Disgust (C4) made clear.

Filming the climax of the The Third Man, he was less than keen to descend into Vienna's sewers, so disgusted was he at the aromatic delights slooshing around down there. And frankly, who can blame him? Disgust, we were told, is the emotion of civilisation. It separates us from other animals, keeping us safe from unhygienic harm and, with disgust working from an ancient part of the brain, predating rational thought, helping us to climb the evolutionary pole.

Dr Val Curtis, an expert in disgust (though not in the same way William Hague is), has carried out research in Africa, Asia, Europe and India and has found the same responses crop up time and again: we don't like dirt. Faeces, urine, menstrual blood, yellow teeth all provoke disgust, regardless of where the survey is done (though South East Asians aren't so horrified by rotting meat and vegetables, which certainly explains why Imelda Marcos is still so popular).

There is even a Universal Facial Expression of Disgust, which is regularly demonstrated by Coronation Street's Jez Quigley who, per haps erroneously thinking it makes him seem scary, has adopted the look of someone who has doggie doo smeared on his top lip.

Curtis, who you probably wouldn't want to chat to at a party ("There are 15 different types of urine on those peanuts, I'd wager"), was nonetheless a joy in Anatomy Of Disgust, along with Mary Douglas, who famously argued that "dirt is matter out of place". Now in her 80s, Douglas's achievements and explorations could have made a documentary in themselves. But here she was, one of a host of nifty sociologists, anthropologists and other ologists who made this programme a joy to watch, even though its subject was wee and poo and other nasties (oddly, aubergines and courgettes never got a mention, but maybe that's next week).

Professor Susan Greenfield - who you would want to chat to a party and possibly cuddle up to in a taxi on the way home - was guiding us through how the brain develops in the glorious Brain Story (BBC2). Attacking the nature versus nurture debate from a different angle to Anatomy Of Disgust, Greenfield's programme made an interesting companion to its Channel 4 counterpart. Ultimately concerned with the same thing - how we are who were are - this was science programming at its very best. Brain Story explained the dynamism of the brain's circuitry, the dif ferences in the fine tuning and how these configurations make each one of us unique. This was thought-provoking stuff. And were its educational benefits not enough, we also got to see the foxy Prof Greenfield making pottery. Swoonsome.

Equally swoonsome was Glasgow Kiss (BBC1). Two-thirds of the way through its six-part run and the course of Stuart and Cara's love still isn't running smoothly. As Iain Glen and Sharon Small weave around each other like uncertain fireflies and their public and private lives orbit ever closer, promising collision, Glasgow Kiss's drama was upped to the nth degree, and it was like watching a pair of close friends having a crisis. While it may not now hold any huge surprises, it is warm, pithy, smart and gentle. A well polished gem, a diamond in the rough of current telly drama.

Not entirely unsurprisingly, comedy was the subject of What A Performance! (ITV), an undemanding look at what was billed as "off-the-wall" humour. Not that ITV needs any more encouragement to patch together a compilation programme (there is someone in Network Centre who incessantly made compilation tapes as a gangly adolescent), but with lunatic antics from Spike Milligan and the Monty Python team on display, this was quality stuff. And while it was also great to have Terry Jones, Harry Hill and Milligan on explaining madcap humour, it missed the point that such humour, like magic, is best left unexplained.

fields.headline: John Tukey
fields.standfirst: Pioneering mathematician who transformed the use of statistics
fields.trailText: The American John Tukey, who has died aged 85, was among the most inventive pure and applied mathematicians of the last 50 years. One of the most influential statisticians of his generation, he developed wide-ranging theories and ingenious techniques to analyse masses of complex data and compute series of numbers quickly.
fields.body:
The American John Tukey, who has died aged 85, was among the most inventive pure and applied mathematicians of the last 50 years. One of the most influential statisticians of his generation, he developed wide-ranging theories and ingenious techniques to analyse masses of complex data and compute series of numbers quickly.

His pioneering work for teasing out the hidden patterns and correlations in large amounts of data - now called data mining - had a profound impact in fields as diverse as electrical engineering, operations research, financial and business risk management, and the social sciences.

The early work for which Tukey was probably best known among his peers was his collaboration in 1965 with James Cooley, then working for IBM. Together, they developed the fast fourier transform, an algorithm (or math- ematical procedure run on a computer) that was applicable to a wide range of physical sciences and engineering research. It helped astron- omers, for example, to determine the spectrum of light from a star more quickly than previously possible.

An inspirational teacher, Tukey always told his students that "an approximate answer to the right question is worth a great deal more than a precise answer to the wrong question". His later work, on what statisticians call robust analysis, found ways of reaching credible conclusions even when working with flawed data.

The ideas and techniques he generated between 1946 and 1984, gathered in the eight volumes of The Collected Works Of John W Tukey, were the fruits of a career in which he held simultaneous posts as professor of statistics at Princeton University, and a researcher at the renowned Bell Laboratories. His work covered statistical topics, such as spectrum analysis, multiple comparisons and exploratory data analysis. His genius ranks alongside the like of Alan Turing in the advances he brought to communication theory and computing.

In 1944, Tukey coined the term "bit," an abbreviation of "binary digit", to describe the 1s and 0s that are the basis of the binary code in which all digital computer programs are produced. He was also credited with conceiving the word "software".

No stranger to controversy, Tukey was prepared to support unfashionable causes. In the 1950s, he attacked Alfred Kinsey's research on sexual behaviour, the conclusions of which he believed were seriously flawed because they relied on a sample of people who knew each other. Tukey said a random selection of three people would have been better than a group of 300 chosen by Kinsey.

In the 1970s, Tukey chaired a research committee that warned of the damage to the ozone layer from aerosol sprays. More recently, he recommended that the 1990 US census be adjusted by statistical formulae to compensate for the huge numbers of poor urban residents whom he believed it had missed. Always eager to apply statistics to new questions, from 1960 to 1980 he helped design the polls used by the NBC television network to predict and analyse American elections.

Tukey was born the only son of teachers in New Bedford, Massachusetts. His parents believed his talent would be best developed if he was educated at home, so his formal education began only when he entered Brown University, at Providence, Rhode Island. He graduated with a first in mathematics and chemistry and, in 1937, went to Princeton, where he obtained a PhD in mathematics in 1939 for a thesis on denumerability in topology.

During the second world war, he was engaged on strategic research that involved statistics, work he found fascinating, especially since it involved rubbing shoulders with other statisticians recruited to Princeton for the war effort. In particular, he met William Cochran, the brilliant Cambridge mathematician, who had moved to the US.

For Tukey, this was the start of a long and fruitful exchange of ideas with Cochran and other senior researchers. In 1945, he was offered a post in statistics within the mathematics department at Princeton, and, at the age of 35, was made a full professor. In 1965, he became founding chairman of Princeton's statistics department. One post was not, however, enough to absorb his energy, and, in 1945, he also joined Bell Laboratories.

The modern science of statistics is more than 100 years old. Tukey believed that, after the first 40 years, its practitioners lost sight of its original objectives of finding methods of analysing data that described patterns, trends, and relationships, and detected anomalies. In 1962, he maintained that mathematical statistics was ignoring real-world data analysis. He urged a return to the origins of scientific statistics, using modern methods in which the statistical description of the data was paramount.

Tukey proved his case by developing exploratory data analysis, a philosophy that returned to the original goals of statistics, but relied on modern computer methods. It is now a widely accepted technique, due, in large part, to the growth in desktop computers and the explosion of data for which traditional statistics is not suitable.

With an emphasis on graphic display, it initially gave mathematicians new ways to analyse and present data clearly. More refined versions of the technique let people with no statistical expertise discover what patterns, relationships or trends might lie hidden in the data they needed to examine.

One of those tools, the stem-and-leaf display, remains in the high school curriculum. Students use the technique to arrange a series of data points in rows and columns, and then make judgments about what techniques - such as calculating the average or median - would allow them to analyse the information intelligently. The method of displaying data confirmed Tukey's belief that mathematicians should start with their data, and then look for a theorem to interpret it.

Over the years, he became a hub for regular scientific meetings of a group of Princeton professors, including Lyman Spitzer, who inspired the Hubble space telescope. In his work on the philosophy of statistics and of research, Tukey balanced the usefulness and limitation of mathematical statistics.

Tukey had no immediate survivors. Elizabeth, his wife of 48 years, died in 1998.

 John Wilder Tukey, mathematician, born June 16 1915; died July 26 2000

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Enemy Of The State | Body Heat | Your Friends & Neighbors | A Tale Of Two Cities
fields.body:
Enemy Of The State

(Tony Scott, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

Basically an adrenalin-crazed reworking of The Conversation. Tellingly, Gene Hackman, star of the 70s Coppola thriller, appears here too, as the veteran surveillance man winkled out of hiding to rescue Will Smith's innocent attorney from a murder rap concocted by government spooks. The snappy pairing.

Body Heat
(Lawrence Kasdan, 1981)

10pm, Sky Cinema

Kasdan's stylish, steamy homage to film noir in general and hardboiled novelist James M Cain in particular is set in an 80s Florida steeped in the amoral sleaze of the 40s thrillers. Kathleen Turner's Matty Walker, persuading William Hurt's lawyer Ned Racine to murder her husband, ranks with the great femme fatales, while Hurt is the archetypal fall-guy, dragged low by a salty mix of sex and greed.

Your Friends & Neighbors

(Neil LaBute, 1998)

10.10pm, Sky Premier

Writer-director LaBute expands the brutal misogyny of his debut, In The Company Of Men, into full-scale misanthropy, creating a closed system of six characters and pretty much making us detest all of them. It's joyously acidic though; actors like Catherine Keener, Ben Stiller and Jason Patric make the most of some hilariously scathing dialogue, and all are made to reveal the selfish and basic urges beneath their cultured exteriors. Apart from the literal and metaphorical shaftings, not a great deal happens, but there's a wealth of domestic observation and home truths here.

A Tale Of Two Cities

(Jack Conway, 1936)

2.55am, TCM

Vintage screen Dickens with a cutting edge: the French terror is vividly, hauntingly realised, all chaos and guillotine ghouls. Dashing Ronald Colman plays Sidney Carton, a selfish soul ennobled by love. Colman finely underplays, eschewing the matinee-idol mannerisms for a more workaday heroism: a far, far better thing.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What Butlins Redcoats are watching
fields.trailText: What Butlins Redcoats are watching
fields.body:
Julia Wier: "I mainly watch game shows. At 4pm It's Fifteen-To-One - I like questions and general knowledge, it keeps me on my toes. And that Countdown - there's numbers on there and everything. We all sit around, cup of tea, watching it and playing along. Everyone says I should go on as I get the conundrum, but I'm too shy really; and I don't really fancy winning a dictionary. But I'd love to meet Richard and Carol. I like intelligent women. I like X-Files too - all crime and supernatural stuff. I'm in to weird and wonderful - ghosts, UFOs etc."

Suzanne Biddle: "I'm on the evening shift so I like to watch kids stuff in the day. You see I'm a bit of a kid at heart - Mopatop's Shop is me fave; Jim Henson - I'm into all of them. I'm into cartoons as well, like Fly Tales. Haven't you seen it? The fly goes around, eating everything. I like Corry. I'm from up North. All right ducky and that. My real ambition would be to have my own programme like Ant and Dec - get to meet all those pop stars."

Rob Sugar: "I like Richard And Judy - they're brilliant. Just like being in your living room, really down to earth. I don't like those hospital ones, like that vets' one. It has to be Ready, Steady, Cook though. Actually I went for an audition last week. We had to act out emptying out the contents. They had lookalikes there from James Bond - Jaws and Oddjob. I'm keeping my fingers crossed."

Jamie Thompson: "It's Big Brother for me. Who do I like? Caroline. Couldn't believe she was kicked out. Without her there's no programme. I voted 22 times to get Thomas out. I like people programmes - fly on the wall, Airline, Zoo-Keepers, all that. And The Simpsons - you can relate to it. There are hidden jokes that you get that others don't. It's very clever. What I'd love to do is something like Jim Davidson's show - bring variety shows back to the forefront. You see, Stars In Their Eyes is all about lookalikes and not real talent. Right, I'm off to go and vote to kick that Thomas out again.

 Jemima Sissons talked to Redcoats in Bognor Regis.

fields.headline: Makeover day for brewers
fields.standfirst: Market forces  Neil Hume
fields.trailText: Investors were taking a fresh look at unfashionable pub and brewery stocks yesterday following news that a private equity company was stalking the largest regional brewer in Britain.
fields.body:
Investors were taking a fresh look at unfashionable pub and brewery stocks yesterday following news that a private equity company was stalking the largest regional brewer in Britain.

Shares in Wolverhampton & Dudley surged 80p to 455p after Botts & Company - which normally specialises in providing equity for media, luxury goods and information technology companies - emerged as a potential suitor for the manufacturer of Banks's and Pedigree beers.

Botts has teamed up with Robert Breare, the chairman of Noble House Leisure and former head of the Alchemy-backed pubs group InnSpired, for a possible offer. It is in the process of setting up talks with the company.

Analysts were not surprised by the development. The low valuation of the company is, they say, evidence that equity investors have little interest in a company that has failed to create a successful growth strategy - and in an industry that is facing long-term margin pressure.

They also noted that Botts may be only one of several private equity bidders interested in W&D. At their most basic, companies like W&D are attractive to private equity firms because their cashflow allows them make highly leveraged takeover bids.

However, a move by another private equity firm or even a pub company such as Punch is not likely to come until the office of fair trading has completed its review of the beer orders; the limit on the number of pubs brewers may own or deal with. The OFT's findings are expected any day.

Nevertheless, with several other companies in the sector trading at discount to net asset value, further consolidation is expected - and yesterday, investors were placing their bets.

Greene King, which pipped W&D to the post in the battle for Morland, was the favourite, rising 16p to 490p, while Regent Inns gained 1.5p to 128p and Eldridge Pope added 9p to 205.5p. Analysts at Deutsche Bank reckon that the move for W&D highlights the value in Greene King, which is cheap on fundamentals.

Leading shares, meanwhile, closed higher for a second consecutive session, lifted by strength in the oil, banking and telecoms sectors.

The FTSE 100 gauge closed 55.6 points higher at 6,475.5, as market turnover hit 1.35bn by 6.00pm last night.

Among the leaders, ARM Holdings advanced 25p to 689.5p, lifted by the return to form of semiconductor stocks in the US on Monday night. Elsewhere in the sector, optical chip specialist Bookham Technology rose 85p to £36.00. Goldman Sachs is said to have set a £60 target price for the stock.

Steel group Corus, off 3.5p at 73p, was again under pressure, this time from a negative research note from Merrill Lynch. The broker has cut its near-term rating on the steel group to "reduce" from "neutral", and has lowered its dividend forecast for 2000 to 3p from 6p. The moves reflect the impact of sterling strength on Corus.

Outside the leading index, materials and metals specialist Bodycote International was again the focus of takeover speculation, with shares closing 15.5p stronger at 208p as talk of a management buyout gathered pace.

According to the gossips a deal very similar to that which saw McKechnie , down 1.5p to 390p, taken private is being put together.

About 3.8m Bodycote shares changed hands, but a spokesman said he was not aware of any approach; Bodycote publishes interim figures on August 23.

Shares in video compression specialist Geo Interactive Media shot up 105p to £12.80, helped by short covering and wild rumours of a link between Ericsson and Samsung, which licences some of Geo Interactive's technology.

On AIM, late night bar operator Po Na Na made a solid debut, closing at 172.5p - up 10.5p from its placing price.

Analysts at Deutsche Bank reckon that the move for W&D highlights the value in Greene King, which is cheap on fundamentals. Leading shares, meanwhile, closed higher for a second consecutive session, lifted by strength in the oil, banking and telecoms sectors. The FTSE 100 gauge closed 55.6 points higher at 6,475.5, as market turnover hit 1.35bn by 6.00pm last night. Among the leaders, ARM Holdings advanced 25p to 689.5p, lifted by the return to form of semiconductor stocks in the US on Monday night. Elsewhere in the sector, optical chip specialist Bookham Technology rose 85p to £36.00. Goldman Sachs is said to have set a £60 target price for the stock. Steel group Corus, off 3.5p at 73p, was again under pressure, this time from a negative research note from Merrill Lynch. The broker has cut its near-term rating on the steel group to "reduce" from "neutral", and has lowered its dividend forecast for 2000 to 3p from 6p. The moves reflect the impact of sterling strength on Corus. Shares in video compression specialist Geo Interactive Media shot up 105p to £12.80, helped by short covering and wild rumours of a link between Ericsson and Samsung, which licences some of Geo Interactive's technology. On AIM, late night bar operator Po Na Na made a solid debut, closing at 172.5p - up 10.5p from its placing price.

fields.headline: Primate investigator
fields.standfirst: She spent four years studying chimpanzees in the jungles of Burundi, and certainly knows her pongidae from her hylobatidae. So why is she being hailed as the new Charlie Dimmock?  Emma Brockes  meets Charlotte Uhlenbroek, TV's latest wildlife expert
fields.trailText: She spent four years studying chimpanzees in the jungles of Burundi, and certainly knows her pongidae from her hylobatidae. So why is she being hailed as the new Charlie Dimmock? Emma Brockes meets Charlotte Uhlenbroek, TV's latest wildlife expert
fields.body:
Charlotte Uhlenbroek's appearance on television tonight has been sold as a tantalising new chapter in wildlife documentary. In the three-part series, called Cousins, the 33-year-old zoologist promises to make some startling revelations about the monkey world. But this isn't what's got critics gasping for oxygen like expiring fish. The combination of Uhlenbroek's youth, her PhD and her long, swishy hair has proved too much for certain elements of the press, who have heralded her as the "sexy new female David Attenborough", and, more desperately, "the new Charlie Dimmock".

In mannerism, in fact, Uhlenbroek is more like David Bellamy, wriggling about in her chair and flexing her hands as she strives to communicate her passion for primates. She is not glamorously dressed, but in baggy jeans and big trainers befitting a woman who spent four years in a shack in the Burundian jungle, monitoring chimpanzee behaviour. Her hair, however, shoulder-length and wavering, is emphatically impractical and when asked if she resents the slant of the pre-programme coverage, she looks cheekily delighted. "I've heard mention that I'm going to do for primates what Charlie Dimmock did for water features, and that's fine. I think Charlie is absolutely great, I think she's very natural and enthusiastic about her subject." Uhlenbroek quickly adds, "Of course, I wouldn't like the focus to shift off the wildlife too much."

Just as Dimmock shone like a rare orchid beside the dumpy Alan Titchmarsh, so Uhlenbroek's on-screen glamour gains much from the fact that her only competition is a bunch of apes. Her energy and obvious love for her subject are, however, genuinely attractive. On several occasions, she almost levitates out of the chair with the excitement of explaining the habits of a particular species. "There's a tendency to think of chimps as amusing caricatures of humans," she says, leaning urgently forward. "But they are sophisticated animals in their own right. Although the development of chimps and humans is comparable in primitive terms until about the age of three, after that we go our separate ways." It is her aim in Cousins to explain where the two species run into each other again, and by doing so, to shed light on the fundamental question of what it means to be human.

Uhlenbroek's first encounter with a primate came when she was 15 and on holiday in Tanzania, although it was not her first encounter with the jungle. She is well qualified to spend long stretches in distant lands, because her childhood left her with indistinct notions of home. Her Dutch father, an agricultural specialist for the United Nations, and her English mother, brought her up in Kathmandu, Nepal, before moving to Tanzania when Uhlenbroek was 14 and sending her to boarding school in England.

"I suppose that culturally, I am mostly English. I've spent a lot of time in English schools. Even when I was in Nepal I was at an American school. I've never lived in Holland, and although I'm proud of my roots there, I can't say that I'm culturally Dutch. But in terms of where I'm at home, I am a bit of a nomad. It means that I feel at home in most places."

The emotional investment she makes in her research projects is such that, the first time she touched down in Burundi, she felt the euphoria one only gets on returning home. "I had never been to Burundi before, but I had the feeling that I was happy to be home." It was the culmination of seven years' work in the footsteps of her role model, Jane Goodall. Uhlenbroek was introduced to Goodall at the age of 15 whilst out in Tanzania. The groundbreaking primatologist had struck the young Uhlenbroek as "extraordinary", and the job she was doing, monitoring primate communities, as "fantastic".

When she left school, Uhlenbroek enrolled for a bachelor's degree in zoology and psychology at Bristol University, then got a job as a researcher in the BBC's natural history unit in Bristol. It was while she was there that, one evening at the pub, a colleague casually asked if she'd heard that Jane Goodall was looking for volunteers to set up a primate project in Burundi. "I literally left my beer on the table and headed straight for the payphone and rang her. I said: 'Can I go?' And she said: 'Send me your CV'. Things went on from there."

Over 80% of primatology PhD students are women, a fact that, quite nauseatingly, has been attributed by some observers to the likeness of a chimpanzee to a baby human. Uhlenbroek rejects this as fanciful: "I don't think it's that at all. All the women I've met that do primatology are very interested in animal behaviour. I'm sure they find the little ones sweet, but I don't think that's the primary motivation. One of the reasons that so many women have gone into primatology is because the stage was set by people like Jane Goodall and Dian Fossey of Gorillas in the Mist fame, and prior to that it never occurred to them that it was something they could do."

Uhlenbroek's flourishing television career happened by default, she says, whilst conceding that she has taken to it extremely well. "It never crossed my mind to work in television, which is stupid because it's a great job. I should have thought of it a while ago." She was given an "easy" introduction to the camera six years ago, when the BBC invited her to make a programme called Chimpanzee Diary whilst doing her PhD with Goodall in Burundi. She hit on a style of delivery that involved speaking to the camera as if to an old friend and ad-libbing from a very informal script.

The reaction to her growing celebrity in the academic world has been surprisingly good, particularly since "pop scientists" like Susan Greenfield are routinely sniped at by less celebrated colleagues for selling their subject short. But Uhlenbroek insists she is not compromising the complexity of her field by presenting it to a television audience. "I believe that there's no concept that is too complex to talk about in ordinary language. One of the problems I find with research is that you always have to address everything in very dry, academic terms to a very narrow audience, and I think that science is something that should be shared with the general population. I don't think you become inaccurate just by talking in normal language. I love it."

She does miss the depth of doing non-televised research, and she finds trying to play the fame game in the middle of the jungle ludicrous. Tight BBC budgets have so far kept living conditions on location as basic as her student digs, but Uhlenbroek had the experience of filming for the American TV show Prime Time Live. "It was like Hollywood descending. There were suddenly satellite phones all over the place, showers rigged up, these amazing meals. That's not the BBC's style and I prefer it that way. If you're in the bush, you might as well be in the bush." Just as long as you have a good hairdryer.

 Cousins is on BBC1 tonight at 7pm

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Big C | Tom Jones - In His Own Words
fields.body:
Imagine the worldwide panic were fifty jumbo jets to crash every day with no survivors. Yet, as Geoff Watts points out in The Big C (9.0pm, Radio 4), we don't turn a hair when that many cigarette smokers die prematurely each year. They, of course, have the courtesy to go quietly. With government campaigns gradually reducing the smoking habit in industrialised countries, the tobacco giants have targeted the third world. Thailand is fighting back with religion: its highly influential monks are legally forbidden to smoke on duty.

After 35 years in showbiz the Welsh heart-throb with the brass lungs launches a six-episode autobiography, Tom Jones - In His Own Words (10.0pm, Radio 2). In the best tradition, Jones's first record flopped. Then the BBC wouldn't play his second, deeming it "far too hot". Fortunately the pirate station Radio Caroline thought It's Not Unusual was wonderful and went on plugging it until it reached the top of the charts.

fields.headline: Once upon a time ...
fields.standfirst:
The BBC disinters a much-loved tradition
Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Sometimes the best kind of progress is based on undoing changes ordered in previous bouts of progress. The new controller of BBC Radio 4, Helen Boaden, yesterday announced a daring year-long experiment in the form of a magazine programme for children aged around eight to 10, based on the old-fashioned art of storytelling - largely banished from the schedules by her predecessor James Boyle.
fields.body:
Sometimes the best kind of progress is based on undoing changes ordered in previous bouts of progress. The new controller of BBC Radio 4, Helen Boaden, yesterday announced a daring year-long experiment in the form of a magazine programme for children aged around eight to 10, based on the old-fashioned art of storytelling - largely banished from the schedules by her predecessor James Boyle. "I don't expect to recreate Listen with Mother," she added - rather unnecessarily perhaps, since the progamme she plans is aimed at an age group which does not need and may not want mother there while it is listening.

Ms Boaden is bravely reversing the assumption which has taken hold over the years at the BBC and almost everywhere else that children nowadays are simply too restless, too intent on catching up with new music, too keen to gossip about pop stars and boyfriends and girlfriends, too eager to sally out and have fun, for anything so inherently tranquil as tuning into the radio and sitting quite still and imbibing. And maybe that will prove to be true. Maybe a great cry of "boring" will arise from a million homes. Maybe at the end of its year's probation Ms Boaden's new concoction will be sent the way of Toytown by SG Hulme Beaman, and Norman and Henry Bones, boy detectives, and other star attractions of the BBC's long ago Children's Hour.

But maybe it will not. In an age where bookshops stay open till midnight and are stormed by clamorous queues eager to get their hands on the new Harry Potter, it seems hopelessly pessimistic to say that one cannot build an audience for a meaty, dramatic and well-told story, whether told by someone resolutely old-fashioned like Alan Bennett or by some big name imported from the world of celebrity music. Ms Boaden is to be congratulated on this splendid example of radical, progressive reversion to previous practice. We will be tuning in, fingers crossed, when the great day comes.

webTitle: Russia blasts allied raids on Iraq

fields.headline: Russia blasts allied raids on Iraq
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Russia condemned American and British air raids on Iraq as a violation of international law yesterday, and called for them to be stopped immediately.
fields.body:
Russia condemned American and British air raids on Iraq as a violation of international law yesterday, and called for them to be stopped immediately.

A foreign ministry statement said: "Strikes against Iraqi territory do nothing but increase tensions in the region."

Allied aircraft resumed their attacks in the southern no-fly zone last weekend after a six-week lull, killing two people and injuring more than 20, according to the Iraqis.

Washington and London said they attacked air defence sites after Iraq opened fire on planes patrolling the no-fly zone.

Baghdad said the raids, on Samawa, 170 miles south of the capital, hit a railway station and a warehouse storing goods imported under the UN oil-for-food programme.

"The destruction of food supply outlets does most harm to common Iraqis who are experiencing colossal suffering from the sanctions," the Russian statement said.

In 1990 Moscow supported the allies' intervention after Iraq invaded Kuwait, but since then it has distanced itself from US policy and has pushed for the early lifting of UN sanctions.

Recently it suggested that the US and Britain would have to suspend air strikes in the no-fly zones before Iraq would open its doors to the new UN weapons inspection team, Unmovic.

Russian flagged tankers have been implicated in sanctions-busting exports of Iraqi oil.

fields.headline: No: 1700
fields.standfirst: Daphna Stern
fields.trailText: Daphna Stern
fields.body:
Occupation:
Photocopy girl.

Are you sure? Haven't I seen that body somewhere before?
Possibly.

I could have sworn she was that model - you know, the one known as the "bird from Brazil".
The "boobs from Brazil" you mean - Gisele Bundchen, the superest of supermodels. And that's what the guys at GQ magazine thought, too.

Is that the reason they hired her to do their photocopying?
Maybe. But she proved very handy to have around when they needed an emergency cover model.

That's where I've seen her! So you mean that isn't really Gisele on the cover of the current issue, even though it says Gisele in big letters?
Not all her, no. The face is Gisele's, but everything else is Daphna's.

Isn't that a bit naughty?
Not if you call it art. The image used on the cover was actually an "airbrush painting" based on Gisele and Daphna.

So is there something wrong with Gisele's body, then?
Not that we're aware of. They just didn't have quite the right shots of her.

You mean they couldn't afford her.
Neither could you - she charges up to £250,000 for a day's work.

Still, Daphna's not a bad substitute.
Her proportions match Gisele's exactly, from the 32C bust downwards. And her mum's from Argentina.

The "boobs from Buenos Aires", you could say.
I suppose you could.

Shame the fluffy dog ruins the image.
Quite the opposite. Gisele's got one too.

Daphna's destined for the catwalk herself, no doubt.
Actually she's a law graduate, and her real ambitions lie in journalism.

Can she write?
Who cares?

Don't be pathetically laddish. She's obviously very intelligent.
Not to mention rich. Her German dad's a property magnate.

Do say:
"I think the A3 tray's out of paper."

Don't say:
"You're very beautiful, you know. You should be a model."

Not to be confused with:
Who do you think?

fields.headline: Disputes delay Tomb Raider takeover
fields.trailText: Disagreements over price and the size of bonuses awarded to key Eidos directors are thought to be delaying a possible bid for the British computer games firm by its French rival, Infogrames.
fields.body:
Disagreements over price and the size of bonuses awarded to key Eidos directors are thought to be delaying a possible bid for the British computer games firm by its French rival, Infogrames.

Eidos confirmed yesterday that it remains in talks with a potential bidder, eight weeks after saying it had received an approach. The takeover panel is understood to have prompted Eidos to update the market amid growing concern that a bid may never materialise and frustration in the City at the lack of clear information from the company.

Shares in Eidos climbed 12p to 425p. However, sources close to Eidos last night indicated that the two parties remained some distance apart on price.

Infogrames executives are also thought to be concerned by the annual bonuses of £4m awarded to Eidos director Jeremy Heath-Smith. Chief executive Charles Cornwall received a bonus of £800,000 in the year to the end of March.

Mr Heath-Smith is the managing director of Core Design, the subsidiary which is responsible for Eidos' key franchise, Tomb Raider, and his bonus is directly linked to the performance of Core Design.

Declining sales of Tomb Raider games was one of the key reasons behind the profits warnings that shattered Eidos' share price and led to a bid approach.

fields.trailText:
• Outsourced

Brewing group Whitbread is to contract out its central data technology services in a £50m seven-year deal with Computer Sciences Corporation . "This agreement will help overcome sector skill shortages, maintain our pace with evolving technologies and achieve cost savings," said Whitbread.
fields.body:
 Outsourced

Brewing group Whitbread is to contract out its central data technology services in a £50m seven-year deal with Computer Sciences Corporation . "This agreement will help overcome sector skill shortages, maintain our pace with evolving technologies and achieve cost savings," said Whitbread.

 Hits

In all countries except the US, online networks and ISPs topped the list of the most widely visited categories, according to a report from analyst Media Metrix yesterday. In the US, users flocked to services sites that provide chat, e-mail, cash or prize incentives, downloads or coupons, the report said.

 Acquisition

fields.headline: German auction could net £30bn
fields.trailText: Proceeds from the auction of third generation mobile phone licences in Germany could hit DM100bn (£30bn), according to one of the Berlin's government's top economic advisers.
fields.body:
Proceeds from the auction of third generation mobile phone licences in Germany could hit DM100bn (£30bn), according to one of the Berlin's government's top economic advisers.

Yesterday the bidding topped DM85bn after 150 rounds - four times the amount pencilled in by the Berlin administration - as the six remaining bidders battled it out for a licence in Europe's biggest market. So far only one bidder has dropped out.

"It looks like the state will take in DM80bn to DM100bn," said Rolf Peffekoven, one of the government's council of independent advisers, known as the "wise men".

As the bidding entered what could be its final phase yesterday, the telecoms regulator cut the amount by which new bids have to top existing offers from 10% to 5%.

The result of the German auction will reignite the debate about the cost of 3G licences which started after Britain raised £22.5bn from the sale of five licences.

Governments have taken different approaches to the question of how licences should be sold. Critics of the auction process argue that the high prices paid in Britain and now in Germany could mean that new networks will be rolled out more slowly or that services will be expensive as the bidders seek to recoup costs.

A number of analysts have cut their earnings forecasts for the sector and the big players have seen the cost of licences weighing on their share prices. Shares in Deutsche Telekom have fallen from a peak ahead of the British auction of 103.9 euros to just below 50 euros while France Telecom shares are down from 219 euros to 139 euros over a similar period.

Yesterday one City broker, Charles Stanley, put out a "sell" note on Vodafone citing, among other factors, the amount the company would be spending on third generation mobile phone licences.

Finland offered its licences for free in the hope that would bring new services to the market quickly and cheaply. Spain, which used the "beauty contest" route rather than an auction, pulled in 500m euros (£300m).

Not all auctions have proved successful. Holland raised only 2.7bn euros, but the German experience will put pressure on other governments to raise as much as they can.

Yesterday, for example, Mr Peffekoven argued that the proceeds from the mobile phone licence auction should be used to reduce debt. "That will give annual interest savings of between DM3bn to DM3.5bn."

In France, one of the biggest markets where licences have yet to be awarded, the government has already decided to set a fixed price for the four licences on offer, which will raise a total of 19.8bn euros, and will pick the winners on the basis of their business plans.

Italy is going for a hybrid which combines elements of both the auction and beauty contest methods with the government looking to raise a figure in the region of 13bn euros.

Britain's BT and Vodafone are both heavily involved in the bidding for a German licence and both will be contenders for licences in France and Italy through existing joint venture or consortium partnerships.

The cost of the licences is already having an effect. Deutsche Telekom, which has won licences in Britain and Holland and is a front runner in Germany, has said it will not bid for a licence in Italy.

The German group does not have a mobile presence in Italy and believes it would be expensive to build up a network and customer base from scratch.

"We do not want to be the fifth provider. it will be very costly," said a spokesman for the German group. It will, however, be bidding in France.

fields.headline: Kohl spares party blushes
fields.standfirst:
Ex-chancellor bowed out of reunification celebrations to defuse row

Special report: the German corruption scandal
fields.trailText: On November 28 1989 Helmut Kohl, then the Germany chancellor, rose to his feet in the Bundestag, the lower house of parliament, and declared that reuniting East and West Germany was his aim.
fields.body:
On November 28 1989 Helmut Kohl, then the Germany chancellor, rose to his feet in the Bundestag, the lower house of parliament, and declared that reuniting East and West Germany was his aim.

It was just three weeks since the breaching of the Berlin Wall. Around the world politicians, diplomats and ordinary people were struggling to come to terms with what that could mean, given Germany's grim wartime history. Reunification was far from a foregone conclusion.

Mr Kohl said: "Nobody knows now what a reunited Germany will look like. But I am sure that unity will come if the German people want it."

Less than a year later, on October 3 1990, the former East Germany rejoined the federal republic - and the skill and decisiveness with which Mr Kohl managed the reunification and cajoled fellow world leaders into endorsing it appeared to secure his reputation as a great statesmen.

He could scarcely have believed then that a decade later his standing would have fallen so far that he could not even attend the 10th anniversary of his greatest achievement.

But he has decided to stay away from the next month's ceremony to spare everyone's blushes. Since last November he was been embroiled in a still-unresolved controversy which has shown that he and his party took millions of pounds worth of illegal party contributions.

A parliamentary commission of inquiry is examining whether the secret donations were made in exchange for favours from his government.

Mr Kohl vehemently denies that allegation, but by his decision to stay away he has tacitly admitted that he is no longer a celebrity, but an embarrassment.

He said on Monday that he would not attend the 10th German Unity Day celebrations, in order to end a row over whether he should take part. He had been invited as a guest to the event, in Dresden, but was not invited to speak - an omission that brought complaints from other politicians.

Nevertheless, as German commentators noted yesterday, by his actions Mr Kohl has kept open divisions in his own party, the Christian Democrats (CDU), and shown that he retains the power to cause serious trouble for its new leader, Angela Merkel.

The decision not to allow him to speak was taken by Kurt Biedenkopf, the Christian Democrat leader of the state government in Saxony, of which Dresden is the capital. He was a leading critic of Mr Kohl, and Mr Kohl, a formidable party wheeler-dealer, reacted by derailing Mr Biedenkopf's political career.

Mr Biedenkopf's attitude drew criticism from Kohl loyalists and even an implied rebuke from the party's new general secretary, Ruprecht Polenz, who said: "Personally, I would have welcomed it if Kohl had given a speech in Dresden."

A ruling for or against the decision had been expected from Ms Merkel, who incurred Mr Kohl's wrath herself by being the first leading Christian Democrat to distance herself from him as the scandal unfolded.

By taking the issue out of her hands, the Mr Kohl has not only strengthened his own reputation for decisiveness but reinforced the growing suspicion that indecision is Ms Merkel's achilles heel.

The centre-left Berlin newspaper Der Tagesspiegel said yesterday: "The CDU has still not made clear its relationship with its erstwhile patriarch . . . Merkel wants to step out of Kohl's shadow, but the party is reluctant to let her. And Kohl even more so."

His reputation may be in ruins, but Mr Kohl's capacity for mischief remains immense.

webTitle: MPs call for open skies timetable

fields.headline: MPs call for open skies timetable
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: MPs yesterday attacked the United States for its "intransigence"on a new "open skies" policy for flights between Britain and America.
fields.body:
MPs yesterday attacked the United States for its "intransigence"on a new "open skies" policy for flights between Britain and America.

A report from the Commons environment, transport and regional affairs committee has called for the US to change existing legislation which gives its own airlines priority within the US.

"The United States has proved to be intransigent about its domestic legislation relating to cabotage - reserving internal flights to US carriers - to airline ownership and Fly America. The current proposal to accept a more liberal air services agreement in return for permitting alliances between airlines in order to allow UK airlines to gain access to the US domestic market may lead to a deal in the short term, but such a deal should include a clear timetable for the lifting of US restrictions on cabotage and airline ownership and Fly America policy," says the report.

Only a handful of carriers, such as British Airways and Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Atlantic, are allowed to operate transatlantic services into and out of Heathrow airport. British carriers have restrictions on US destinations. The report says a new agreement will bring advantages to Britain's airlines, consumers and the economy as a whole.

fields.headline: Pan-Europe wants more of Telewest
fields.trailText: United Pan-Europe Communications, Europe's largest cable television business, yesterday gave further hints that Telewest's days as an independent company could be numbered.
fields.body:
United Pan-Europe Communications, Europe's largest cable television business, yesterday gave further hints that Telewest's days as an independent company could be numbered.

Mark Schneider, UPC chief executive, said the Netherlands-based company remains keen to increase its 25% holding in Telewest, the second largest cable firm in Britain. But he suggested that a deal could instead be brokered with Telewest's main rival, NTL, which has interests across Europe.

"Telewest belongs with either us or NTL at some point," he said, adding that Telewest was too small to fully fund the investments needed to offer an interactive cable service. "It needs to be rationalised. Capital is king and at some point these companies will come togther out of necessity."

The future ownership of Telewest has come under intense speculation since its share price was laid low by an admission that the company was suffering a shortage of the set-top boxes needed for digital services. The company, which has 1.2m subscribers, is three months behind schedule. It had hoped to get 500,000 digital customers by the end of the year but has now put that target back to the first quarter of 2001.

Any change in ownership of Telewest would probably be done on an agreed basis as UPC and Microsoft between them own about 50% of the company. In a complex web of ownerships Microsoft also has a small stake in NTL as well as an investment in UPC.

Mr Schneider criticised the investment community for being too short term in its assessment of Telewest and for failing to appreciate the potential for digital services such as broadband internet access and video-on-demand. "This is only the beginning of the battle," he said. "Investors look two months ahead when they should be looking years ahead."

Shares in Telewest, which reached 563p during the internet mania in March, yesterday edged up 4.5p to 170p.

UPC, which has also been hit by problems in the roll out of digital services, recorded a 19% increase in revenues for the second quarter to 238m euros (£143m) while losses were cut by 21% to 368m euros - beating the expectations of analysts.

UPC said that it had 7m basic cable television subscribers at the end of the period while its internet customer base had grown to 230,000.

Microsoft, which is supplying software for UPC's set-top boxes for the company's planned digital service, has said it will fail to meet a September deadline, and the cable group is shopping around for alternative basic software to enable its October launch.

webTitle: Test of vocal cords is a scream for Polish winner

fields.headline: Test of vocal cords is a scream for Polish winner
fields.trailText: A young Polish woman has become Europe's screaming champion for the second time, beating 300 rivals from many parts of the world.
fields.body:
A young Polish woman has become Europe's screaming champion for the second time, beating 300 rivals from many parts of the world.

Dagmara Stanek, 25, from the Baltic resort of Sopot, emitted a scream of just over 126 decibels, equivalent to the noise of a large pneumatic hammer or a racing car travelling at top speed, the organisers of Sunday's event said.

She outscreamed a male rival, Pawel Dabrowski, 35, from Warsaw, who produced a five-second scream of 125.3 decibels, defending his 1999 title of best male screamer.

Europe's only vocal noise competition, modelled on an annual screaming festival in Japan, took place in the town of Goldap in Poland's northeastern lake district, and was broadcast live on state television.

The contestants ranged in age from a girl of four to a man of 74, and came from Poland, the US, the Czech Republic and Austria.

"We allowed them to scream greetings like 'I love you' or 'I like you' . . . the only restriction was they were not allowed to swear," said the director, Andrzej Sokolowski, who has organised the contest for the past four years with the Goldap Sports Council.

One young Polish man, he said, used the occasion to propose to his girlfriend.

"The Austrians were the most musical," he added, "probably due to their yodelling tradition."

Ms Stanek said she planned to defend her title again next year.

"This comes from practising screaming every day down by the lakes," she said. "I'm not married yet, but when I am I'll be able to try this out on my husband and improve still further."

Mr Dabrowski said his friends were shocked when he discovered his talent.

"I'm a placid man at heart, but I must admit this is a good way to vent my frustrations," he said.

The winners each took home a colour television set, and Ms Dagmara received a bonus prize of a live 20kg (44lb) turkey.

The judges measured the highest scream level of each contestant with equipment normally used by environmental inspectors to check noisy workplaces and neighbours.

Mr Sokolowski said he hoped to persuade representatives of the Guinness Book of Records to record the results at next year's competition.

Following the success of his screaming competition, Mr Sokolowski established an annual beer drinking contest,

Heis also behind Poland's first kissing championship, to be held in Goldap in October.

webTitle: Gadafy pays to free island hostages

fields.headline: Gadafy pays to free island hostages
fields.trailText: The 16-week hostage crisis on the Philippine jungle island of Jolo could be over within a day following the intervention of the Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy, according to reports in a German daily paper.
fields.body:
The 16-week hostage crisis on the Philippine jungle island of Jolo could be over within a day following the intervention of the Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy, according to reports in a German daily paper.

Die Welt reported yesterday that Colonel Gadafy had put up a ransom of $25m (£16.6m) for the freedom of the western hostages who have been held by the Muslim separatist group Abu Sayyaf since April 23.

Rahab Assurak, a former Libyan ambassador to the Philippines and a leading negotiator in the hostage affair, told Die Welt on Monday that the hostages would be "freed within the next 48 hours".

"I'm absolutely certain that the hostages will soon be back home," he added.

According to Die Welt, a private Libyan jet was waiting at Manila airport to take the hostages home. Libyan doctors were on board.

Mr Assurak said the hostages were due to board the plane last night for the flight to Tripoli, where they would be expected today.

Mr Assurak was engaged by the Gadafy Charity Organisation three months ago to work as a negotiator because of his good contacts in the region.

Twenty-one foreign tourists and workers were seized from a diving resort on the Malaysian island of Sipadan almost four months ago by the Muslim militants and taken to Jolo. The militants later made more abductions.

In recent weeks one German and six Malaysians from the Sipadan group, together with a German journalist and two Filipino reporters, have been freed. The militants have also released three people seized in other kidnappings.

Six of the remaining hostages are French, three Malaysian, two German, two Finnish, two South African and 14 Filipino. Their mental and physical state is said to be deteriorating all the time, and some are threatening suicide, according to a message written by one of them.

There was speculation yesterday that the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, might fly to Tripoli to meet the two remaining German hostages, Werner Wallert and his son Marc. Renate Wallert, Werner's wife, was released on July 17, suffering from a nervous breakdown.

Germany is alleged to have paid a total of DM12m (£3.7m) for the release of Mrs Wallert and a reporter from Der Spiegel magazine.

The Libyan ransom is said to be part of Col Gadafy's attempt to escape from political isolation.

Mr Assurak said the ransom money would be used for schools, hospitals, plantation development and other humanitarian causes.

webTitle: United Airlines faces difficult ride in its attempted link with rival

fields.headline: Turbulence upsets the party spirit
fields.standfirst: United Airlines faces a difficult ride in its attempted link with rival
fields.trailText: What should an airline do if its staff is in revolt, its performance has nosedived and nobody believes that its multi-billion dollar acquisition of a rival will succeed?
fields.body:
What should an airline do if its staff is in revolt, its performance has nosedived and nobody believes that its multi-billion dollar acquisition of a rival will succeed?

United Airlines, the world's largest carrier with 2,330 flights a day, has decided that the answer is to spend $500,000 on funding this week's Democratic party convention in Los Angeles.

The US company has been hit with a wave of bad news in the past week. Few analysts expect it to be in party spirit in spite of its generosity. Several Wall Street analysts downgraded the company's third quarter earnings estimates last week after the carrier warned that its union troubles and cancelled flights would cost at least $50m this year.

The company has cut its September flight schedule by 3%, about 2,000 trips, citing bad weather, air traffic control issues and the unsolved dispute with its powerful pilots' union over a new contract. More than 1,000 flights were cancelled last week. United's 10,000 pilots, who together with other staff members own more than half of the company, are refusing to fly overtime.

Generosity

The argument between the two sides has become more heated. United blames staff for an increase in sick days off and maintenance calls, while the unions say the company does not want to take on more pilots, which, they maintain, it desperately needs.

The dispute is taking its toll on the company. In the first week of August fewer than 40% of United's domestic flights arrived within 15 minutes of their schedule, down from 57% in May, when the company announced its proposed $4.3bn acquisition of US Airways. Amid such turmoil, United's position as the tenth largest contributor of "in-kind" money to this week's Democratic convention may appear odd. The connection between the US airline industry and the country's political establishment has always been close. United, American Airlines and Northwest are among the top 70 corporate political donors in the US this year while US Airways, United's intended partner, was a significant donor to the Republican party convention.

None of this generosity is directed at any particular issue, though the industry does need political favour to consolidate. In the last few weeks United has appointed former deputy White House chief of staff Harold Ickes to help its lobbying efforts. Mr Ickes has been an adviser to Hillary Clinton in the New York Senate race.

United's attempt to buy US Airways, the smallest of the six main US carriers, needs regulatory approval from the department of justice. One Washington source said yesterday Mr Ickes's "heavyweight appointment" could help United win support for its proposed acquisition.

It also needs to convince individual politicians in the Senate that the merger will improve current levels of service, and not lead to job cuts or fewer flights.

At Senate hearings in June, United argued that the merger would improve service. But politicians, who were not convinced by the airline, took turns to ask what the merger meant for their constituency. One government official described the hearings as a "public dance".

The head of Mercer Management Consulting's global aviation practice Peter Walsh says the merger should go ahead. "I think some consolidation has to be good for the industry," he says. It would benefit both parties. It would allow United to route some of its flights through US Airways' east coast hubs rather than Chicago, which is renowned for air traffic control delays. It would also permit the smaller company to use the international network, says Mr Walsh.

Others, such as employees and some politicians, are less sanguine about the plans. They fear it would lead to other mergers and regional monopolies. At the earlier Senate hearings, John Conyers, a senior Democrat on the House judiciary committee, said: "We've already seen the creation of non-competitive markets in many cities ... I'm concerned that the United-US Airways merger could trigger a spate of other airline mergers."

Such fears were exacerbated by takeover talks between American, Northwest, Delta and Continental after United announced its acquisition plans.

British Airways, keen to do a deal with American, and KLM, which has an alliance with Northwest, also entered the takeover scene in June. The US and UK governments will be discussing transatlantic flights next month in London.

United's unions scuppered the last attempt at a merger between the company and US Airways in 1995. In May this year, the Airline Pilots Association at United expressed its "strong concerns" about the current deal.

Wall Street's arbitrage traders are already betting that the deal will not go ahead. Shares in US Airways were trading at about $37 yesterday, well below the $60 a share offered by United.

United and US Airways remain confident that their deal with gain approval.

Few analysts believe that any decision will be forthcoming before the Presidential elections, for political as well as corpporate reasons.
